TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Army Training Manual
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.The Army training manual entitled Aid to the Civil Power is counter to Australian and international covenants on civil liberties.
2.This manual threatens the human rights of Australians and is an attack upon the democratic rights of the citizens of this country.

3.We call on the Government to hold an open public enquiry into this document to establish how and why it was thought necessary to train Australian Army personnel in illegal and undemocratic procedures.
4.We seek assurances from the Government of community input and access to any document relating to Australian Defence Personnel involvement in civil protest or industrial disputes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes any United Nations inspired intervention by the Federal Government in the democratically enacted laws of the State of Tasmania noting that the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, admits that the recent ruling by the United Nations has no direct impact on Australian or Tasmanian law.

Your petitioners request that the Senate uphold the purposes of its formation and support the right of the State of Tasmania to determine its own social laws through its democratically elected Parliament and oppose any legislation seeking to override Tasmania's laws.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the Pension age for women from 60 to 65.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Haiti
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled
The Petition of the undersigned urges the Government to reject any move which will give encouragement to the Government of the United States to invade Haiti.
We also urge the Government NOT to send any police to an invaded Haiti as this will give solace to the illegal invasion by the US.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to insist that the former President Aristide be reinstated by peaceful means. We remember with sadness that the US invasion of Panama caused 10,000 civilian deaths and the likely invasion of Haiti will cause a similar number of casualties.

PETITION.TITLE: UN Convention on Desertification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We, the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the proposed signing of the UN Convention on Desertification has the potential to adversely affect the rights of farmers to manage their farms, and of local authorities to govern their shires as well as infringing the constitutional responsibility of the states on land management issues.
We therefore request that the treaty not be signed without first receiving the scrutiny and approval of the Senate and subject to such reservations as the Senate might recommend.
As your petitioners in duty bound shall ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to provide for a remission power in the Quarantine Act 1908 for fees charged for the provision of quarantine services by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS).

The remission power will allow revenue collections which are surplus to cost recovery requirements in a financial year to be returned to the relevant industry groups in the form of uniform fee rebates in the following financial year.

As a public monopoly providing regulatory services, AQIS needs to be able to justify its pricing policies to its clients. It also needs to make its costs and recoveries visible to them. An enhanced client focus is and will continue to be an integral part of the reform of AQIS announced in the 1994 budget.

Significant increases in industry activity and reductions in operating costs arising from the ongoing reform process resulted in surplus revenue from quarantine inspection activities of approximately $6.1 million during 1993/94.

Consistent with the closer relationship which AQIS has endeavoured to develop with its clients, the issue of an appropriate mechanism in which surplus revenue can be returned to the relevant industries has been the subject of detailed discussions with representatives of those industries. The fee rebate proposal has been developed as a result of these discussions.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, I present the report of the committee entitled Australians all: enhancing Australian citizenship, together with submissions, transcripts of evidence and briefings, minutes of proceedings, an issues paper entitled Inquiry into enhancing the meaning of Australian citizenship and a report prepared for the committee of overseas citizenship practices.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to table the report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration entitled Australians all, enhancing Australian citizenship. The report is a comprehensive analysis of Australian citizenship law and practice. It contains 56 recommendations aimed at strengthening and revitalising Australian citizenship.

PARA.TAB: Throughout the inquiry, the committee perceived a genuine community interest in raising awareness of and understanding about Australian citizenship. The committee is sympathetic to the view expressed in a number of submissions that, if Australian citizenship is to carry enhanced meaning, the foundation stone of that citizenship, namely, the Australian Citizenship Act, should be accessible and easily understood by those who already are and those who aspire to be Australian citizens. In this regard the committee has recommended: a redraft of the Citizenship Act by 1999, the 50th anniversary of Australian citizenship; a redraft of the citizenship regulations so that they operate as a comprehensive, accessible and easily understood guide in relation to citizenship; production of a reader's guide to the Citizenship Act and regulations; and production of a citizenship booklet for wide public distribution.

To enhance the symbolic meaning of the Citizenship Act, the committee has proposed that the preamble to the Citizenship Act be revised and expanded so that it is based on certain fundamental principles of Australian society as enunciated in the National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia. Much of the evidence to the inquiry indicated that increasing community awareness about citizenship is the best way to enhance its meaning.

The committee agrees with the sentiment expressed in a variety of submissions that those who are well informed about the meaning of citizenship are more likely to become citizens, and that well-informed citizens are more likely to become active citizens who participate in and contribute effectively to the community. Accordingly, the committee has recommended the development and implementation of a broad-based education and information program on citizenship, including: citizenship courses for migrants of English and non-English speaking background; and a national curriculum for citizenship education, to be implemented as a national priority through the school system.

The committee also has recommended the development and implementation of a national strategy for citizenship promotion which should include: a national citizenship week held on an annual basis; national citizenship awards; and a year of Australian citizenship in 1999, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Australian citizenship.

The committee also has targeted citizenship ceremonies for improvement by recommending that: citizenship be conferred principally at public ceremonies; prescribed minimum guidelines be established for the conduct of citizenship ceremonies; the guidelines for the conduct of citizenship ceremonies be updated regularly, and include suggestions for improving the meaning of those ceremonies.

The committee considered the legislative provisions governing the acquisition and loss of citizenship. Many of these matters are of a technical nature. The broad thrust of the committee's recommendations on Australian citizenship law are to simplify and clarify the residence requirement for grant of citizenship; retain the existing rules for acquisition of citizenship by birth; retain the existing requirement for registration of children born overseas to Australian citizens, but extend the concession for those who are not registered by the time they turn 18 years of age; increase the powers of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to revoke citizenship where that citizenship is based on permanent residence gained by fraud; waive the citizenship application fee for British child migrants; and extend the Defence Force concession.

In terms of the core criteria for the grant of citizenship, the committee notes in its report that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) indicated at the outset of the inquiry that those criteria were not in need of amendment. Indeed, limited evidence on the criteria was received by the committee. Nevertheless, it is evident that there is a variety of views in the community about those criteria. For this reason, the committee has proposed that a review of the core criteria be conducted in the lead-up to the 50th anniversary of Australian citizenship in 1999.

The committee also examined the administrative arrangements for the processing of citizenship applications. The committee found that the acquisition of citizenship by grant involves a streamlined administrative process aimed at producing a speedy determination with minimal inconvenience to the applicant. While the committee commends the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for establishing such a system, the committee is concerned that the system may have become too focused on administrative processing and insufficiently focused on the careful evaluation of applicants for citizenship. Accordingly, the committee has recommended upgraded citizenship interviews to provide for careful and thorough evaluation of the criteria for grant of citizenship; enhanced guidelines for officers conducting citizenship interviews; and greater emphasis on immigration status, character and security checking of citizenship applicants, with access by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to a comprehensive and up-to-date national index of criminal activities.

The committee also has recommended a six-month time limit from when citizenship is granted to when it must be conferred; a specific power for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to revoke citizenship certificates before citizenship is conferred; improved practice for ensuring the enrolment of new citizens on the electoral roll; and on-line access to the records of state registrars of births, deaths and marriages for the purpose of passport issue.

To further enhance the meaning of citizenship, the committee has proposed that greater prominence should be given to citizenship within the existing portfolio arrangements. As the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs itself told the committee, we should stop thinking about citizenship as something that migrants get. The committee has recommended that the department responsible for administering the Citizenship Act should be renamed the department of citizenship, immigration and ethnic affairs. This will help all Australians to recognise that citizenship is a matter of significance to the Commonwealth and will ensure that Australians are readily able to identify which Commonwealth agency is responsible for citizenship matters.

In line with this recommendation, the committee considers that it would be more appropriate for all the functions associated with citizenship to be controlled by one Commonwealth department. For this reason, the committee has recommended that the government consider transferring responsibility for administration of the passport function to a renamed department of citizenship, immigration and ethnic affairs.

The issue of dual citizenship attracted considerable attention during the inquiry. The overwhelming view of submissions was that Australia's insistence on single citizenship for those born in Australia is outmoded and discriminatory. In a world of increasing mobility, it was considered anachronistic that one section of the Australian population should be disadvantaged by a prohibition on accessing more than one citizenship.

The existing legislation has long accepted dual citizenship. It is only fair and equitable that the opportunity to acquire the citizenship of another country should be extended to all Australian citizens. Accordingly, the committee has recommended the repeal of section 17 of the Citizenship Act, thereby allowing Australian citizens to acquire dual citizenship. The committee also has recommended that those who have lost Australian citizenship under section 17 have the unqualified right to apply for the resumption of their Australian citizenship.

Tolerance of diversity is a cornerstone of a multicultural Australian society. The ultimate expression of such tolerance would be the recognition that while Australian citizens owe their primary allegiance to Australia, they also can show a commitment to their country of origin or the country in which they are resident. (Extension of time granted)

As chairman of the committee, and on behalf of the committee, I wish to express my sincere appreciation to all those who contributed to this inquiry, be it by way of submission or appearance before the committee at public hearings. I thank my fellow committee members, particularly the deputy chairman, Senator Short. Special thanks also are due to the committee secretary, Mr Andres Lomp, who is here in the advisers gallery; the committee's legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin; the inquiry staff, Mr Stephen Boyd, Ms Dianne Fraser and Mr Pete Tighe; as well as the committee's parliamentary intern, Ms Rosemary Van Der Meer.

The history of Australian citizenship may be brief, but all Australians can be proud of that citizenship and what it represents. Australian citizenship is a symbol of unity in a multicultural society which draws strength from diversity. Adoption of the committee's recommendations will enhance Australian citizenship as we, Australians all, prepare to meet the challenges of the new century. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, I have much pleasure in joining the Chairman, Senator McKiernan, in commenting briefly on this report and congratulating him on his chairmanship of the committee. He did an excellent job. I think, and I hope, our colleagues will feel that that is reflected in the quality of the report that has been produced. At the outset, I would also like to join Senator McKiernan in thanking all those who contributed to the report, particularly those who made submissions and who appeared before the committee, and especially all members of the staff of the committee, in particular, without naming everyone—Senator McKiernan has already done that—our secretary, Andres Lomp, and our consultant adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this is a very important report because the issue of citizenship really goes very much to the whole core of what it means to be Australian, what we feel about Australia, what being an Australian citizen means and what the term citizenship means. It was very interesting, we found as members of the committee, to see the differing views that were expressed in the wide number of submissions that we received as to what was really meant by citizenship and the values of citizenship. Interestingly, the first paragraph of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: No substantive evidence was presented to indicate that the meaning of Australian citizenship would be enhanced if citizenship was of greater practical value. Indeed, the Committee is sympathetic to the view that an individual's desire to acquire citizenship should be based on a person's sense of commitment to Australia rather than a person's desire to secure particular benefits for himself/herself or his/her family.

I think the members of the committee individually supported that view, which was heavily reflected in the submissions that we received. I hope the report reflects that, essentially, citizenship is really all about a commitment to Australia and to the basic, core values that most Australians accept. Whilst they often find these hard to define, almost innately they know what they mean.

PARA.TAB: The other important point that came forward and that I would like to emphasise—and Senator McKiernan commented on this in his remarks—is that citizenship is more than just for migrants to Australia. At the moment the only people who actually receive a citizenship certificate are those who are granted citizenship by virtue of coming to Australia, meeting the residential requirements of a minimum of two years, applying for citizenship, attending a citizenship ceremony and being granted citizenship. All the rest of us, who were born in Australia, never go through that and, therefore, we take citizenship more for granted and perhaps with a bit of a yawn than those who come to our shores and actually go through the act of taking citizenship.

Various submissions were received, very interestingly, through an organisation chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen and other organisations. Various suggestions were made as to how the concept of citizenship in a practical way could be made more significant for us—I do not mean by practical benefits, but in bringing it home to us that we are Australian citizens even though we have not, as Australian-born citizens, gone through the actual process of being granted citizenship. I think that is something we ought to look at more as a parliament and as a nation in the future.

I will highlight just a few of the 56 important recommendations made by the committee. Recommendations 10 and 11 deal with the question of guidelines for the conduct of citizenship ceremonies which must be followed by the minister's delegate conducting the ceremonies. I think that is a very important point. As members of parliament, we all too often, quite rightly, receive complaints from people who have gone through citizenship ceremonies. People tell us what a deadly, dull, boring process it was and that they came away feeling very disappointed. They go through an event which is a very important step in their life, but they leave feeling that they had to sit through a pretty pathetic performance. As a committee, we believe that there should be a set of minimum guidelines that need to be met in terms of the conduct of citizenship ceremonies. I think that is a very important point.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new oath of citizenship has been a big improvement.

—There are different views on that. That was not a matter that was dealt with in any detail by the committee. This is a non-partisan debate, I hope, so I will not get into that, other than to say that I basically disagree with Senator Schacht.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 11—and I think it is an important one too because I hope it will help upgrade the level of the citizenship ceremonies—is that the Commonwealth government should provide a subsidy for citizenship ceremonies to those local government authorities which conduct public citizenship ceremonies in accordance with the prescribed guidelines. At the moment, local government bears the full cost. As local government is doing this as the delegate, in effect, of the Commonwealth, it is right that it should be paid an appropriate subsidy.

Recommendation 16 is important. It recommends that the Citizenship Act be redrafted, using simple language and being recast in modern legal drafting style. It recommends that this rewriting be in place for the 50th anniversary of Australian citizenship in 1999.

Recommendation 28 is also important. It deals with the review of the core criteria for citizenship and recommends that such review be conducted in the lead-up to the 50th anniversary. Some of us had difficulty in coming to grips with those core criteria. Therefore, this area certainly needs to be looked at and given careful re-evaluation and review over the period leading up to the 50th anniversary.

The recommendation for upgrading interviews for citizenship applications is another important recommendation. Concern was expressed by members of the committee and by some of those making submissions to it about the quality of the interview process that applicants have to go through in order to acquire citizenship. It is a very important thing that they are seeking and we should all be sure that they have been subjected to the necessary quality of interview before being deemed eligible for the grant of citizenship.

Senator McKiernan mentioned the recommendation to rename the department to include the word `citizenship'. That picks up the recommendation that all matters pertaining to citizenship should be governed by what is now the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and therefore that it be renamed the department of citizenship, immigration and ethnic affairs.

Finally, I draw the attention of all Australians to the recommendations in relation to dual citizenship, particularly that section 17 of the Citizenship Act be repealed so that Australians who wish to take citizenship of another country are able to do that while retaining their own Australian citizenship. It is estimated that there are almost three million Australians who are already dual citizens by virtue of having been born overseas. It seems appropriate and equitable that the opportunity for dual citizenship be extended to Australian-born citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to say something about this essential report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, and I use the word `essential' advisedly. There is a legal concept to citizenship but, more importantly, there is also a spiritual one. There must be a moving of the heart and soul towards those qualities that make the ideal Australian community. That is the basis of this report.

PARA.TAB: The qualities which make the ideal Australian community include: our unity as a people; a culture with a vast range of roots; the universal reign of tolerance and legal equality between all people; the rule of law and the predominance of high principles. That concept underlies this excellent report on citizenship.

A lot of the report's recommendations might seem to be mundane but they are not so if we consider what gives rise to them. As Senator Short said, citizenship is a matter that we should take very seriously. Perhaps we do not take it as seriously as we should. If we did, the recommendations in this report would make a great deal of sense.

We have in Australia a very rich culture that has been brought here by people from many lands. The chairperson of this committee is Senator Jim McKiernan, who, may I say, Mr Deputy President, as you know, turned 50 yesterday, quite a young age to be in this place but, nevertheless, an important milestone. He came from Ireland, which has, amongst other nations, produced people over the years in this country that have done great things for it. Of course, if we go back to the last century many a person came in all sorts of ways to this country whose descendants have contributed mightily to this place.

It would be a pity if the concepts of Australian citizenship stopped with this report. I see this report as a basis for further consideration about citizenship. As I say, it would be a pity if we got tangled into legal concepts of who is a citizen and who is not and what should be done to the person who is not a citizen but is in Australia. Those things are necessary matters to take on board in underpinning a much higher consideration that should be given to what we are as an Australian nation.

I think that Senator McKiernan and Senator Short have covered the essential thrust of the report. I just wanted to emphasise, as they both did, that it is the spiritual content of citizenship that we are mainly concerned with, and the recommendations we have made are matters that, we hope, will go to protect that concept. I will finish by simply seeking leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on a system of national indicators and benchmarks for citizens' rights and obligations be extended to 31 May 1995.
Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Teague:

That the Declaration by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs of 10 July 1994, as contained in Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. 5270, and made under subsection 10(1) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, relating to Hindmarsh Island, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion that Senator Teague presented yesterday relating to the declaration made by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) on 10 July 1994. The Greens (WA) most certainly do not support the disallowance motion. It is true that there has been some concern, but Professor Cheryl Saunders actually made the point in her report that it was inevitable that the outcome of the report would not be pleasing to everybody. She said that, whatever the outcome, there would be great disappointment on the part of some, and she hoped that the divisions would be healed in time and that planning for the future would be made possible through constructive cooperation, drawing on the lessons of the past.

PARA.TAB: There are many lessons to learn from this particular decision. I have received some letters protesting the outcome of Professor Saunders's report, which was that Mr Tickner, the federal minister for Aboriginal affairs, placed a protection order over the sacred sites at Goolwa and Kumarangk, the Hindmarsh Island in South Australia. I have also been privileged to visit the area and meet hundreds of people who were deeply concerned at the extent to which development was going to affect that area.

People may know that the area under consideration is unique. The area—the Murray mouth and the Coorong—is of national importance. Some honourable senators will be familiar with the movie Storm Boy, which demonstrated the unique environmental features and the beauty of this place. Environmentalists have been struggling to make sure that the encroachment of a bridge and development on Hindmarsh Island does not destroy the environmental features of this area. So its environmental values are well known. Lesser known, but of even greater importance, is the history of this place and the Aboriginal significance of this area—in particular, its significance to Aboriginal women.

Yesterday Senator Teague talked about the fact that these women's issues had not been heard of until April of this year, four years after the proposals had been through some form of environmental scrutiny and assessment and the approval to go ahead had been, at least in part, given. I think that illustrates a very serious problem about the ways in which the state Labor government of that time actually addressed the issues of this unique and important area.

The various decisions that had been made prior to a proper and adequate consultation should prompt questions about the process that led to the approval of the bridge development in the first place. It is quite clear that the process failed to take full account of either environmental considerations or Aboriginal considerations.

I was very concerned about some of the comments that Senator Teague made. In referring to the Saunders report, he said that the personal consultations that Professor Saunders had with women and also the protected and confidential nature of the disclosures she received were the flimsiest basis for the protection order. I think everybody who knows anything about this issue would be offended by that statement.

I would like to know whether Senator Teague has discussed the situation with his wife, who is a personal friend of mine and who I know would have similar values. I think it is impertinent for men who know that this area has major Aboriginal significance to Aboriginal women to declare as `flimsy' evidence that they have not seen. It is an extremely important area. On page 2 of her report, Professor Saunders said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the custodians of this knowledge described the area to me as "the most important place for the Aboriginal people of the Lower South".
That is both men and women. The report continued:

Viewed from this perspective, the bridge presents a threat to the area in the form of a permanent prominent and physical link above the water between two parts of the territory which would, in accordance with Ngarrindjeri tradition, render the cosmos, and human beings within it, "sterile" and unable to reproduce. The Ngarrindjeri women believe that construction of the bridge would not only injure and desecrate their traditions but destroy their culture . . . Within Aboriginal tradition, the specifics of this knowledge may not be passed onto a man.

I believe it is very important that we respect that and that we also respect the integrity and the credibility of Professor Cheryl Saunders and her inquiry. I have talked to women of this area and I can confirm that it is of extremely great importance to them. I believe that Aboriginal spirituality and historical tradition will be affected—no doubt they have already been affected because this area is the burial site of many Aboriginal people. As Aboriginal people would point out to us, `We don't come and desecrate your cemeteries, but you want to desecrate our burial sites with your developments.'

PARA.TAB: Destruction of Aboriginal women's spirituality has already occurred. I think it would be a loss for all Australians if we allowed further damage and desecration to take place. It would be our loss because we would be damaging our own integrity as a nation by not respecting what we would respect within our own culture in terms of our own burial sites and our own cemeteries.

The letters that I received indicate that some people are concerned. They believe the reports of the people who favour the development, that Goolwa and district will suffer economic losses of $175 million and 1,200 jobs. I remind senators that there is no loss involved here; all it is, is savings. It is prevention of an expenditure of $175 million which will destroy not only Aboriginal heritage but Australian national heritage.

I might add that the site is already known as a unique tourist attraction. People flood to that area to see the unique qualities represented there. I think it would interfere with a great deal more of the development of that area to use such an important area as a bridge site that brings development to the island which damages both the environment and the Aboriginal significance of the area.

Reconciliation will continue. We have to recognise that, while some people are extremely bitter that Aboriginal voices have been listened to at this time, it has been one of the most important steps in the reconciliation process that the minister for aboriginal affairs has heeded the voices of the Ngarrindjeri people. He has responded to the views of the Ngarrindjeri women, has stored them for posterity by having obtained such a detailed and thorough report, and has allowed protection of that area for 25 years.

The view of the environment and conservation movement, which failed to protect the environmental significance of the area and was under great threat from the state government and the developers because of legal sanctions, has declared this as very positive. It is not just a decision about Hindmarsh Island, those people say, but a just decision. I will quote the spokesperson for the council, David Shearman. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Significant harm to the Ngarrindjeri people, the Aboriginal community in general, the reconciliation process and the fragile environment of Hindmarsh Island has been avoided.
In his press release he went on to say:

The Conservation Council recognises the sensitivities of State Rights versus Federal decisions, but there will always be occasions when for reasons of environmental damage or human rights, a national approach has to be taken. The State Government was too locked in legally to be able to make the appropriate decisions.

We hope that the extensive investigations by Professor Saunders, an independent legal expert, will be the first step in the healing process whereby the entire community can move forward together to provide a fruitful, environmentally wise and economically sustainable future for the Murray mouth region. Draft plans for appropriate development are already available which have the support of the Ngarrindjeri people and environmentalists. Dr Shearman concludes by saying:

Let us thank Mr Tickner for a wise and just decision, analyse our mistakes, avoid recrimination and move forward to appropriate development based on our shared heritage which can therefore be supported by all the community.

This is a very important feature. We could not hope to have reconciliation without restoration of historical justice. Desecration of a sacred burial site, a site of extreme and private significance to Aboriginal women, is not compatible with restoration of historical justice. Any reconciliation process which allows desecration to happen first cannot be true reconciliation.

PARA.TAB: Last weekend I met some Aboriginal women in Adelaide at the women's conference. They expressed joy at the positive steps that have been taken by the protection of their area. They say that reconciliation is moving on apace thanks to the intervention by the minister for Aboriginal affairs, Robert Tickner, and this protection order. That is why the Greens have no intention of supporting any disallowance of what we see as a very valuable step forward in the history of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to oppose this disallowance motion. I noted Senator Teague's disparagement in his speech yesterday of the Aboriginal claims. I begin by drawing attention to the speech which was made by the Hon. Dr Michael Armitage, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the South Australian parliament, a Liberal parliament, when he gave permission for the damage of the Aboriginal sites on Hindmarsh Island.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note what Dr Armitage said because, quite clearly, the Liberal government recognised the importance of these Aboriginal sites, recognised that it was in a difficult situation with respect to contracts entered into in the dying moments of the previous Labor government in South Australia and was really doing a balancing act. It was with great reluctance, in recognition of the importance of the sites, that the minister gave this order. I would like to read some of what he had to say. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to inform the House that I have today reluctantly issued an authorisation to the Department of Road Transport to allow damage to Aboriginal sites to the minimal extent necessary to allow the construction of a bridge to Hindmarsh Island.
I will come back to that later. Clearly the bridge, in giving increased access to the island, would be a prelude to much more extensive damage occurring on Hindmarsh Island. He continued:
This authority has been given under s.23 of the Aboriginal Heritage Act following consultations with the Aboriginal community and further archaeological site work.
The minister went on to say that it was a personal decision. He continued:
I have come to this decision aware of these facts.
Yet, it gave me no pleasure to make this decision.
Firstly, the Government has explored all legal measures to extricate ourselves from this difficult situation.

Dr Armitage is drawing attention there to the fact that clearly he recognises the importance of these sites to the Aboriginal people, but also recognises that the South Australian government was in a situation not of its making but in which it found itself as a consequence of decisions of the previous Labor government. He then said:
Secondly, as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I recognise that Aboriginal sites will be damaged by the construction—
He is referring there to the construction of the bridge, and I will return to the further construction on Hindmarsh Island that this bridge would have caused had it been allowed—
and that this fact causes great distress to the Aboriginal community.

Quite contrary to what Senator Teague was saying yesterday, even the Liberal government in South Australia recognised that the decision to go ahead with the bridge would cause great distress to the Aboriginal community. The minister continued:
The Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee, representing the Ngarrindjeri people, remains implacably opposed to the construction of the bridge.

I have met with representatives of the Committee on at least four occasions and discussed their concerns. My staff and I have had numerous written and telephone communications with members of the Committee and their legal representatives. All of these communications leave me in no doubt of the Aboriginal opposition to the construction of the bridge and that the community will be extremely disappointed.

I stress again that that was the Liberal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the difficult situation in which he found himself. With great reluctance he signed that order to allow what he clearly recognised would result in significant damage to sites which were important to Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the claims which have been made by Senator Teague in relation to the smallness and the inadequacy, as he put it, of the Aboriginal women's claims really stand up. We have evidence from essentially Senator Teague's own side of politics saying that there was recognition of the very great significance of Hindmarsh Island to the Aboriginal people and the destruction which would be caused by the bridge.

When I took the position of supporting the Aboriginal people in relation to this claim, I was written to by a number of people from Hindmarsh Island and the Goolwa region, objecting to the position which I had taken and claiming, together with some documentary evidence, that not to build the bridge would result in very significant financial damage to those people, particularly to the people on the island. Amongst other things, it was claimed that there was some $80 million worth of speculative gain to be made from land subdivision on Hindmarsh Island.

I find it rather strange that only yesterday the opposition, in the form of Senator Michael Baume, criticised the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for buying an expensive house in Sydney and engaging in property development—whereas the Prime Minister was saying, quite correctly, that money should be put into productive investment and not into speculation. Yet the opposition is evidently supporting the investment of $80 million not in actual development of property but in property speculation by way of land sales on Hindmarsh Island. I would have thought the opposition would be opposed to the redirection of $80 million into property speculation instead of into productive investment. I think the opposition is being quite inconsistent with respect to that.

I turn to the issue of what will actually happen as a consequence of this bridge being built. We need to look no further than a letter written to me by the District Council of Port Elliot and Goolwa. I refer to a number of paragraphs which clearly indicate that the District Council of Port Elliot and Goolwa saw the construction of this bridge as a prelude to massive development on Hindmarsh Island, with housing developments, marinas, hotels, motels and convention centres; in other words, the turning of Hindmarsh Island essentially into a mini Gold Coast. Anybody would see that that is inconsistent with the environmental qualities of Hindmarsh Island, the important wetlands which surround it and the protection of the Aboriginal heritage of the area. I quote from some paragraphs contained in the letter from the District Council of Port Elliot and Goolwa:

SPEECH.PARA: There is increasing pressure for development of housing on waterfront land in the region due to the substantial development of existing foreshore and riverside residential land elsewhere on the Encounter coast. Because of the existence of extensive shoreline and low level depressions on Hindmarsh Island the emphasis on new development to accommodate both housing and boat moorings is shifting to the Island.

Well before this, there were already four proposals, going back as far as 1988, for very extensive marina developments associated with motels and restaurants, accommodating many hundreds of boats and houses. Clearly, the council is supporting this type of development. The letter continues:

The only road access to Hindmarsh Island is provided by means of a ferry crossing at Goolwa. The ferry is operated by the Department of Road Transport and provides a continuous service carrying approximately 12 normal sized motor cars with a cycle time of 9 to 10 minutes. This service is adequate for normal purposes—
And I draw attention to that comment; clearly, the council recognises that the ferry service is adequate for the present development on Hindmarsh Island—
but with the development of the Island—
This is what is being anticipated; this is the point that needs to be stressed—
for recreational, tourist and residential use the ferry crossing becomes over taxed during peak periods causing lengthy delays in crossing.

The council is clearly not looking on the bridge simply as access to the one marina, the Binalong marina which was the subject of the agreement between the former Labor government in South Australia and Binalong, but is looking for much more extensive development which would make the ferry service inadequate.

PARA.TAB: Therefore the council is anticipating not just the construction of the bridge and the damage that that would do to the Aboriginal sites, but also further encroachment onto the island with recreational, tourist and residential use, and the ferry would then become inadequate. The council goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The visitor interest is derived from. . . the natural environment and in particular the bird life which breeds in and frequents the wetlands and waters around Hindmarsh Island.
The council recognises the environmental importance of the island. The council further says:
Increasing pressure from visitors can be expected due to the proximity of the Island to a growing metropolitan population.

The council is recognising the increasing pressure and it wants to shift that pressure onto the island by building a bridge and giving greater access; yet in the previous paragraph the council has recognised the environmental importance of Hindmarsh Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —You misinterpret them; the mayor supports the bridge.
—I will get onto that, Senator Teague, in a moment. The council continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The natural attributes of the Island and its waterways are attracting heavy boat usage with resultant demand for facilities.
There again the council is anticipating those facilities going on Hindmarsh Island.

PARA.TAB: Picking up Senator Teague's point: what the mayor and the council evidently do not recognise—and I regard them as being naive, stupid or deliberately blind—is that environmental protection is inconsistent with the heavy demand—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order. I ask Senator Coulter to withdraw his accusation that the mayor and councillors of Goolwa are stupid.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I would say that they were either naive or dissimulating when they were attempting to argue that this heavy development, which they clearly anticipate, is consistent with environmental protection. We have repeatedly seen that that type of heavy development is not consistent with environmental protection; with the birdlife and the wetlands and so on which the council has identified. Therefore I believe that they are inconsistent and not to be taken seriously when they are supporting the bridge and the development which they clearly anticipate would follow. The council continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years the South Coast area has expanded rapidly to become one of the fastest growing urban areas within South Australia. The District Council of Port Elliot and Goolwa increased its population by 22.4% from the census of 1986 to the census of 1991. This has resulted in increased demand for permanent accommodation and it is predicted that this trend will continue. Council has supported the further development of allotments on Hindmarsh Island due to the attractiveness of the Island, its potential for waterfront development and the marginal nature of agricultural land on the Island. Development should be pursued and encouraged on the Island so that prime agricultural land in other parts of the Council area is not lost to the State needlessly.

Clearly, the council is anticipating that the agricultural practices on the island are going to be replaced by housing, and that the agricultural practices will shift elsewhere. Again I stress that that is not consistent with the protection of the island for either its environmental values or the values which the Aboriginal people quite significantly have placed on the island, and to which Dr Armitage has drawn our attention. The council goes on:
Ensure substantial development proceeding in the State and in particular in this region.
The council wants this development. That is the council's view of the island. The council says:
Will enable development by way of subdivision of land on land which is marginal agriculturally but physically attractive and stop development of prime agricultural land.
Again, we see this shift from agricultural activities on the island to the mainland and the substitution of those agricultural activities by intensive development on the island.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely clear from these paragraphs that the building of the bridge was and is in the minds of its supporters, both those on the island who hope to make $80 million worth of speculative gain from subdivision and the members of the council, a precondition for rapid subdivision and development of the island—a development which, as I have indicated, in my view, and I think in the view of any dispassionate observer, is quite inconsistent with the protection of those environmental and Aboriginal values which the order of the minister seeks to protect.

It is also clear from so many examples that, under pressures already present among those who want to develop the island, the protection of culturally significant sites, wetlands and the environment generally would become an impossibility and we would finish up seeing a Gold Coast type development on Hindmarsh Island, unless this order by the minister is upheld.

The Democrats have no intention whatsoever of supporting this motion for disallowance. We see the conflict as much wider than the bridge. Senator Baden Teague yesterday tried to narrow the debate down to simply a bridge; yet, as I think I have shown quite convincingly, the bridge is really only a beginning to a much more extensive development. Importantly, it is that more extensive development which would damage those sites of environmental and Aboriginal significance.

The whole area of the lower Murray—together with Hindmarsh Island, the Murray mouth and the two peninsulas framing the mouth and the Coorong—has been occupied by a large population of Aboriginal people for many thousands of years. I do not think that is really in contention. It is of undoubted and very great significance to these Aboriginal people, especially to Aboriginal women.

I have drawn attention again to Dr Armitage's reluctant announcement that he was prepared to damage these sites of significance because of the difficult financial situation in which the South Australian government found itself. The situation is one which, I believe, the federal government has extricated the South Australian government from. I am rather surprised at its present position; I would have thought it would have been quite pleased that it did not have to proceed with the bridge.

Not only has the area provided extremely well for these Aboriginal people in terms of basic sustenance, but also it has acquired this deep spiritual ambience. It generates in Aboriginal people, and in those non-Aboriginal people who understand, this same sense of reverence and respect which many white people would feel when they visit a great church or a cemetery. Having been with Aboriginal people on Hindmarsh Island, down through the Coorong and onto Younghusband Peninsula, one gets a sense of this reverence felt by Aboriginal people.

Just as one would not put ice-cream booths and pizza bars between the headstones of a cemetery, for reasons that Jesus turned the money changers away from the temple, so we should recognise that the developments anticipated for the area as a direct consequence of the building of the bridge—and they are the developments to which I referred earlier, which are in the council's own document—are inappropriate for this area of special significance to the Aboriginal people. That these analogies are not seen by those who would cover the island with houses and marinas is a form of covert racism. Essentially, the Aboriginal people should be acceptable as equals. That is the view of those who would argue for the bridge and for the development. They are saying that Aboriginal people are acceptable as equals, provided they behave and exhibit exactly the same value system as the dominant white culture. Hopefully, we have moved beyond that with the moves towards ATSIC, towards reconciliation and towards the land fund, which we may get to debate later this week. There must be within the total Australian society a recognition of the legitimacy of the alternative Aboriginal cultural system.

Indeed, I would go further: I believe that we need to adopt some of those same values of reverence for land and the environment into the mainstream. That would be of great benefit to the dominant culture.

If reconciliation is to mean anything, it is my firm belief that there must be a two-way movement with the dominant culture moving towards the indigenous culture as well as the Aboriginal moving towards the mainstream. In a sense, the Hindmarsh Island debate is in microcosm a symptom of what is happening in the larger community.

The dominant culture is consumerist and exploitative—everything is tradeable. Of course, we see that in the attitude of the council and of those who would develop land on Hindmarsh Island. Land is simply a commodity to be traded, to be turned into $80 million worth of profit through subdivision. It does not have a reverence attached to it which is part of the Aboriginal view. Land and nature are clearly, in this view, commodities.

Increasingly, we in the white society are recognising that these attitudes have to change, that Western industrial economic systems that represent the fullest expression of these attitudes are indeed wrecking the environment, as they would on Hindmarsh Island, and they are doing this both locally and globally. The environment movement in many ways is a movement back towards those values which allowed indigenous people to live somewhere near balance with the environment for countless thousands of years. Indigenous people achieved this balance by imbuing the physical world with spiritual values and invoking spiritual sanctions for transgression.

I pause here to reflect again on Senator Baden Teague's speech yesterday when he seemed to be arguing that, because the Aboriginal views were, by his standards, in some way irrational, they were to be discounted. I would have thought that if one looked closely, from the point of view of pure rationality, at many of the beliefs in the Christian religion, one would say they are totally irrational. But people hold those views and I think they have a perfect right to have those views accepted with reverence and with respect by others, whether or not they hold those views themselves. The rationality of a view is, I believe, not to be questioned in relation to a religious view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree about respect.

—Senator Teague will get a chance to answer these arguments later. It is not surprising, therefore, that around many of the conservation battles—and Senator Teague himself drew attention to this—there is now a growing convergence of the environment movement and Aboriginal people. I found it really very stimulating to go down to Hindmarsh Island to meet with both white people and Aboriginal people and to see the convergence of the concerns which both sides have for the island. The white people, for their part, were developing that same sense of reverence for the land and the environment which is an integral part of Aboriginal culture.

PARA.TAB: It is my hope that this development portends a similar movement in the wider community. For this balance will not only provide the legitimacy and acceptance of Aboriginal values, which I see as an important part of the reconciliation process, but also provide to the new and emergent culture within Australia those values which will underpin environmental protection and, ultimately, underpin our own human survival.

Much of the argument favouring the bridge comes from those who stand to gain some material advantage, while the argument on the other side comes from those with nothing to gain whatsoever, only a share of what they perceive as the common good. And I believe that this makes the latter position much more believable.

Much of the argument for the bridge is deceptively naive—perhaps deliberately so. It is claimed that the bridge will disturb only two sites—and we heard this from Senator Teague: those containing the footings and bridge approaches. It has been claimed that through strong planning, a bridge could be built without that leading to any further subdivision of land on the island or to any more marinas. This position has been put to me quite strongly by some of the people on the island.

Yet that is totally denied in those clauses which I have read from the council's statement. I believe this is political naivety at its worst. Once better access is provided, the pressure to exploit the island and the area to the south-east, involving the Coorong and Younghusband Peninsula, would be irresistible.

In 1988, and I referred to this earlier, the Binalong development—with 670 residential allotments around an artificial lake, 170 residential apartments, a marina with 1,150 moorings, 500 dry-stand berths, shops, a motel and a chandlery—was being seriously entertained by the then Labor minister for the environment in South Australia, even though the development plan showed the area as non-urban. At that stage, he was suggesting a rezoning.

In addition, several proposals were under consideration through the rezoning process: a proposal for Narnu waterways, with 700 allotments around an artificial lake, a marina and a restaurant; a proposal for 400 allotments and a marina on the north-eastern shore; and a proposal for 200 to 250 allotments on a series of artificial canals, with a wilderness lodge, a motel, a restaurant and a convention centre opposite the Murray mouth. Much of the pressure for the bridge comes from these sources. It is inconceivable to think that, once the bridge was built, this pressure would not be successful in achieving these subdivisions, with many more subdivisions extending across the island.

Increased population pressure would clearly impact adversely on those very values that Aboriginal people and the conservation movement are working so hard to retain and protect. This much larger population would not only lead to the despoliation of the island, but the new residents would seek recreation and penetrate further, and in larger numbers, into the Coorong and onto the Younghusband Peninsula, both areas of great significance to Aboriginal people and the environment movement. There is already marked pollution of the lower Murray and Coorong because of the number of boats using these waterways—from the rubbish which is thrown overboard which causes a hazard to wildlife as well as visual pollution in the water and along the shorelines.

The inevitable further consequences of the greater access provided by the bridge are of greater significance. One cannot retain the awe and inspiration of a cathedral with the tables of the money changers between the pews; nor can one retain the reverence of a cemetery with snack bars between the gravestones; nor, I would submit, can the dignity of Aboriginal people be maintained and their important land values protected if areas of such deep significance are covered with houses, artificial lakes, motels, shops, restaurants and convention centres. We will strongly and continually oppose this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on the disallowance motion moved by Senator Teague. I make a few points on behalf of the government as to why we oppose this disallowance motion. On 10 July 1994, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) moved to ensure the long-term protection of an area of particular Aboriginal significance in the vicinity of the proposed bridge to Hindmarsh Island in South Australia. The minister's declaration, issued under section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, would remain in force for a period of 25 years. The minister also acted on the basis of an independent report—and I emphasise that it was an independent report—
—He appointed her.

—prepared by Professor Cheryl Saunders, who is the Director of the Centre for Comparative Constitutional Studies at Melbourne University. I note that Senator Teague interjected, `He appointed her.' Of course the minister did, but is anyone suggesting—except for Senator Teague—that Professor Cheryl Saunders is anything but an eminent constitutional lawyer. She has a credible position in the Australian community, whether in the academic area or the wider community. To suggest that, just because she was appointed by the minister, there would be a presupposed outcome is an outrageous slur on her reputation. I trust that Senator Teague is not making that suggestion.
—I am not making that suggestion.
—That is good.
—I am criticising the minister.

—But surely the minister cannot be criticised for appointing Professor Saunders, because she is an eminent person in her own area. I am not an expert in this area, but I am told by others that it would be very hard to pick anybody better than Professor Saunders to carry out the task.

PARA.TAB: I imagine that if Mr Tickner had taken this decision without appointing someone like Professor Saunders to report to him, Senator Teague would have been in here screaming that it was a straight political act, based on no proper assessment. In that case there would have been validity to Senator Teague's criticism. But I do not think that Mr Tickner can be criticised in any way for appointing a person of such eminence as Professor Saunders to carry out this task.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a political act.
—Senator Teague is suggesting that Professor Saunders was selected to carry out a presupposed outcome. That is outrageous.
—They are your words.

—That is what Senator Teague is inferring and that is an outrageous suggestion. He would not want to make that suggestion outside this chamber because I suspect that Professor Saunders would take appropriate action. That is a slur on her credibility.
—Because he criticises the appointment?

—Senator Teague is not just criticising the appointment; he is criticising the outcome and the fact that her appointment was political. Every appointment ever made by any minister is political. That is in our nature as politicians. Clearly anybody we appoint is political. But we should not shoot the messenger because she was appointed by Mr Tickner.
—I am criticising the minister.

—If the minister did not appoint Professor Saunders, I would be interested to hear who he should have appointed to carry out this review. I cannot think of anybody better. Anyway, Senator Teague has made his point and I have disagreed with it. Professor Saunders is a very eminent person. I do not claim to be an expert on this issue, even though I am a South Australian, but I do understand—
—Secretly, you want the bridge.

—No. What I want to say very strongly is that, as I understand it, one of the benefits of Professor Saunders's appointment is that she is a woman and therefore had access to the traditions of Aboriginal women from that tribe and within that area—women who would not speak to men about this.

PARA.TAB: I am basically an agnostic leaning towards atheism—that is my general view of religion—but I respect the principle of freedom of religion. The spiritualism of Aboriginal religion has just as much validity as the formal religions such as Christianity, Buddhism, Islam and so on. We have to respect the fact that Aboriginal women's religion is different from that of men and therefore they cannot communicate with men, even Aboriginal men, about some aspects of their spirituality. But apparently they were able to communicate with Professor Saunders because she is a woman.

I therefore think that it shows some intelligent discretion on the part of the minister to appoint an eminent constitutional academic who is a woman so that she was able to get more information than a male appointed to the position. The Ngarrindjeri people have consistently maintained the importance of the area in accordance with their traditions and beliefs and have sought Mr Tickner's involvement pursuant to the act to take action to protect sites of significance to them from injury or desecration.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many are there?

—I would have thought that whether there were one, 50 or 50,000, the religious validity of these people's beliefs is just the same. Is Senator Teague suggesting that the determination of religion and spiritual belief is based purely on the number of people who hold that belief? That is putting a numbers count on whether people have a valid religious belief. That goes against the whole concept of religious freedom.
—What about the valid beliefs of the million people of South Australia?
—Their beliefs are taken into account.
—Are they?
—They have to be taken into account. But the Ngarrindjeri people living in the area have a particular religious belief based on their association with the land in that area.

PARA.TAB: Under section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, Mr Tickner had certain obligations to meet. That act was passed by this parliament. If he does not carry out the intent of the act, someone in this parliament will have a go at him for not—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we are disallowing it.

—But he is carrying out the intent of the act. Senator Teague may want to disallow it, but other people would say the intent of the act is quite clear. If Mr Tickner had not carried out the process he did and made the decision to make the declaration that the bridge could not be built for 25 years, other people may well have criticised him for abrogating his responsibility under the act.

PARA.TAB: We cannot have it both ways. We cannot choose to have an act that we want interpreted only one way when it suits our particular beliefs. I have to say that one has to be extremely cautious about any area that deals with religious beliefs and spiritual beliefs because the indissoluble right of an individual's spiritual and religious beliefs should be unimpeded by any of us. No matter what those beliefs are, once we start trying to make a value judgment that one person's religious beliefs are superior to another's, we will all end up in a pretty hairy mess in very quick time. I think Mr Tickner met his responsibility and did it in a very appropriate way. In my view and the government's view, he could not have picked a better person to carry out the review than Professor Saunders.

Mr Tickner advises that the evidence available to him and Professor Saunders's report led him to the conclusion that the area is of significance to the Ngarrindjeri people and to Aboriginal women in particular within the meaning of the act and that it was under the threat of injury or desecration. The minister advises that this was not a decision which he took lightly, nor without the most thorough examination of the evidence and consideration of his responsibilities under federal law.

Mr Tickner appreciates that the question of whether or not the construction of the bridge should proceed has unfortunately been a protracted and contentious issue within the South Australian community. Senator Teague and I would agree as South Australians that this has been a protracted controversy in the South Australian community and has been a bit like a soap opera as far as its length is concerned. As Senator Teague would know, the various forces that are lined up on this issue have been a movable feast over a period of time. It is certainly an issue of controversy, and no-one disputes that. In the end, whatever Mr Tickner's involvement and whatever he had declared or not declared, I suspect he would have been abused by people who perceived themselves to be the losers of his decision. That is the nature of this controversy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Australian government supports the bridge; that is the critical point.

—I will come back to that in a moment. As I have just said, inevitably there will be disappointment on the part of some as a result of the decision. However, I should stress that, as Professor Saunders articulates in her report:

SPEECH.PARA: These areas are important and deserve respect, preservation and sensitive management in the interests of all Australians.

We believe that is the nub of the report under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act. That is what the minister has done; he has discharged his duty. I suspect that it is an issue about which in many ways Mr Tickner would wish not to have to make decisions, if the South Australian community could have reached a consensus. But in the end it could not, a federal act applied and he carried out his duty.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague interjected a moment ago that the present liberal government of South Australia supports the building of the bridge. We ought to be a bit careful about being dogmatic on that point because this extraordinary saga of the building of the so-called Hindmarsh Island bridge has been, as I say, a bit of a movable feast with regard to people's attitudes.

I have a copy of a letter written by Ian McLachlan, the honourable member for Barker, to a Mr Gunn of Encounter Carpet Cleaning on 16 June 1994, in which he clearly indicates that he thinks that the building of a bridge is of very low priority. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you don't want to know what the Budget means—okay—but there are a lot of people who disagree with you on the Bridge and I have said on any number of occasions there are many other commercial applications where the money could have been better spent. For example:
.Berri Bridge
.Kangaroo Island hasn't even got a completed bitumen road around it.
In any case, the Labor Party were dishonest enough to sign a contract a few weeks before the election.
By the way, I didn't notice you at a meeting called before the South Australian election about the Bridge, at which I said what I said above and hardly anyone supported the Bridge.

Mr McLachlan made it pretty clear—and he is a frontbencher, a shadow minister in the opposition—that he is opposed to the bridge. He thinks it is of very low priority and that something else should be done with the money. That is what his letter of June 1994 says. The Southern Times Messenger newspaper of 28 April 1993, which covers the electorate, contained an article under the heading `Fleurieu News'. The article states:
Goolwa residents urgently need a new primary school instead of a $6.4 million bridge to Hindmarsh Island, says Alexandra MP and Opposition leader Dean Brown.

PARA.TAB: "It is unacceptable for the Labor Government to build a $6.4 million bridge at Goolwa when there are 335 children in totally unacceptable school accommodation," he said.
"The Government bought land for a new school over three years ago but has failed to commit funds to start work."

SPEECH.PARA: We have there a pretty clear indication by Dean Brown in the middle of last year, when he was Leader of the Opposition, that he opposed the bridge or gave it an extremely low priority.

PARA.TAB: On 12 September 1993 he again spelt out in a local paper the lack of priorities of the then government in wanting to spend $6.4 million on the Hindmarsh Bridge. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser on 9 October 1993 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition Leader, Mr Dean Brown, said if the Liberals won government all contracts regarding the bridge would be examined.

So he made it pretty clear that if he could think of a way to get out of building the bridge he would. That was a pretty clear attitude. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 10 June last year states:

PARA.TAB: Mr Quigley said yesterday the Liberal Party and "a small group of friends with vested interests" were using the bridge issue as a political football.

SPEECH.PARA: It states further:
. . . people such as Mr Brown who were cynically "playing politics".
It also states:
. . . Opposition distorted information, which the Liberals were exploiting for purely political gain, Mr Quigley said.

Finally, the South Australian Country Magazine of July this year, an insert of which goes into country newspapers, contained an interview with the opposition leader of the federal coalition, Mr Downer. The article states:

PARA.TAB: Despite strong business support for the bridge in Goolwa—formerly part of his electorate—he describes the bridge as a "bridge to nowhere". I'm sure it will be convenient to have the bridge but at what price?" he says.
It seems to me an enormously expensive project for the benefits the community will get from it.
The decision was made by the Bannon Government . . . the Labor Party has locked South Australian taxpayers into building a bridge to nowhere."

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last 18 months we have had the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, the Leader of the Opposition federally, and the now shadow minister for the environment in the federal coalition all opposing the bridge on the basis that it was a waste of money or `a bridge to nowhere', as Mr Downer described it. It is very strange that Senator Teague should move a motion to disallow the declaration to stop the bridge being built when his own leader, to say the least, is utterly unenthusiastic about it, his leader in South Australia when he was Leader of the Opposition was unenthusiastic about it and opposed it, and his own shadow minister for the environment clearly does not believe in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of those you quoted support this disallowance.

—It is not unusual to do double somersaults with back twist and pike in the opposition these days, but this is a pretty astonishing back somersault in position. What is the real reason now for the back somersault with twist and pike? It is that this issue is about states rights. The old hoary chestnut has been pulled out of the fire—states rights. When coalition members cannot agree on anything and cannot get a unified position, the one thing they will agree on is the lowest common denominator: states rights. That is what Dean Brown said openly when Mr Tickner made the decision. He was not interested any more in the economic decision, the Aboriginal heritage issue or the development issue. He said, `This is outrageous that this is a federal government intervening in South Australia on a states rights issue. This is a states rights matter; leave this to South Australia.'
—He was right, too.

—We had left it for five years to South Australia, but it could not make a decision. Senator Campbell is dead right; we left it to South Australia. The community in South Australia and the politicians, both Labor and Liberal, could not make a decision that could stick, one the community could agree with. We stood out of it for five years and Labor and Liberal blued and argued and the community blued and argued. The unions got involved. One union was in favour and one was against. The community was split for and against, there were demonstrations and so on.

PARA.TAB: So those opposite cannot tell me that we intervened capriciously. This argument has been going on for four or five years and, for a long period when they were in opposition, they opposed the building of the bridge. Now they are in favour of building the bridge, but not for economic, Aboriginal heritage, tourism or convenience reasons. They support the bridge now for only one reason: states rights. I have to say that it is a rotten foundation to build anything on—the basis of states rights and nothing else.

TALK.START.PARA: —You caricature it.

—I am surprised at Senator Teague. He is described as a very small `m' moderate and small `l' liberal in the coalition. Moderates in the Liberal Party usually make a concession towards a national approach in Australia. I am surprised that he has fallen for the pea and thimble trick, lining up with the conservatives in the coalition on the issue of states rights. I do not know whether this has anything to do with factional politics in the Liberal Party in South Australia or here, or whatever else; but it is a bizarre position for those opposite to take. Only on states rights grounds do they want to build the bridge; not on any of the other criteria.
—You caricature me.

—It is absolutely inexplicable. I have quoted the Liberal leaders, state and federal, and the shadow minister who was formerly looking after the Hindmarsh Island area that used to be in the Barker electorate—now it is back in the Barker electorate.
—I have given full reasons.

—Senator Teague says there is a comprehensive and rational view about this—but there is none. Those opposite are all over the place, twisting around. The only thing they can all agree on is the old hoary chestnut of states rights. I have to say to Senator Teague that I am surprised at him. I am not surprised at Senator Campbell, who is from the seventeenth century on states rights. He is where the colonies were in about 1836 on states rights. I am not surprised at Senator Campbell; I am a little surprised at Senator Teague. I do not know who put this to him. I do not know who broke his arm or twisted it, or kicked—
—I did.
—There must be some other motive, because it is to us—
—Justice! Justice!

—It has nothing to do with justice. It may have more to do with future Liberal Party internal politics. As I say, it does Senator Teague no justice at all, when one considers the positions he has quite courageously taken at times within his own party, for him now to be here as a stooge for the Senator Campbells and those mad states righters, those mad right wingers and so on. I find it inexplicable that Senator Teague is doing this.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I will conclude by making this point. After this debate had been going on for four or five years in South Australia, with no satisfactory resolution—and this had been a major political issue on which people were contradicting each other and changing positions—Mr Tickner was requested, as he was required to do under the act that this parliament has carried and that he is responsible for, to carry out his duty and appointed a very appropriate person to do an independent survey, an independent investigation, of all the facts. The person whom the minister appointed and whose integrity one cannot impeach made a report, carried out the purpose of the act and made a decision that is supported by this government.

According to the perceptions of Senator Campbell, others and now Senator Teague, it is very unfortunate that the decision overrides states rights, but so be it. The sooner this country moves away from the dead hand of the ideology of states rights, the sooner this country will do a lot better. I know Senator Teague believes in that. I cannot help Senator Campbell or the others who want a different sort of Australia, an Australia that is inefficiently managed and governed based on stupidities and differences that really should not exist between all Australians, wherever we live.

Mr Tickner made this decision in accordance with the national legislation. I am glad he did because it upholds the view that we are all one country and are not bedevilled and split over the stupidity of states rights—an outdated ideology that holds Australia back from its proper economic and social development. We urge the Senate to reject Senator Teague's disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is about much more than just building a bridge. This is about a question of process and a question of power exercised by a federal minister. It is a question I thought the government party would have been most interested in, as process is one of the tenets that it holds dear. The question here is whether the disallowance made by the minister in relation to the building of this bridge to Hindmarsh Island is indeed a proper declaration. The motion proposes that it is not and that it should be disallowed.

PARA.TAB: This matter has ramifications for the whole of Australia. Recently in Western Australia the minister made a similar declaration in relation to the extension of the Broome crocodile farm. Senators might not think there is much relationship between a crocodile farm and a bridge, but the common denominator is the action that was taken by the minister, and it is that action which is the cause for concern.
