On 12 May this year Minister Tickner issued a stop order on the continued construction of a bridge to Hindmarsh Island in South Australia. As such, the bridge had been approved by a state Labor government and, what is more, was approved by a Liberal state government. The company concerned was put into receivership as a result of that stop order by the minister.

This situation is akin to a citizen gaining consent from a local council to build extensions to his house and then entering into a contract with a builder to carry out that work. Whilst those extensions are under way or half way through, it is tantamount to the council saying, `You've got to stop.' Where does that leave the citizen? The citizen is left financially disadvantaged, and in such a case one has a complete lack of process.

In a moment I will refer to the history of this matter, but I will not deal with the personalities and individual philosophies of people whom Senator Schacht mentioned. I bow to the local knowledge of Senator Teague, who has outlined the local issues so well.

We must look at the history of this matter. This matter goes back to 1977, because it was in 1977 that the company concerned purchased land on the western portion of Hindmarsh Island. From then on, planning took place. A marina was planned. Submissions were put to the state planning authority. In 1983, work commenced on the site. In 1987, pressure was applied for the construction of a bridge. At that stage there was a ferry service in operation which I understand cost in the region of $400,000 a year. In 1988, a further global plan was produced, with the undertaking by the state government that a bridge could be built.

There were two Aboriginal anthropological studies carried out, by a Ms Edwards and a Mr Lucas. They were carried out in 1989 and 1990. There was also an environmental impact study placed on display. It was advertised; and that was completed the following year. So in 1991 most of the hurdles had been negotiated and the contract for the building of the bridge was let.In fact, as I understand it, the government indicated that the bridge would be built by 1993. In December 1993 a Liberal government was elected and while it sought advice on the matter construction was stalled but it recommenced after an independent opinion was provided by Mr Jacobs QC.

What this indicates is that from 1977 to 1993 this developer had gone through all the process demanded of the developer—environmental impact statements, Aboriginal anthropological studies, town planning approval, all the usual things that we would expect. So we had the bridge under construction and then bang—the guillotine fell on 12 May 1994 when Minister Tickner issued a 30-day stop order without any consultation, without reports, and he then ordered an independent inquiry.

I might say that this matter is before the Federal Court in South Australia where it is alleged that Minister Tickner drafted the order to suspend work for 25 years before he had even obtained the independent report. That is a question of process which is of grave concern. It is not a question of states rights in relation to that aspect; it is a question of whether the minister used his powers properly. These powers are comprehensive ones—powers which can stop construction midway; powers which can send a company into receivership. No doubt the Federal Court will examine that matter in due course and come to a determination. I might add that Minister Tickner's decision to halt the development of the Broome crocodile farm under similar circumstances is also under review by the Federal Court in Western Australia. I await with great interest the result of those judgments in relation to the exercise of the minister's powers.

The question of states rights was raised by Senator Schacht. It is an inherent aspect of this Federation that the state governments have control over certain areas of good and proper government for the citizens of the states. There is no question, I put to the Senate, that the states should not govern things like law and order, main roads, the distribution of power and the general day-to-day things that affect the citizens of this country. Similarly, in this case, the state government of the day had allowed progress on this development and these various plans were approved. The developer had gone through all the usual channels.

At the eleventh hour we find a federal minister riding roughshod over the due process and interfering. I put it to the Senate that this power contained in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 is a power which has to be used with great care and great caution. During the process of approval for this bridge none of the Aboriginal concerns were raised; they were only raised in the last 12 months. Remember I said that this went back to 1977.

It is the case for the complainants in the action against the minister that the minister failed to give them the opportunity to respond to a secret anthropological report on Aboriginal women's issues that have been mentioned; that Professor Saunders refused to meet with two Aboriginal women who denied claims being made by other women about the spirituality of Hindmarsh Island; that Mr Tickner failed to appoint a mediator to resolve the row despite a formal request from the developers' lawyers; and that Aboriginal women refused to meet with an anthropologist engaged by the developers and refused to provide details of their claims against the bridge. These are most serious concerns. They are before the Federal Court, and I will not comment further other than to place them on record.

These concerns were raised at the last minute after people had committed their funding. Those people have been caught short and, as a result, they have suffered a most severe disability in the form of going into receivership. Men and women of Australia need to know that there is certainty when they undertake commercial enterprises. That, I can tell Senator Schacht, is not a question of states rights; it is a question of basic citizens rights which one would expect from the government of the day. We do not expect to go through all the usual processes, have them approved, be halfway through construction, and then be stopped by a 30-day order without any recourse whatsoever. The process which has been engaged in is highly suspect; so much so that it has to be taken to the Federal Court.

I notice that John McHughes, who is a long time Goolwa resident and a Ngarrindjeri descendant, said that he had moved into the area in 1946 and he had never heard anything about any areas of Aboriginal significance in the vicinity of the proposed bridge. This highlights the uncertainty of the situation. Despite that, the minister went ahead and acted. The consequences of his actions were draconian. One could not get an injunction in a court without having substantial reasons for the injunction. The reason why courts grant injunctions sparingly is that injunctions have the effect of tying up people and money and therefore possibly causing a great deal of financial loss which can be devastating. Just as individuals in their daily lives do not want to be thwarted in their endeavours—especially when they have had approval to proceed—people in the commercial sector do not want to face a similar uncertainty.

Senator Coulter mentioned the question of property speculation. Any commercial endeavour has an aspect of speculation about it. We live in a free enterprise society. If one of our neighbours down the street has a garage sale, there is an element of speculation about that; there is an endeavour to sell something and get money in return. Men and women in Australia frequently buy houses which have been the subject of development. Daily, we find builders and developers opening up areas for new residences. That is an endeavour which is in the best interests of this country. Should we halt all commercial speculation tomorrow? Should we halt all development tomorrow?

If we do not have development of that sort, we will not be able to offer young couples setting out to buy a house any hope at all. This is all about offering some sort of certainty to people when they embark on these sorts of ventures. The law does not disregard individuals who have concerns or cultural groups in that regard; that is why we have environmental impact statements, town planning proposals and even anthropological studies, which were carried out. But where was the objection in the 1980s? We have had it only in the last year. It was only when ATSIC had been advised that some sort of objection on cultural grounds could succeed that we had these aspects or concerns being raised.

Let us assume that these concerns are genuine. The fact still remains that they were not raised earlier, and that is the aspect of most concern. There is a principle of equity that, if people sit on their rights, they lose them. If people's rights are being infringed and those people take no action in relation to that, one can only assume that they are acquiescing or waiving their rights or any exercise on their part to take action to enforce those rights. That is an aspect which is of crucial importance here.

In relation to Western Australia, we view this with great concern because it is federal interference with the due process of something which is squarely within the jurisdiction of the states. It is not a question of asserting states rights; it is a question of making the federation work. The federal government is very keen on looking at a republic. If the government approaches this issue with the attitude of `to hell with states rights', then it will never reach any form of consensus as to what form this country will take in the next century.

Australia is a very large country and over that huge geographical area there are different interests and requirements for its various citizens. If the federal government, which sits here isolated in Canberra, does not take that into account, it can forget any question of reaching consensus as to where this country will be going in the next century. If its ministers are to exercise such comprehensive powers without due regard to the process of law, then it will fragment society. It will cause division in society. This approach will not lead to the consensus which we would all hope for because the federal executive arm of government in this country has shown over recent years a contempt not only for the proper process of parliament but also for the regional aspects concerning the people of Australia. That is what the government is faced with here.

I am not saying that this is a question so much of states rights; it is a question of state responsibilities. These are areas where the state governments have responsibilities to govern for the people of the states, and this is an area where a federal minister has intruded without any basis for such intrusion. I believe that the Hindmarsh Island bridge and the Broome crocodile farm in Western Australia, albeit quite discrete, quite separate, stand for a principle which is of universal application in this country: an arbitrary executive decision by a minister riding roughshod over the due process of law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The points that both Senator Ellison and Senator Teague have made in this debate are vital to the future development of Australia and the future protection of Aboriginal heritage and culture. I want to make a few remarks about the disallowance motion moved by my colleague Senator Teague.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht questioned Senator Teague's motives for moving his motion. Senator Schacht refuses to understand that even though the flawed legislation, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait (Islander Heritage Protection) Act, gives the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) the power to do what he has done, it also clearly vests in this parliament the power to do what Senator Teague is seeking to do today. So, as representatives of the states—and Senator Teague is a representative of South Australia—we are exercising a power to disallow. It would seem from the indications of my colleagues from the Australian Democrats and the Greens that the parliament, in its wisdom, will decide not to disallow the declaration in relation to Hindmarsh Island. However, Senator Teague has the right to do what he has done.

If I may seek to enter Senator Teague's mind, I believe that he and I would share the same view about Australia and how one protects individual rights and freedoms in Australia—that one of the worst ways of seeking to protect individual rights and freedoms is to have decisions about people's lives made some 3,000 miles away in Canberra by ministers who have no political link with a particular area. It will not matter what Minister Tickner does to the people of South Australia or the people of Goolwa because his political life will never be affected by those decisions. Yet the decisions of people like Dean Brown, the Premier of South Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dean Brown opposed the bridge when he was leader of the opposition.

—I will get to that. I know it is very hard for the minister to comprehend these ideas—it is very hard for him to comprehend anything because his mouth is open all the time; it is very hard for his brain to get into gear. Premier Lynn Arnold and Premier Dean Brown had their political fortunes affected by these decisions. Michael Armitage and all of the politicians in South Australia have a political stake. Senator Schacht would tell the Senate that the South Australian community could not come to an agreement; that there was no unanimity; that no-one cheered when Lynn Arnold gave the contract; that no-one said, `This is fantastic. We have unanimous support for the building of this bridge.' I do not think one could obtain unanimous support for the building of a bridge anywhere in the world. I do not think anyone could say, `This is a great thing—every single person in this community wants this bridge.' There is probably a ferry operator somewhere who would not want a bridge. That would apply even to the Friendship bridge that we built in Laos.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague and I probably do come from slightly different strands of Liberal thinking but we would very much share the view that one needs to protect individual rights within our democracy and within our federation. We share one thing very solidly, as all Liberals do, and that is the belief that the best way of ensuring that individual rights and freedoms are protected within a democracy is to make sure that decisions that affect people's lives are made very close to them.

This great federation of Australia has been undermined by Senator Schacht's party and by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, over their 10 or 11 years in power. They do not like this federation. They have always argued that there should be one government and that should be in Canberra, and that there should be subservient regional governments and no state governments. It is part of their political philosophy. It is part of Senator Schacht's philosophy. He does not want state governments; he wants to abolish the states. He also wants to abolish the Senate. They would like to have a unitary government here in Canberra making decisions and some throwaway, hand-me-down type powers given to subservient regional governments which would be virtually totally reliant on Canberra for funding.
They would like even the head of state appointed by their unitary government in

SPEECH.PARA: Canberra. They would like to appoint the head of state. They would not dare contemplate allowing the people of Australia, in the circumstance that Australians decided to move to a republic, to actually elect that head of state. They would not dare give people that amount of power; they would want to preserve that for themselves. They want a unitary system. They want one house of parliament, the House of Representatives, and, of course, no state governments.

PARA.TAB: This is a crucial issue in this decision. What we are looking at here is not the building of a bridge and whether Mr McLachlan or Mr Brown liked the bridge; we are looking at how we run a country. How do we run Australia? In the case of the Broome crocodile farm and in the case of the Hindmarsh Island bridge, we have earnest, honest people seeking to go about developing this nation. They went through all the processes that Senator Ellison has so eloquently described—the environmental processes, the ethnographic surveys, the Aboriginal heritage processes and the local museums. Finally, in the case of Hindmarsh Island, they got approval, even with all of the surrounding political controversy—the Labor Party wanting to build the bridge and the Liberal Party opposing it. They get the thing under way and at the last minute the government from Canberra comes in and decides to stop the construction of the bridge.

That is what we are talking about. It is not states rights or anything else. It is simply: is that the right way to run a country? Will we have a sustainable nation? Will we have a sustainable federation if we have this extremely wasteful duplication of process and the uncertainty that would surround that process? If Senator Schacht earnestly believes that the federal government is the best government to make decisions about these land development matters, then the government should go to the Australian people and put to them a referendum question seeking their approval to hand over the power of land management to the federal government. If that were the case, it would become an efficient process.

It would be very hard for people from South Australia, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland to come here to get their approvals, but it would be a far more efficient process than what we have at the moment. At the moment, people who want to develop anything in Australia have to go through all of the local and state processes and then cross their fingers and hope against hope that the federal government does not intervene at the last moment. So we now have this enormous risk, which is increasing every single year because of the activities of this Labor government, that development processes at the local and state levels can be overridden at the last moment.

If we want an efficiently run nation, if we want an efficient federation, we should have a land management process that is controlled by one level of government. We in the opposition would, of course, argue that it is most appropriate that that be done close to the ground, close to where the action is taking place, so that there are political imperatives acting upon that local level of state government and the local authorities to ensure that decisions are, indeed, in touch with the community. That would be our argument.

Senator Schacht and Mr Keating would prefer to see all of that abolished. As with their native title legislation, they would like to see control over land management shifted to the federal arena. I put it to Senator Schacht that, if he had the guts to put up a referendum that these issues should be referred to the federal government, we would be happy to meet him around Australia and debate him at public forums to say that we oppose that power moving to Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —See what the people think.

—Exactly. We should give the people a say on whether they want this power shifted to Canberra. Of course, the Labor Party will not do that. The Labor Party will not ask the people. The Labor Party will get around the requirements of the constitution; it will bring in pieces of legislation like this and undermine the power of the states and the power of local decision making surreptitiously. It will never dare ask the Australian people because it knows that virtually every time it has asked them in a referendum proposal during the past 90 years of federation the Australian people have overwhelmingly said no.

PARA.TAB: That is really what the coalition is saying today. We are saying that in a federation we must have a sense of subsidiarity. We must ensure that the decisions made at the local level are given full faith. We cannot have a federation working if, all the time, the federal government is going to second-guess what the states are going to do. We must be able to give full faith to those decision making processes or we have to go to the states and say, `Sorry, you're making a hash of Aboriginal heritage issues. We're going to take it right over' and then have a fight about that. If we are going to have Aboriginal heritage matters at the state level and at the federal level we need to work out how it is going to work.

In the case of the Broome crocodile farm which I have a close interest in, and now the Hindmarsh Island bridge, that has not happened. It is a system that will, in the long run, do much to undermine people's faith in Aboriginal heritage and culture and the processes we go about in resolving the conflicts that occur between development and the sensible protection of that. If we do not get this worked out it will undermine not only the certainty that developers have in the processes but also community support for the protection of Aboriginal heritage and culture.

That would be a very sad thing for Australia because virtually all Australians are very proud and have an increasing awareness of Aboriginal heritage and culture. That is something that has emerged over the last few years. It has been promoted more; it has even been commercially exploited. It is probably a slightly crass example, but we recently saw the painting of a Qantas jet by an Adelaide artist, whose name escapes me—

TALK.START.PARA: —John Moriarty's people.

—Yes, John Moriarty's company. That is probably not the warmest and cuddliest example of Aboriginal heritage but it is a monument to the increasing understanding of Aboriginal heritage, art and culture among the broader community. It is probably one of the better examples of the reconciliation that is occurring between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

PARA.TAB: What seriously concerns me is that when we have these jurisdictional battles between state and federal government, the community's appreciation of these matters is being undermined. That is something that no-one in this place would like to see happen. There have been two very bad examples in my time in parliament—the Broome crocodile farm and the Hindmarsh Island declaration—where the whole process has been a disgrace. That needs to be changed.

Professor Saunders said in her report that there are a number of issues in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act that require review and possibly amendment. She looked particularly at the giving of evidence and the secrecy provisions. They are not matters on which I have focused. However, in the light of the Broome crocodile farm example, I have focused some of my attention on the matter of compensation payable when these declarations apply.

When I was in the United States a couple of months ago there was a debate raging in the Congress about a similar issue. The US federal government had issued a wetlands protection order on some land in Louisiana. The issues involved were similar to those that we are facing. In the US case, the federal government had issued an order to protect the heritage and environmental values of the wetlands while in our case the federal government is issuing a heritage protection order to preserve indigenous culture and heritage.

The bill that is going through the Congress—I am not sure whether it has been successful—is designed to ensure that in those cases where the federal government intervenes and effectively takes away people's property rights, those people have a legislated right to proper compensation. The compensation provisions in the Australian heritage protection act provide no fundamental right to compensation. There are clauses that consider the issue of compensation but effectively the compensation is left to the discretion of the minister. If the person appealing for compensation is not satisfied, he or she has the right to go to the Federal Court. What concerns me is that in virtually all other areas of the acquisition of land and property by government there are strict provisions for the calculation of that compensation. In the case of the acquisition of freehold title, compensation is determined very much by the value of the land. There is an enormous amount of common law covering these acquisition issues.

I have drafted a private senator's bill to address these issues, but it may need to incorporate some of the matters that Professor Saunders has raised. It is designed to ensure that, as compensation arises in matters such as the Broome crocodile farm and Hindmarsh Island, there are quite clear guidelines, prepared by senior and independent valuers and incorporated in regulations. That way, people who have these sorts of orders put on their land and have the value of their land diminished—in fact, have many of their property rights compulsorily acquired—should have no doubt whatsoever as to the guidelines relating to that compensation.

In the case of the Broome crocodile farm, where Mr Douglas can do nothing with his land for something like 25 years, effectively, in any reasonable man's consideration, we would have to say that that equates to a resumption of the freehold or a resumption of the leasehold of that land. If one is not allowed to do anything on the land for 25 years, effectively the value of the land is nil or negligible and, in those circumstances, the Commonwealth would certainly have to be required to pay the full value of the land.

I foreshadow that, once I have gone through the normal party processes, I will be bringing forward a private senators bill to seek to amend this bill. Certainly Professor Cheryl Saunders has raised some other potential amendments, and I hope that the Senate will constructively consider what I think are amendments that could improve this act, which is certainly causing concern in a range of areas right across Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am a South Australian senator and I support this South Australian project, the development and building of a bridge across the River Murray to Hindmarsh Island. That is why, on behalf of the opposition, I have moved a motion for the disallowance of the declaration of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, that that bridge be banned for 25 years. He has banned it without an explanation, and we are holding him and the government to account. The declaration is without foundation. It should not stand. The bridge should be built.

PARA.TAB: The South Australian government, a liberal government elected last December, supports the building of the bridge and wishes to see this declaration by the federal minister disallowed. The former Labor government—that is, the government in power before last December—entered into a full contract to build the bridge. The Labor government in South Australia wanted the bridge built; its successor, the current Liberal government, wants the bridge built.

The Liberal and National parties in this parliament in Canberra want the bridge built. It happens that my colleagues the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Downer, the shadow minister for the environment, Mr McLachlan, and the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mrs Gallus, are all South Australians, as I am. We all want this declaration by Minister Tickner disallowed.

Six senators have contributed to this debate. I listened carefully to all of the speeches, except for five minutes at the beginning of Senator Chamarette's contribution which I missed. I am disappointed by the contribution made by the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the Labor government. Not one of those senators has gone to the nub of the explanation that was proffered in a very flimsy way by a person I do respect, Professor Saunders.

I do not criticise Professor Saunders; I criticise the minister who appointed her with such haste and with a deadline of weeks—she had three and a half weeks to report on a complex matter—and I do not believe Professor Saunders's report is in any way convincing. I can respect a person and still be unconvinced by the argument or conclusion that that person might put to me. I will be honest enough to say that I am not convinced by the bottom line on this matter of this highly respectable academic, this constitutional lawyer, Professor Cheryl Saunders.

I spent a great deal of my original speech yesterday when introducing this matter getting to the nub of Professor Saunders's reasons for recommending that the bridge be not built. I included page 42 of her report in full. I do not wish to go over it at any great length, but not one of the senators who spoke against my motion referred to this crucial element. The only references that were made by Senator Coulter or Senator Chamarette to Aboriginal sites of significance related to burial areas, bones and human remains, but this was not sufficient to move the minister to make this declaration.

There are about 1,000 sites in the lower Murray area, including all of Goolwa and most areas of the Hindmarsh Island, in which there are burial sites and human remains. There are also about 1,000 middens spread out over the area. In his briefings to Aboriginal people last December and again in April the minister, Mr Tickner, said, `That is not a convincing argument for me to intervene and to make a declaration that the bridge be not built; you must come back with wider, more convincing arguments.'

I will spell this out more explicitly with material that I did not use yesterday. In December 1993 a delegation of the Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee, led by Douglas Milerar and George Trevorrow, saw Minister Tickner here in Canberra. They spoke about Aboriginal sites, burial grounds and middens. They did not refer at all last December to the issue that moved Professor Saunders; the issue that Minister Tickner has referred to as being the reason for his declaration, and that is the women's issues—what is in the secret envelopes that he cannot read.

What happened between December and when the women's issue arose in June this year? I will tell the Senate what happened. The asking of Mr Tickner to use special Commonwealth laws to delay or stop the bridge because it threatened sites of archaeological significance was not sufficient. The legislation had not been used to protect the site `primarily of archaeological significance'. ATSIC said that Mr Tickner would be greatly influenced by evidence of the cultural significance of the sites affected by the bridge.

People went away and tried to do some homework again on this. Senator Coulter is right when he said that a coalition developed between those with Aboriginal concerns and those with environmental concerns. I acknowledge that. In fact, the trade unions were involved as well and they were crucially important in the articulation and the publication of newsletters and so on on behalf of that coalition.

I understand their position. They were a minority. They have an extreme environmentalist concern that says, `Hey, the former Labor government in South Australia wanted the bridge built; the current newly elected Liberal government wants the bridge built. How can we stop this? What sort of rearguard action can we take to stop the bridge?' They try the environmental argument. The environmental argument does not wash. It does not actually affect the outcome. Then, along with the advice that the Aboriginal committee gained in December and more subsequently in April from ATSIC, they said, `Hey, we have got to play the Aboriginal card. We have to find something of cultural significance in the lower Murray that will be able to be used by Minister Tickner to gain the real prize which is the environmentalist arguments in that coalition.'

I used the word `contrived' yesterday. I do not use the word `contrived' of Professor Saunders or of Mrs Kartinyeri, the spokesman of the Ngarrindjeri women—and I still do not know whether there are five, 15, or only one or two Ngarrindjeri women. No-one has answered that question in this debate. I do not question Mrs Kartinyeri's evidence. I just say that she was the spokesperson for these Aboriginal women from April, May, or June—the critical period this year—when a new argument had to be found. She lives on Yorke Peninsula. There are no Ngarrindjeri women who live in the lower Murray any more. She had to develop a culturally significant argument that would allow Minister Tickner some new card—environmental, Aboriginal, left-wing Labor, political or whatever the motivation, or whatever things were guiding the minister's decision.

Mrs Kartinyeri, as I said yesterday, at that point said, `I, personally, did not know the areas of significance in the lower River Murray.' She said that in a letter to Mr Tickner. That is why I used the word `contrived'. Words were put in her mouth about the women's issue: the lower Murray waters around islands, with bends and around the Murray mouth, being an analogy with a woman's reproductive system.

I can imagine how women last century and the century before in their dreaming and in their sense of stewardship of sites in the whole of this region could have a spiritually important sense of stewardship for the lower Murray in these terms. But Mrs Kartinyeri did not know what were the sites of significance. She `recently' discovered them, in the context of the coalition that Senator Coulter has referred to—environmentalists, Aboriginal activists and trade unionists—as a minority against the wishes of the majority of residents of Goolwa and the lower Murray area, and against the wishes of the people living on Hindmarsh Island, to be a part of this rearguard action to try to stop the bridge.

When the argument was eventually put to Professor Saunders, no-one was able to articulate the spiritual beliefs of the women—and we are not told how many there are. I will concede, with Senator Schacht, that maybe there is only one. If there is a spiritual belief of one Australian, a Ngarrindjeri woman, I want to respect that person's beliefs; I fully respect the spiritual beliefs of every Australian. But we must ask questions as to the relationship of those spiritual beliefs to any assertions as to what should happen in public policy.

Senator Collins is in the chamber. I bring to his attention a debate that occurred in cabinet about a mining development in the Northern Territory in which Senator Collins disagreed with former Prime Minister Bob Hawke with regard to the credibility of certain Aboriginal claims that were being used by the then Prime Minister as a reason for not going ahead with the development in the Northern Territory. The then Prime Minister was in a minority in that discussion, and yet, because he was Prime Minister, he won the day. That was one of the telling indicators that Mr Hawke was on the skids as Prime Minister: he did not have credibility in his argument.

I make the same assessment with regard to Mr Tickner's response to the Saunders report on this issue. There was such a bias, such a predisposition, on the minister's part, whether for environmental reasons, whether for left-wing Labor political reasons, whether out of competition with the Democrats and the Greens for a minority vote—I do not know what the reasons were. To then gain a contrived argument about women's issues, an Aboriginal sacred site is used to stop a development that will cause $175 million worth of loss to South Australia, and to this region in particular, and 1,200 new jobs to be lost.

Those figures were acknowledged by Senator Chamarette and by Senator Coulter. They said, `We understand those figures, but the sacred site is more important.' I think Senator Coulter would say that the birds are more important. I share Senator Coulter's concerns for the natural environment. I am not as outspoken as he is with regard to whether we have any human development near areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —Massive human development.

—Senator Coulter says, `Massive human development.' He talks about a Gold Coast on Hindmarsh Island. I will come to that in a moment. I make the point that the minister has intervened on a matter that was recently heard. I say it was contrived by politicians, using one or two Aboriginal people, to get a hook to hang a declaration on that would stop the bridge.

PARA.TAB: I get to the nub of the issue again: it is not about archaeological sites; it is not about burial grounds; it is not about middens; it is about women's issues. It is what is in the secret envelopes that cannot be read by a man. That is what public policy is being built upon. The people of my state reject it. They laugh at it. They are not convinced. They are ordinary, decent, hardworking South Australians and they need a voice. They need justice.

Senator Schacht said he was surprised that Senator Teague was speaking up for his state—the same state that Senator Schacht represents, by the way. I say that I am speaking up for justice—justice for ordinary Australians, justice for all Australians.

The link between the spiritual beliefs—and I respect the spiritual beliefs—and the building of a bridge is put in these terms by Dr Fergie. She said to Professor Saunders—I am referring to page 42 of the Saunders report—that none of the women could articulate what the connection was between their spiritual beliefs and the bridge. This is the witness on their behalf saying it—an anthropologist appointed by the Aboriginal legal rights movement. Then she said, `I surmise, I think, that the issue is that the bridge will go above the water'—the word `above' is underlined—`and not through the water. Because it goes above the water, it is not mediated by water. Consequently, it would make the system sterile.'

We are supposed to be rational. Is anybody convinced by that? Let them put up their hand. Let them indicate now that they are convinced by this logic. I respect the spiritual beliefs but, when it is a matter of public policy, there must be a clear explanation of the relationship between any individual's freedom to have a spiritual belief and how that will lead to public policy.

I can only say to Democrat senators, Green senators and Labor senators: when the little boy stands up in a little while and says, `The king has no clothes on', will they be among the group that says, `We knew the king did not have any clothes on but, out of political correctness, we had to say that he had on the finest clothes in the land'?
I put it to honourable senators that there is no explanation. In my submission to Professor Saunders on 11 June, in the second major point I made to her, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as a consequence of Ministerial intervention under this Act, the Minister must publish a clear explanation of the specific heritage matters that are in need of protection. This explanation should be given both in terms of the reasons for the declaration under section 9 being made (that is, the nature of the appeals or the alleged heritage matters to be protected) and then, later, in terms of the confirmed findings of any inquiries made as a result of the Minister's intervention. In particular, I respect the fact that some aboriginal heritage matters are secret to the specific guardians of that heritage.

After all, for six years I was a member of the council of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and did all I could in those six years to further the Aboriginal heritage of this country. My submission continued:

However, it would be a failure of Ministerial accountability if such secrecy denied an appropriate and substantial explanation by the Minister of the matters involved. Appropriate, intelligible summaries (which avoid the specific secret words) would still need to be given by the Minister.

That was my submission to Professor Saunders. Professor Saunders has not given that intelligible explanation and Minister Tickner has not given that intelligible explanation. I call upon all senators to reject the intervention because it is not good enough for ministers to act without reason.

PARA.TAB: I refer very briefly to some of the other matters raised in this debate. Senator Chamarette did not give an explanation of the nub of this issue; she only referred to the sacred burial sites. She is out of date. She is talking about conversations she had when she visited earlier this year, before the ATSIC advice to the minister that that was insufficient for the minister to act. She did not refer to the women's issues at all. She quoted the environmentalists, particularly Mr Shearman, as welcoming the ban because she is really wanting an environmental and Aboriginal outcome, as do Senator Coulter and the Democrats. There is a competition between these two minority parties to get the vote of the environmentalists and the Aboriginal communities which they believe can be won by one or other minority party.

Senator Coulter, making an extravagant analogy, talked about reverence. I say to Senator Coulter that there is no monopoly on reverence. I have a great sense of the beauty and a reverence for the experience when I go to that part of God's creation which I see in the Coorong National Park in the lower Murray region. I agree with him about having reverence. But to make extravagant analogies about money changers in the cathedral or snack bars between the graves, is, of course, just rhetoric relating to his particular assessment and his opposition.

I accept that Senator Coulter is opposed to development. He has said, in an exaggerated way, that this development will be a mini-Gold Coast. He said, `As an Australian Democrat, I am opposed to development. I am opposed to anything that the mayor has outlined as being forward planned for development in Hindmarsh Island.'

I make the point to Senator Coulter that the mayor and the council of Goolwa, who have responsibility for Hindmarsh Island, fully support the bridge being built. They have written in those terms to every senator.

I have already addressed most of the matters raised by Senator Schacht. He spoke about the moving feasts of various political opinions about this bridge in recent months. I can only affirm my earlier response: the former Labor government authorised the bridge. A contract was let and a start was made on building the bridge two months before the state election last year. It was stopped by the rearguard action of demonstrators. Subsequently it was laid over until after the election, and it was again started—this time by the Liberal state government—in May of this year; and then it was stopped by Minister Tickner's preliminary one-month ban, which was then confirmed as a 25-year ban.

I am not moved by Senator Schacht's references to various opinions that people have held in the past. I am moved by the stated views of the politicians to whom he has referred, all of whom support the disallowance of this declaration.

Finally, I wish to refer to my colleagues Senator Ellison and Senator Campbell, both Liberal senators from Western Australia, who have consistently supported my arguments with regard to the wrongness of the federal minister's intervention in the matter of the Hindmarsh Island bridge. I welcome all that they have said and I thank them for their support. I particularly draw attention to Senator Ellison's legal references to the important issue of process and how it must be conceded in the Senate that we are to act upon the basis of law; that we are to give certainty to any developer on the basis that a legally approved project means what it says; and that there ought not to be eleventh hour stoppages to developments that Australian citizens are going about in the normal course of their lives on the basis of legal approvals.

In my speech yesterday I referred in detail to the approvals that have been given for this bridge, which has now been stopped only because of the federal minister's intervention. Let me make it quite clear to the Senate: if this motion that I have moved is now passed by a majority of senators, all barriers to the building of the bridge will have been removed and the bridge will be built. I hope that 39 senators will support the disallowance. I am confident of 36. I hope that all senators have listened carefully to the debate, and that in the division which is to occur in a few minutes time we will see the 36 Liberal and National senators supported by at least three other senators in this chamber.

If we gain the 39 votes, the declaration will be disallowed; there will be no 25-year ban on the building of the bridge and the people of South Australia, and the great majority of the people in the lower Murray region of my state—including the very great majority of people who live on Hindmarsh Island and at Goolwa—will give a great cheer that justice has been upheld; that saneness and soundness will have been rewarded; and that inappropriate action by a federal minister would have been disallowed. I urge all senators to support the motion for disallowance.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Teague's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in full flight at about 7.20 on Monday night speaking on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) before being interrupted by the Acting Deputy President who was in the chair at the time. Now I have to get back the same sort of enthusiasm that I had—not enthusiasm for the issue but for attacking the government on the disastrous way it has hoodwinked the Australian public about the home child-care allowance. At the last election, Mr Keating said that the person at home caring for a child would get $30.

PARA.TAB: The people who listened to that election speech would have thought `tremendous'. Little did they know that the dependent spouse rebate would be taken out of the paid working partner's contribution, with about $2.60 added to make up the $30—a pea and thimble trick. Many of the carers at home, who are mainly women, were hoodwinked into thinking they were going to get $30.

Then the government tried to implement that promise. It suddenly found that there were some complications when it took the money out of the tax system and put it into the Department of Social Security. When I was last speaking on this bill—before I was interrupted because we ran out of time—I was outlining some of the problems associated with that, and I will continue with them.

One problem is that a significant number of families with dependent spouses and dependent children who are currently eligible for the dependent spouse rebate will not be eligible to transfer to the home child-care allowance. They will not be eligible for the home child-care allowance primarily because the transfer of this payment from the taxation system to the social security system involves consequent differences between the systems—differences in residency requirements, age requirements, prescribed student exclusion and spouse and income definitions.

When I was interrupted on Monday night, I was talking about young academics on study leave for six to 12 months who would not be eligible for the dependent spouse rebate or the home child-care allowance because they were away. They would have been eligible for the dependent spouse rebate under the old system before Mr Keating's election promise. Those young people, while trying to improve their knowledge and skills and contribute to the education of other young Australians, were going to be penalised. Those are the sorts of people we are talking about.

We argued this point when another bill was debated in relation to this issue. Fortunately, the government has had belatedly and grudgingly to amend the legislation to deal with this issue. We were actually right. Mr Keating said, `No family will be worse off.' That is similar to the promise of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, who said `No child will live in poverty.' Here was the next Prime Minister giving us another promise—that no family would be worse off. We identified a large number of families that would be worse off, and the minister at the table at the time—I think it was Senator Crowley—pooh-poohed the idea and said that it was all wrong.

Now the government has grudgingly come to the party and brought in some amendments. Families which were ineligible for the home child-care allowance under different social security definitions were not even able to claim the dependent spouse rebate at the with-child dependent spouse rate under the new government amendments. They will receive the dependent spouse rebate only at the lower rate for dependent spouses without children. The way the government goes about it is pretty measly. People claiming a rebate cannot go back to the old system; they can get the without-child dependent spouse rebate. So they are still penalised under the government amendments.

The without-child dependent spouse rebate is paid at the lower rate of $1,188, while the with-child rebate is paid at $1,425. In effect, if a family is left claiming the dependent spouse rebate on the without-child rate, it will be $237 worse off, and it will be $372 worse off than families with dependent spouses and children who are receiving the home child-care allowance. Mr Keating's promise was that no family would be worse off. As my colleague Senator Watson foreshadowed, I will move an amendment in the committee stage of this debate to ensure that those families which currently receive the with-child dependent spouse rebate and which are not eligible for the HCCA, because of the stricter eligibility test, will continue to receive the with-child DSR.

The home child-care allowance has been a disaster from beginning to end. I will give honourable senators an example. I was talking on the phone last night to somebody who had applied for the home child-care allowance. The application form was sent in, but a signature was missing on one page. Back came a new form, not the old form so that the person concerned could correct it and sign it. If that person makes an error on that new form, I presume it will go to the Department of Social Security and come back again. It is a whole lot of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should understand the number of pieces of paper that are—
—Well, they just get extra numbers of pieces of paper.
—Why don't you go and have a look at how it actually works? I've done it.
—It did not work for this family. The old form could have been sent back for signature rather than a whole new form.

PARA.TAB: As I said, this was Mr Keating's key election policy commitment. At the launch at his last election campaign he said, `This allowance is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it will replace.' But that was a deliberate deception. The scheme was flawed in its original drafting and implemented with incompetence, trickery and bungling.

The history of the home child-care allowance has involved an election promise that was a deliberate hoax and deception. The original bill caused thousands of families which qualified for the dependent spouse rebate not to be eligible for the HCCA because of different DSS income and eligibility criteria. There was a belated and begrudging government amendment to provide a safety net for those currently eligible for DSR but not eligible for HCCA, but only at the without child rate of DSR—a totally unacceptable and inequitable proposal.

The history has involved a situation whereby thousands of families which do qualify for HCCA will be worse off than when receiving the DSR because of different and stricter DSS definitions of income. And it has involved a bungled legislative program, resulting in the government incompetently failing to pass the complementary tax legislation which abolishes the dependent spouse rebate in time for the start-up of the HCCA—a bungle which has placed around 420,000 families in danger of receiving unexpected tax bills. In addition, there is the overriding inequity of means testing the home child-care allowance but not means testing the child-care rebate.

By paying HCCA directly to the carer a positive signal is being sent to the community about recognition of the real value to our society of the task of raising children. I have acknowledged that before when I have spoken on this issue in this place. But it can be argued that this message is not evident in a system which gives a tax deductible spouse rebate to the parent who is not at home raising the children. The message is half-hearted in that it offers $30 a week, means tested, to parents who choose to raise their children at home, but offers up to $60 a week to parents who go out to work and put their children in a child-care centre.

As I have said, the federal government has been forced to admit that its new home child-care allowance has not lived up to Mr Keating's promise that it would be more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it replaces. The very fact that the government has indicated that it will move an amendment to provide a safety net confirms what the coalition said at the outset—that thousands of families will be worse off.

In fact, this has been an absolute disaster from beginning to end. It was a promise hatched up, I suppose, with Ms Anne Summers—who was brought out at great cost to the Australian public to help Mr Keating win the women's vote—and dreamed up somewhere without any consultation on implementation. We have seen that it has not been easy to implement. It will mean that some families are worse off and, despite our best efforts, some families will still not get the same amount they were getting under the DSR. This has been an absolute hoodwinking of the Australian public and the government will be constantly reminded of it by this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is the third of probably five omnibus taxation bills which, up until this week, the parliament was expecting to consider this year. I doubt whether we will get around to them now. The bill contains 158 sections amending the income and sales tax laws. It creates sections with such interesting new names as 160CX5A, which sounds more like a radio station than a section of a tax act.

PARA.TAB: This tax act appears to be growing more quickly than the Assistant Treasurer, George Gear, and his new income tax simplification group can reduce and simplify it. It has 20 chapters dealing with a wide range of tax matters, small and large. The largest revenue measure is the introduction of the reportable payments system, first foreshadowed in September 1992 and expected to raise upwards of $100 million a year.

Much of the bill deals with various concessions and rebates, such as incentives for regional headquarters of multi-national corporations, arrangements governing the dependent spouse rebate and home child-care allowance, provisional tax, tax deductibility of cultural bequests, and sales tax exemptions for exported re-manufactured goods. The Australian Democrats will be supporting most of the bill, although we will be proposing three sets of amendments and supporting one of the opposition amendments.

Before moving to the areas of contention, I want briefly to note three areas of the bill. Firstly, this bill sets up the prescribed payment system for taxation, and this initiative was first foreshadowed in the Treasurer's tax statement back in September 1992. It is probably worth recalling a little bit of the politics of the time because that was when the government was under pressure to fund its unfunded tax cuts and it explored a range of tax options after the 1992 budget. Then, miraculously, Tax Commissioner Trevor Boucher sent a letter to Treasurer Dawkins proudly claiming that he could collect hundreds of millions of dollars of extra tax revenue with a few new compliance measures. I think that solved the government's immediate dilemma. It was about to go to a 1993 federal election with tax funds it claimed were now funded, only to discover in the 1993 budget that they were not and forcing up a range of indirect taxes instead.

Two years later the key compliance measure from the 1992 tax statement has finally arrived. I note that Mr Boucher's successor, Mr Carmody, has revised down substantially the amount he thinks he can collect from the prescribed payment system to just $100 million. The Democrats will give this measure our support and we will watch with interest to see the revenue that the government ends up collecting from this measure.

The second item I wish to mention is the concessions for the establishment of regional headquarters in Australia. We do not object to it in principle, but we are not entirely convinced about the way we are going about it. I note that a wide range of firms have reported that the concessions are not competitive enough when compared with Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong. But, given our much higher standard of living and provision of government services, I would hate to see Australia engaged in a tax bidding war against developing countries.

I am concerned about the priorities which the government shows in this bill in respect of providing millions of dollars of concessions to multinational companies to come to Australia. I am not concerned about their coming; I am concerned about the government's priorities in doing that on the one hand at the same time as denying urgently needed tax relief to Australian small business. Again, this is an initiative that we will be watching.

The third item I wish to mention is the sales tax exemption on re-manufactured goods. The Democrats, after a lot of consultation with industry, have resolved to support the opposition amendment to extend the sales tax exemption from re-manufactured goods used by business and intended for export to include non-taxable organisations. This was the case until 1992. Given that re-manufacturing is a labour intensive area with the potential to reduce our propensity to import capital goods, that manufacturing encourages the recycling and the extension of the life of equipment and that non-taxable organisations deserve to be treated no less favourably than taxable ones, we have resolved to support the opposition amendment.

Later in this debate my colleague Senator Lees will outline our position on the provisions relating to the dependent spouse rebate and Senator Coulter will move amendments to the cultural bequests section. But I want to concentrate on the provisional tax uplift factor. Too often, and most recently in the employment white paper and the budget, the government has forgotten that small business is the engine room of job creation. If Australia is ever to reduce unemployment to five per cent or lower, this has to be recognised.

The tax system, the finance system and the regulatory system need to be adjusted to broaden the growth horizons of small business rather than to hinder them, as they often do at present. A few weeks ago, Alexander Downer released The Things That Matter. In that document he committed the opposition to promotion of small business, to greater assistance for families and to genuine but balanced environmental policies. He committed the opposition to building up the status of parliament and to more effective scrutiny of legislation in the parliamentary process.

This bill gives the opposition an opportunity to do a lot of that. I want to know what the opposition thinks about the anti-small business provisions contained in the provisional tax section of this bill. This bill seeks to put into practice the budget announcement that the provisional tax uplift factor will be set at eight per cent for 1994-95. That means that provisional taxpayers, including most small business people, farmers and self-funded retirees, will automatically have their taxable income from 1993-94 inflated by eight per cent to become their provisional taxable income for 1994-95.That is nearly four times the inflation rate.

The result is to force many small businesses to pay more tax than they should have to. I do not object to people having to pay tax, but I think we have to do it fairly. Based on government estimates, setting the uplift factor at eight per cent rather than, say, five per cent, increases the tax take in 1994-95 by about $250 million. This is the money which the government largely concedes it will have to refund in 1995-96. So by setting the provisional tax uplift factor too high the government is effectively borrowing money—money out of the pockets of cash-strapped small business. It is a clever trick if people think they can get away with it. Up until this year the loan was interest free. Now a small interest rate will be paid until it is refunded.

The government tells us that small businesses can apply to have their provisional tax uplift factor reduced, but this requires a detailed assessment of income projections, with penalties if the projection is outside the approved 15 per cent tolerance. For most people, such a detailed income projection costs money.

The President of the National Tax Agents Association, Ray Regan, gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Monday, 3 October 1994, that to have such an application professionally prepared would cost between $60 and $600. He said that it takes time, it takes effort and it adds to the compliance costs. Mr Regan estimated that half or about 800,000 provisional taxpayers would have income which would rise by less than eight per cent, and should be encouraged to apply for a variation. About 170,000 taxpayers had to apply for a variation last year. Based on Mr Regan's estimate of the cost of such applications, that represents a compliance cost last year of between $10 million and $100 million.

More than that, I think the government has failed to establish any defensible rationale for the eight per cent figure. The explanatory memorandum says that the uplift factor reflects the effects of inflation and other relevant factors. Inflation in 1994-95 is estimated to be a bit over two per cent. So what are the other relevant factors?

Treasury officials at the Senate committee hearing failed to identify these factors, but we can look at other relevant factors. On term of shares the all ordinaries index rose just 5.08 per cent in the year until August. Retail trade increased by just 5.72 per cent in the year to June. Ninety day bill interest rates rose from about 4.75 per cent to about 5.5 per cent in 1993-94. The property market was mixed, with metropolitan residential markets improving but commercial and rental properties remaining fairly flat.

What does that leave us with? The relevant factors all seem to suggest that eight per cent is just too high. In fact, the relevant factors have been suggesting that for four years. In the five years to 1994-95 the uplift factor has exceeded the inflation rates by an average of 6.3 per cent. This is more than twice the gap between the uplift factor and the inflation rate over the previous five years from 1985-86 to 1989-90.

Over the past five years, provisional tax receipts have been very flat and have risen by less than the inflation rate. In the last three years for which tax statistics are available, the average income of provisional taxpayers fell by an average of 0.4 per cent, against an uplift factor of 10 per cent. The Democrats, in our budget submission to the government, called for a reduction of this uplift factor. This followed discussion with members of the Small Business Coalition and was part of our response to the key issues they raised. We were disappointed that the white paper on employment failed to address the impact of provisional tax on small business cash flows, compliance costs and employment generation ability.

The opposition tells me that it is not going to support our amendment. It has trotted out some terrific justifications, the first one being that it is going to plunder the public revenue. Minimal cost is not plundering the public revenue. If Senator Panizza had been at the Senate committee hearing, he would have heard Treasury officials say that over two years it costs virtually nothing. The second little excuse we heard from the opposition was, `Small business is already engaged in working all this out and does not want to have to change. Let us wait until next year.' But those opposite should ask small businesses whether they would like some cash back now. They will say that they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about petrol?

—That is the only thing Senator Abetz can ever trot out. He should look at what we are trying to do to solve the real problem in the petrol industry. We supported the suspension of the training guarantee levy.
—You supported its introduction.
—Yes, and it was effective for a while. The second reason was that small businesses cannot handle money back at the moment. Being able to answer that, the third reason is that it is blocking supply.
—No, it is not.

—Senator Panizza should speak to COSBOA about the reasons proffered by the opposition. COSBOA has certainly been told that the opposition does not want to block supply. We all know that the political motivation of the opposition in this case is to avoid doing anything that would give the government a trigger. It is not costing money; small business wants it; and it is something really constructive we can do immediately for small business.
—And you don't want to, I suppose?

—I do not mind whether we do or we do not. I do not predicate my decisions on what they do for the government's election strategy. I predicate my decisions on what is right—in this case, for small business. And small business is crying out for this right now.
—I don't believe you; that is a most disingenuous reply.

—Senator Vanstone can examine our record. We have never voted for a piece of legislation because of how it fits into a government's electoral strategy. She might be making a mistake in ascribing her motives to the way the Democrats operate—she would not understand it.
—Why not? I am asking you—
—I am not ascribing motives; I have been told. With the cash flows of small business improved by something between zero and $250 million—
—Wishful thinking!

—The history will be written one day—and this will all be documented. With the cash flows of small business improved by something between zero and $250 million, additional employment would be generated—this is what the opposition needs to consider—possibly by as many as 7,000 to 10,000 extra jobs. Private sector debt should fall by a similar amount as small business will no longer have to use scarce cash reserves to pay tax bills and borrow for the purposes.

PARA.TAB: I think that provisional tax needs to be reformed. I do not believe the Senate should pass legislation which so adversely affects small business, when it has other options. As the Council of Small Business Organisations head, Mr Rob Bastian, put it:

SPEECH.PARA: Small firms have played their part by employing large numbers during the depths of the recession. They look to you—
the opposition—
now to treat these quite reasonable and oft expressed concerns seriously.

In terms of priorities, I think it is wrong that the government in this bill is providing huge concessions to multinational companies—$20 million in tax relief to foreign owned banks—and continuing to treat small business in this discriminatory way by placing the uplift factor at the level it is.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.
