TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I seek to address the report from the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, Waste disposal, which was tabled last month. I had the pleasure of serving on that committee. Let me say, firstly, what a pleasure it was being involved with my colleagues from all sides of politics. Secondly, this report once again highlights the benefits of Senate committees with members from all parties investigating matters and coming down with reports—once again, in this situation, with a unanimous report. Thirdly, it is unfortunate that these types of reports do not get the degree of media publicity that they deserve. The people of Australia do not often see this side of the parliament in operation; nor do they see the results achieved by these committees, where senators from the Labor Party, the Democrats, the National Party and the Liberal Party cooperate to achieve a report.

PARA.TAB: To commence my remarks about the report, let me thank Robert King, Cheryl Scarlett and other members of the committee secretariat for their efforts. The background to this report is that on 17 November 1993 the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts received a reference on existing and developmental waste disposal facilities and methods, including the use of incineration as a means of disposal of waste and energy recovery, the application of alternative technologies to the disposal of toxic and hazardous wastes, the potential for commercial development, and the export opportunities of methods of waste disposal and waste disposal technologies.

The inquiry was required to take particular account of the findings and recommendations contained in two reports: the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste report entitled A cleaner Australia and the Scheduled Wastes Working Group report to the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council which was dated 27 May 1993.

In all, the committee received 89 submissions. The committee has presented a report of some 280 pages. I suggest that it is in fact a report to all Australians, and a report that is worthy of consideration. As such, I recommend it to all Australians, because waste disposal is a problem that needs to be addressed not only by industry and by government but by all Australians. Waste disposal is a community problem. It is not only an industry problem, it is also a domestic household problem—and, of course, a problem that local councils and local shires around Australia need to deal with, as it is usually their task to deal with waste disposal.

It was estimated by one witness that 14 million tonnes of waste is generated in our country each year. That is a lot of waste. Unfortunately, a mere 10 per cent of this is actually recycled, so well in excess of 10 million tonnes of waste is categorised as waste with no further use. Approximately 90 per cent of our waste goes into landfill.

Some years ago, as part of a political exchange program, I had the privilege of examining the landfill waste disposal program in Germany. Vacant land is at premium prices in Europe. In Australia we have been cushioned to a certain extent because of our vast tracts of vacant land. However, it is still a problem that we need to consider as a nation before it is too late.

Another problem with landfill is not only the scarcity of vacant land but the fact that the substances from the landfill eventually do leach into our waterways and our underground water supplies. It has been estimated by the Environment Protection Agency that 30 to 50 per cent of the materials going into landfill could be used in other ways.

In considering the problems of waste disposal, the committee needed to define what waste actually is. I will read from page 2 of the report, paragraph 1.7, where two people who gave evidence to the committee came up with their definitions of waste. Professor Mainwaring said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . things are waste in the absence of an economic method of recovery and recycling.
Dr Cole of the Environment Management Industry Association of Australia defined waste in these words:
. . . something that has no economic utility and has to be disposed, or stored, or whatever, but has no utility to society.

The best method of dealing with waste is minimising it in the first place. That is where all Australians can make their own contribution to the welfare of their country. For example, packaging represents about 33 per cent of household waste by weight, and considerably more by volume, according to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. If there can be a reuse of packaging, or less demand for it, we will be making some progress in dealing with our waste disposal problem. Every Australian can assist in that regard.

PARA.TAB: As Australians, we individually consume approximately 70 kilograms of plastic each year. Plastic is an important and very convenient product in our day-to-day lives. However, I am sure that all of us could do something to decrease the consumption of plastic and thus relieve some of the problems our country faces.

Apart from dealing with domestic waste, industrial waste was considered in great detail. A lot of the report is technical and deals with incineration and things of that nature, but I believe that the points I have made thus far are designed to encourage our fellow citizens actively and conscientiously to consider in their daily activities a course of action which will minimise the creation of waste.

Clearly, the disposal of waste is not environmentally sustainable. It also raises the issue of a future resource crisis if materials continue to be disposed of. Simply put, waste in the right quantity and used in the right way becomes a reusable or a recyclable material. As the committee stated, it unanimously supported the principles of waste minimisation and reuse as priorities, and the recycling of waste into other materials in preference to final disposal.
In commenting on this unanimous report, it is noteworthy that certain Commonwealth departments were not at all cooperative with the committee. Paragraph 11.76 on page 266 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter of concern to the Committee was the reluctance of some Commonwealth Departments to assist with this inquiry. The exception to this was the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, who provided a comprehensive written submission, provided informative comments at the public hearing and supplementary material subsequent to the hearing. The Committee appreciates the efforts of the officers from CEPA.
The important part in this paragraph follows thus:

The other relevant Commonwealth Departments did not provide information on very basic issues and did not answer adequately the fundamental questions asked at public hearings. The Committee reserves the right to follow up this matter at a later date.

The lack of cooperation is a sad reflection on these departments. If waste management is to be adequately addressed in this country, all government departments need to be on top of the subject, be conversant with the issues and be aware of the available information and statistics so as to be able to provide the necessary foundations on which to develop our policies in this area. An incapacity to answer fundamental questions and a refusal or incapacity to provide information on very basic issues reflects poorly on the relevant departments and their personnel. It is, more importantly, a great disservice to this country, which is seeking to grapple with the problem of waste disposal. I trust that the relevant ministers have read this report and given the necessary ministerial directives to ensure that their departments become more cooperative.

PARA.TAB: If key departments do not possess the important data, let alone the will, to be actively involved in this issue, then waste disposal as an area of government policy will clearly be neglected to the detriment of this country. It is noteworthy that that was the unanimous finding of the committee. It was not a partisan political point that was sought to be made by the opposition or Democrats but something that was agreed to by the whole committee.

In the few moments that I have left I wish to deal with another environmental issue which is somehow related. It is the issue of the fishing industry's care of our seas and use of them as a convenient dumping ground. I believe that it is only a small group within the fishing industry that undertakes this type of activity but I wish to relate an experience to the Senate this afternoon. One week ago today it was my wedding anniversary and my wife and I decided to take the day off and go for a bushwalk in southern Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not allowed. You are not allowed a day off.

—I did allow myself that one day off. Given the substantial sacrifices that my spouse makes in allowing me to be here, I thought it only appropriate that I agree to her suggestion that we do that. It was an absolutely fantastic day. I just want to recount the walk. I might add that, when we stopped for lunch and I unpacked the lunch box I was carrying, I discovered why the pack was so heavy. Out came the bottle of wine, the bottle opener, the glasses, the works. I am sure that I would not have carried all that if I had known that it was in the pack at the commencement of the walk! But of course that was my spouse's prerogative and I had no complaints.

PARA.TAB: To come back to the point at issue, we walked in from Cockle Creek through Blowhole Valley to South Cape Bay. An hour into the walk we noticed the signs to indicate our entry to the south-west Tasmania World Heritage area. The plains and forests were absolutely superb. The air was fresh, clean and crisp and, thankfully, the rain held off. After two hours walk through this truly exhilarating landscape, we heard the sound of the Southern Ocean and the breakers on the shore. The sea air was superb. The craggy coastline was awe-inspiring.

However, as we descended the rock face, my wife and I were horrified by the amount of rubbish on the beach—from bait box fasteners, to buoys, plastic drums, bits of rope and general rubbish, which were literally strewn everywhere for the whole length of the beach. And that was in an area which is supposedly a pristine wilderness area. That scene did detract from an otherwise excellent and superb walking area.

I would simply call on those elements in the fishing industry to reassess their waste disposal policy, to take their waste back to harbour and shore and then dispose of it on land. Our environment is our heritage and our bequest to future generations. We, Australians all, have an obligation to care for it and nurture it. We can all make a contribution by carefully minimising the waste we create, reusing what we can and thoughtfully disposing of that which we cannot reuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first issue that I wish to pursue today relates to the sending of food parcels and other commodities to the rural areas of New South Wales and Queensland in this time of drought, which is affecting areas to a varying degree. What is happening on some occasions is that these organisations—very well-meaning and well-intentioned organisations—are sending commodities and food parcels to areas where there are adequate shops for people to make the purchases themselves. When such organisations send these parcels, they obviously do not consider the effect it will have upon the economies of those communities.

PARA.TAB: It is not just the farmers who are finding cash flows tight in this time of drought, it is also small businesses. The sending of food parcels, staples and food commodities to these drought affected areas is having a serious detrimental effect upon the businesses and shops in those areas. I would call upon those people who are involved in this—and I am not being critical of them in any way, I just do not think that they have thought through fully the ramifications of their actions—to talk to the local people and community organisations to work out the best methods of providing assistance to those areas.

The sending of food parcels directly impacts upon the income of businesses, shops and stores in drought affected areas by reducing their incomes and, of course, this is seriously affecting the viability of those businesses. When the drought is over, those businesses are going to be needed in the restocking of those areas. However, if they are forced to close because of organisations sending in food parcels, staples and commodities, then the area that they serve will deteriorate further.

That infrastructure is absolutely essential to the continuation of those communities. Some of the communities are quite small and may have only one store. The last thing that that store needs, as it tries to eke out its living, is for someone to render it nonviable. No-one can stay, out of the goodness of their heart, waiting for the drought to end and waiting for rain to come and the incomes of farmers to increase, with no income for themselves. So it is not just the farmers who have these problems, it is also the small businesses.

I am aware that the issue was also raised at the Diocesan Synod of the Anglican Church that is based in Bathurst. It covers the western areas of New South Wales. There is an article in a newspaper out there which clearly states that 10 tonnes of potatoes were sent to Bourke. That is very commendable on the part of the people sending it, but it means that the stores and the greengrocers in Bourke will not be selling any potatoes. I am aware from some conversations with the ABC that one of the large food producers—a large food canning company—is sending a load of canned fruit and vegetables. Wherever this goes, it will mean that the shops in that community are not going to be selling those commodities. As I said, that has a detrimental effect upon the income of those shops.

I would urge people to think very carefully about how they give assistance to organisations. I would also urge organisations to think very carefully about how they are rendering assistance. I have spoken to people in the Smith Family in New South Wales and they have assured me that they are giving cheques and cash. Farmhand is also giving money. Giving people money has a twofold effect: it means that the money is being spent in the community in which the person receiving it lives; and it also means that the people receiving the aid are able, like everybody else, to walk into the shop to buy their commodities, their food or whatever it is they wish to purchase.

If people are given money they do not feel as though they are labelled and they do not feel stigmatised by having a voucher or by having to identify themselves by saying, `I need some assistance. I need a food parcel.' Giving cash helps maintain the dignity of the people who are in need of assistance and it also has a beneficial impact on the businesses, industries and shops in the areas that are being assisted. I urge people to think carefully about this issue.

I am not the only person who has raised this issue. It was raised at the diocesan synod. It has also been raised by the Mayor of Gilgandra, Carol Packham. From a news item that I have heard, I know that she is also concerned about what can be happening. It is not happening only to those areas that are classified in extreme drought; it is happening in large areas where people think and know that the drought is, but where it has not yet reached the extreme stage. I urge people to be conscious of this.

The Retail Traders and Shopkeepers Association of Queensland has also highlighted this as a problem for its members. I urge those people who are involved in sending out and delivering aid and assistance to those people in need to think carefully about the best ways of providing that assistance. I suggest that the best way would be to talk to local government in the areas that are affected, and talk to community organisations and make sure that those community organisations are actually using cash, or, if they are providing physical assistance, that those goods are being purchased in the areas in which they are going to be given.

When people talk to the local branches of organisations which are involved in the provision of assistance to the community groups—St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, Centrecare, Careforce—I ask them please to be aware that there is an absolutely essential need to make sure that the goods used in assisting people are purchased in the areas in which they are going to be given. We cannot afford to have those areas harmed any more than the drought is doing. We do not want to add unthinking assistance to what nature is doing. Unthinking damage can be done by people who, with all the best intentions, want to help people.

To those people who are involved in the provision of aid and those people who want to make food parcels, my plea today is: do not do it. Talk to people who are involved in the provision of assistance and look at the best ways that you can provide the assistance. There are ways that you can provide assistance that will help not just the farmers, but also the small businesses and industries in those towns. As I said before, we very much need those industries and businesses in those towns when the drought breaks.

The other issue I wish to pursue today relates to superannuation and the problems that widows and widowers have after their spouse, who was on a superannuation pension, dies and they have to transfer across. Members may recall that I spoke earlier on an issue related to superannuation. Following my husband's death, I was not eligible for a spouse pension on his superannuation because, prior to our marriage, he had been discharged from the New South Wales Police Force for medical reasons. That does not affect me financially, but it could affect others.

The other issue that I am aware of, and am becoming more aware of since I raised it, is the fact that when the pensioner dies the superannuation pension ceases on the date of death. I am reliably informed by those involved in assisting police widows and widowers that it takes six to eight weeks before the spouse is placed onto the spouse pension. In my dealings with the New South Wales State Superannuation Board I was callously told, with no feeling, no concern or anything, `Go and talk to Social Security'. I have had reported to me again that those comments are still being made to people. There has to be a better and more understanding way to handle the transfer of widows and widowers across to their superannuation pension entitlements following the death of the person who was the initial superannuant pensioner.

I raise this because the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation is looking at women and superannuation. Most of the people affected by this are women, and I want to raise this today so that I can raise the consciousness level of people and organisations out there dealing with superannuation and women, particularly those dealing with widows and widowers receiving the spouse component of their deceased spouse's superannuation pension, so that they can be aware of it. Then we can actually raise it as an issue; we can raise it as something for people to think about.

It is an issue that I had not given any thought to until it actually happened to me, and I guess most people are in that situation. But I urge those people who are concerned about the lack of a seamless transfer from one superannuation pension to the other to address this issue. They would be well advised to address it to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. It is an issue that I want to pursue, and I have given notice to the committee that I want to pursue that within the committee because I think it is a very important issue.

It is a traumatic enough time for people when they lose their spouse; but it is even worse for some. Most of these people are not, as I am, under 50. Most of those who are affected by this are in their 60s, 70s, 80s or even 90s. They are frail, elderly, suffering from the trauma of having lost their spouse—and they may have been married for up to 50 or 60 years—and suddenly they do not know what to do or how or where to do it. They are facing a reduction in their income anyway. The last thing they or their family need to be told when they talk to these people on the phone is, `You have got to talk to Social Security, you have to fill out forms and you have to provide a death certificate—you have to do all of these things.'

Death certificates take some weeks to come through. If, in an unfortunate situation, there has been a coronial inquiry or something like that, then that also may delay the issuing of a death certificate. It may delay the whole fixing up of this issue and add extra strain and burden to those people who are bereaved. I urge anybody who is aware of this situation to think carefully about it, and think through just how seamless is the transfer of superannuation pensions from one spouse to another upon a spouse's death. It is an issue that is of great concern to women, and it is one that we tend to overlook until we actually experience it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night on national media the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, described me in personally abusive, intemperate and offensive language that, had it been said in the parliament, would have had to have been withdrawn.
—It was totally deserved.

—The minister interjected that it was totally deserved. In other words, his standards are such that personal abuse is an appropriate way for the Prime Minister and ministers in this place to behave when they have no other response. I am grateful to the minister for showing his standards in this place—standards that are no better than the Prime Minister's. Now that the Prime Minister has had time to reflect on the matter I ask him formally, here and now, to withdraw those remarks and to apologise to me. As I said, the remarks were unparliamentary and had they been made in the parliament would have been required to have been withdrawn.
—How many unparliamentary remarks have you made in the parliament about him?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wonder if it is possible for me to speak as much as the minister interjects. This minister is a persistent interjector whenever I rise, and it is a pattern of misbehaviour—
—Order, Senator Schacht!

—I give notice that I will take up the matter of the nature of those persistent interjections, which are aimed at preventing me from speaking. It is not just an incidental event, it is a persistent pattern. As I said, the Prime Minister would have been required to withdraw those remarks had they been made in parliament and I ask him, now that he has had time to reflect and cool down, to withdraw those remarks and to apologise to me.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that I have, at times in this chamber, described some of the Prime Minister's actions, particularly in relation to his piggery, as disgraceful. I have described his actions as disgraceful; I have not made pejorative remarks about him, as he has made about me. This is the essential point. I have said that his actions in respect of this piggery are inappropriate for a Prime Minister. In other words, I have dealt with his actions and whether or not they are the appropriate actions of a Prime Minister, and that is a quite proper procedure. If there has been any objection taken to anything that I have said in this chamber, and the Presiding Officer has required it to be withdrawn, I have withdrawn it. Quite frankly, I can recall very few occasions when that has been required.

This Prime Minister, however, has chosen to make statements outside the Parliament which he so far has not yet withdrawn, although I feel confident that he must regret the statements. I challenge the Prime Minister to indicate any occasion when I have used the sort of personal abuse against the Prime Minister that he has used against me. Once again, I ask him to apologise for his intemperate and personally abusive behaviour to me. There is no doubt that imputations emerge from many of the facts that I presented to this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —What facts? When have you presented facts?

—For example, I have presented details of Australian Securities Commission documents revealing that the Prime Minister's half-owned companies told massive lies about their financial status and the parliamentary secretary interjects, `What facts?' I have tabled these facts.
—You lie all the time.
—I have tabled them. There has never been any dispute, and what is more fascinating—
—You are the biggest liar in this place.
—Did I hear the parliamentary secretary interject in a way that personally reflected on me?
—Yes. You're a liar.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I ask the parliamentary secretary to withdraw those comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I withdraw them.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, that interjection that I was a liar was a conscious and deliberate part of a pattern of disgraceful behaviour by members of the government who aim to prevent me from making the points I am seeking to make. They are seeking to denigrate me personally because of the facts—and I stress, the facts—that I present. For example, the facts of the companies half-owned by the Prime Minister making massive losses when they pretended in false returns to the Securities Commission that they had made profits; false returns that asserted that they had positive shareholders' funds when they had negative shareholders' funds; and false returns that covered up the fact that five of the seven public companies in that group were technically insolvent because their liabilities exceeded their assets. All those facts were covered up and I exposed them. All I got was the sort of personal abuse that this parliamentary secretary and the previous minister and this Prime Minister have inundated me with.

PARA.TAB: Is it not fascinating, when there is no response in factual terms, that the last resort of someone who is desperate is personal abuse. When there is a sound response, when there is a factual response, when one can present evidence to support one's position, people do not need to depend on personal abuse. They simply do not need to. It is the last resort of someone with a lack of capacity to respond factually.

There is no doubt that there are imputations that emerged from the facts I presented. There is an imputation that emerged from the fact that I revealed that the Commonwealth Bank, while Mr Keating was a half-owner of this piggery group, had to make a provision for bad debts of $4.5 million. Of course, that was at a time when the Commonwealth Bank was putting a lot of farmers off their properties for debts far lower than that. That is a fact, and no doubt that is a fact that the government does not like because all I get in response to it is personal abuse. The government does not like the imputation that emerges from the facts that I have presented.

It is more than a dispute between the opposition and the government. It is more than a question of personal abuse. This whole matter of the Prime Minister's purchase of a $2.2 million Woollahra mansion, which he is now being criticised for and which I have been subjected to personal abuse over because I dared to raise it—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did your house cost?
—It cost me $220,000.
—Where did you get the money for that?

—I actually saved it. I thank the parliamentary secretary for his perpetual interjections, which as I said are aimed at preventing me from properly presenting the facts to this chamber. It is part of a disgraceful campaign in which he is a happy participant.
—You are lying all the time. Nothing would prevent you from continual lies.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: you have called the parliamentary secretary to order once for calling Senator Baume a liar. Senator Sherry now seeks to continue to do that. I draw your attention to standing order 203, which gives the Senate the power to take action where a senator is guilty of disorderly conduct.

PARA.TAB: There is an agreement in the chamber that, during the luncheon debates, honourable senators do not call quorums or have divisions. Senator Sherry is abusing that agreement between honourable senators. The only way that we can stop Senator Sherry's disorderly conduct is to seek the sanctions under standing order 203. I ask you to draw his attention to the fact that, if he continues so to act, we will have to take action in that regard.

It is clearly a contempt of the Senate to seek to continue his disorderly behaviour, because he knows quite well that it is very hard for the Senate to take that action during the luncheon adjournment, when many of our colleagues are probably outside the building. I warn him, however, that I will certainly move that action be taken if his conduct continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to make a couple of points about the point of order. On the last occasion when, during the luncheon adjournment, the traditions were broken, that was done by Senator Campbell himself. Now he has raised the issue of precedents and behaviour during this luncheon adjournment. He raised the issue, and I am rebutting it.
—That is not a point of order.
—I am speaking to the point of order. Am I allowed to finish my point of order and deal with the points that Senator Campbell raised?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, that is not part of the point of order and I ask you to bring the parliamentary secretary into line.
—That is correct. That is not a point of order, Senator Sherry.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, with due respect, Senator Campbell mentioned the issue of traditions within the luncheon adjournment. I think you would acknowledge that he has raised that matter about the calling of quorums, et cetera.
—That is not a point of order, Senator Sherry.

—Senator Campbell remembered the last time when this happened. He called the quorum and broke the traditions of the chamber. I do not think my behaviour in any way is unruly when we are faced with the litany of—
—The point of order was made earlier in the debate. That is a deliberate attempt—
—Indeed. Senator Sherry, you are not raising a point of order legitimately.

—No, I am addressing the point of order of Senator Campbell. I am not raising a point of order. I am addressing his point of order, that I am unruly. I am seeking to respond to his point of order. If honourable senators would just be quiet, I am on my feet and I would like to finish my comments on the point of order, if I may.
—This is a deliberate obfuscation of Senator Baume's speech.
—When we are faced with the litany of untruths that Senator Baume has thrown across—
—That is not a point of order, Senator Sherry. Would you please resume your seat.

—As I said, this is part of a deliberate campaign to prevent me presenting the facts. It is a disgrace and the parliamentary secretary should behave himself. There is a matter of basic principle involved here—the principle of prime ministers taking risks when they are Prime Minister. Surely it is proper, and everyone accepts it as proper, for ministers of the Crown to report to their Prime Minister—as is required under the cabinet rules—whenever they undertake the purchase of assets or the acceptance of liabilities of any substance at all. The amount has to be reported to the Prime Minister. Those are the cabinet rules. I know that Paul Keating did not abide by them when he bought his piggery, because he failed to report that to former Prime Minister Hawke. We are aware of that from former Prime Minister Hawke's own mouth.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that there is that requirement; in other words, a recognition of the potential for conflict of interest requires ministers to report to their Prime Minister. Who does the Prime Minister report to when he enters a risky, high exposure, big borrowing, commercial venture? Who does he report to? Himself. Because that is an unacceptable situation, it explains why prime ministers as a matter of principle have not entered new, risk taking, high borrowing, commercial ventures while Prime Minister.

Obviously, if someone has a venture going before becoming Prime Minister, the electorate knows of that exposure, that risk and that business. In this case, the electorate did not know that this Prime Minister was going to have to borrow over $1 million and up to $1.5 million on a commercial venture. We know that this purchase of the $2.2 million Woollahra mansion is a commercial venture because Senator Evans told us so. He said, `This has been purchased so that the Prime Minister can lease it out and get a tax benefit.' Senator Evans said that here, so we know it is a commercial venture.

As I said, the principle has been that, because prime ministers cannot simply be answerable to themselves when every other minister is answerable to someone else, prime ministers have by tradition avoided getting involved in this kind of situation where they will be exposed to the changes in interest rates which emerge from government monetary policy. In other words, the potential for conflict of interest is the issue.

We have a situation where we cannot trust this Prime Minister on these matters. In fact, Mr Hawke said today about the Prime Minister that Paul Keating is incapable of telling the truth on the substantive issues. This is Mr Hawke revealing today how Paul Keating was wrong and has misled the people on the facts in relation to the Gulf War. Mr Hawke is saying to Mr Keating, `Don't tell lies. The record shows you are lying. Get on with running the country. That is what your job is, not trying to rewrite history.' The fact is Mr Keating has tried to rewrite history. The fact is he has continued to abuse me when I have presented the facts of his history of half ownership of a disastrous piggery company about which he sought to mislead the Australian people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans representing the Prime Minister, and it is against the background of an extraordinary day in Australian politics when Labor's hero, Bob Hawke, accuses his successor, Paul Keating, of lying in the following terms—and I quote Hawke this morning:

QUESTION.PARA: Now stop it, Paul. Don't tell lies. The record shows that you are lying. Get on with running the country. That's what your job is—not trying to rewrite history.

I ask the minister, as we asked him yesterday: firstly, does he confirm that the record of Bob Hawke in the book is correct, as Senator Evans was present at the meeting? His memory was a little blurred yesterday, but no doubt he has now had time to refresh his memory. Will he confirm the Hawke facts as true as quoted by Hawke from the record this morning? If so, why did Keating in fact argue against Australian support in the war and, if that is so, why is he now criticising the Gulf coalition for not doing the job properly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On an issue as complex as the Iraq invasion in the Gulf, spread out as our consideration of that was over so many months, it is inevitable that recollections will be blurred about what might or might not have been said on particular occasions. A great many meetings were held, whether formally in a cabinet committee context, whether informally between particular groups of ministers or individual ministers, or whether directly or on the telephone.

PARA.TAB: A number of different meetings were held around the time of the original decision to enforce sanctions in August 1990 and again around the time in November 1990 of resolution 678 being passed, the `all necessary means' resolution which did have potential implications for us and did require some decisions about Australian action at that stage. And, of course, a further set of meetings were held at around the time of the Gulf War itself in February 1991.

I have no specific recollection of the particular exchange which is the subject matter of that account in the Hawke memoirs, and I do not think any of the other participants in that particular meeting have any clearer recollection than I do of what was actually said. I am not in a position to confirm what anyone might have said, except to say that any suggestion that Prime Minister Keating was opposed to our commitment to the Gulf War—to the reaction against Iraq—does not conform with my recollection. Indeed, about the only public document I can find around the time—and I do not know who leaked this particular exchange or whose version of it this was—certainly conforms to what Mr Keating is presently saying about the basic character of his reaction—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hawke is a liar?

—No, not at all. This is in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 September, an article by Paul Grigson, in which he is referring to the 10 August meeting involving Mr Duffy and Mr Keating—in my absence overseas Mr Duffy was there as acting foreign minister. The relevant passage is this:

ANSWER.PARA: At that meeting were the acting minister for foreign affairs and trade, Mr Duffy, and the Treasurer, Mr Keating. Both supported the proposal to send two frigates and a supply ship to the Gulf. Mr Keating, attending the meeting in his capacity as Deputy Prime Minister, was gung-ho. He supported immediate and strong action against Saddam Hussein, favouring a military commitment.
I apologise to the Senate for the indelicacy, Mr Deputy President—

That is Mr Keating on the record, at least in the form of a press report, and I have to say that that particular kind of response from Mr Keating is closer to my recollection than the one that appears in Mr Hawke's memoirs.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to be taken as contesting Mr Hawke's account either. The truth of the matter is that I cannot remember what was said. I do not know what was said. All I know is that it is highly unlikely that Mr Keating would have said what he is portrayed as saying in the sense of having some resistance to involvement in the gulf on the basis of it being a US operation.

I know Mr Keating did not perceive it in those terms. He was perfectly well aware there was multinational cover through UN resolutions for this. That was the position I remember him adopting from the outset. He could well have been speculating about the political handling of this, given a perception that it was a US operation. I do not know. People take funny notes at these sorts of meetings, as I discover all the time in looking at what people write about meetings in which I have participated. I am not in a position to second-guess this, nor is anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. That must be the worst answer that this minister has given since he has been sitting in the chair of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What we are talking about here is perhaps the most serious decision that any government could ever make—the decision to deploy Australian troops to a war zone—and this minister has said, `You've got to expect us to have blurred memories about what occurred.' Records are available. The cabinet records are available. Senator Evans keeps his own notes of all these meetings. He tells me he keeps detailed notes. What Bob Hawke said this morning of the current leader of the Labor Party is that he is incapable of telling the truth on the substantive issues. I hope that this minister will not fall into the same error of his predecessor.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to confirm whether he was present at the meeting on 29 November. I ask him to check the cabinet records, as I understand he has access to those records, and his own notes and come back to this Senate and tell us who is lying—former Prime Minister Hawke or Mr Keating. In other words, when Mr Hawke said the record states `Keating started arguing that we should not do anything,' is that correct or otherwise?

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs to be appreciated that there is no cabinet record of the particular meeting on 29 November for the reason that it was not a cabinet or a cabinet committee meeting. There was some record, which Mr Hawke has referred to, that was taken by his own adviser, but not in a cabinet context or not in a PM&C formal note-taking context.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what note might have been taken. I do not know what the perceptions of the note taker who was there might have been about the nature of the exchange. All I know, from my long experience of this matter or any of these sorts of things, is that recollections are constantly faulty on matters of detail. People constantly misremember sequences of events.

The important thing is that at this meeting, as in a lot of other meetings, a lot of options were canvassed and a very clear decision was taken. Every participant in that meeting participated in reaching the decision and implemented a decision which was perfectly clear-cut and straightforward. That is the truth of the matter and that is where it should rest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I understand that this week is International Business Week, which is intended to highlight the commercial benefits of exporting. We all know that exports ultimately mean more jobs in Australia. What is the government doing to assist businesses into exporting, particularly those small and medium size firms which are so vital to our economy and to the creation of additional jobs?
—I congratulate Senator Childs for asking a question—
—Imposed higher taxes on them.
—Order! Senator Kemp!

—Why do you not point out standing order 203 to him, Senator Campbell? I congratulate Senator Childs for asking a question about 1994. It makes a pleasant change. History seminars are of interest but not much value in running the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure most senators, with some notable and loud exceptions, would be aware that this is International Business Week, which is coordinated by Austrade, and that the theme of the week is `Meet the export challenge'. International Business Week is focusing on the need for Australia to become more competitive internationally. There is a lot of detail into which I will not go, but I want to mention two things because there has been some recent publicity about the government not providing sufficient export assistance, particularly to small and medium enterprises.

PARA.TAB: I want to mention initially two seminars which are being conducted in different cities around Australia. The first is a seminar in which senior experts from the grants and loans division of Austrade and officials from the Export Finance Insurance Corporation, from Ausindustry, within Senator Cook's portfolio, will discuss a range of government financial assistance available to exporters. It continues to be a cause for concern that many people eligible for assistance are not aware of the assistance that might be available to them, particularly those in small to medium sized enterprises.

In the second seminar, Asian Development Bank officials will outline that institution's lending to developing countries in this region and advise firms how best to pursue the $6 billion worth of projects arising from it. Once again, I think that is the sort of information that will be particularly valuable to small and medium enterprises which do not have ready access to that level of information. The BHPs and CSRs are quite capable of finding out that information for themselves but the small to medium enterprises tend to need the focal point and the coordinating activity of government to get access to that information.

I would like to refer to two measured effects of government benefits to small to medium enterprises which I think will be valuable for senators. We get a lot of statements of opinion here, but these are some independent evaluations of the value of particular projects, particularly to small to medium enterprises. The first one is the EMDG scheme—the export market development grants scheme—which, as senators will know, is particularly of value to smaller enterprises. That evaluation, as senators may recall because it has been debated here before, suggested that mature exporters generate 15 to 25 times the value of the grants paid in export income. In fact, ITES, the trade enhancement scheme, has an even higher ratio.

More recently, there was an AGB McNair survey which suggested that Austrade helped exporters make $4.8 billion in new sales in the 1993-94 financial year, which is equivalent to 31 times Austrade's running costs to support Australian businesses overseas and a 14 per cent improvement on the previous year's assessment of Austrade's performance. Significantly, the survey showed that small and medium enterprises with turnovers of less than $50 million made up 71 per cent of Austrade's client base and roughly 50 per cent of the clients were small enterprises with annual turnovers of less than $10 million. I think that is a very encouraging and positive picture in the context of International Business Week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to his answer yesterday concerning his recent appointments, reappointments and non-reappointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal and to his previous advice to me that the three-person advisory panel that he appointed to advise him on these appointments included the tribunal chairman, who is a former deputy leader of the Labor opposition in the Northern Territory parliament, and a member of his own ministerial office. Can the minister explain how a small three-person committee which includes a member of his own staff can possibly be considered to be politically independent and capable of making objective, non-political recommendations on such sensitive appointments? Can he also advise which appointments were made either against or without the recommendations of the advisory panel and which panel recommendations for appointment or reappointment he rejected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, as I said yesterday, Senator Short's lack of knowledge in this area is continually surprising. Let me take Senator Short back to what we are talking about. We are talking about appointments by government to a tribunal. We are talking about appointments that traditionally and historically have been made by government at government's discretion. Not only is it a fact of history, but in December 1992 a committee, which had been tasked with reviewing the whole area of non-adversarial immigration decision making, reported to the parliament. That committee was chaired by Mr Ian Macphee, a former Liberal member of parliament and a former immigration minister of the Commonwealth. That committee reported as to the role and the whole concept of making decisions and appointments in this area.

PARA.TAB: At the end of 1992 the committee made it very clear in recommendation 33(3) of its report that it was up to the minister to recommend what appointments should be made. It was up to the minister to make those recommendations to cabinet. The report, which was dealing with the minister setting up a committee to get information as to appointments, said:

ANSWER.PARA: The minister should remain entitled, however, to use additional methods for identifying suitable candidates for appointment and should not be bound to accept the advisory committee's recommendations.
In chapter 78(4) the committee reported that it did not want to impede the minister from accepting advice from other sources or in exercising his or her own judgment as to the most suitable persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order.
—I am giving you some background.

—I know you are, and you might find it fascinating, but it has nothing to do with the question. The question was: was there an advisory panel and were two out of three members Labor Party plants? Therefore, was it in no sense objective? All we are getting is some interesting historical nonsense. Mr Deputy President, I ask you to direct the minister to answer whether the composition of the advisory committee was as suggested by Senator Short.
—On the point of order: I think Senator Bolkus was giving some background as to the process of appointments. Senator Bolkus, I draw your attention to the question.

—I now move to the committee. There was in fact a committee that made recommendations, with the background I have just given. Let me say once again that it does Senator Short no good and it does the opposition no good to run a parallel slur.
—What about having a go at answering the question?

—Pam O'Neil is the chairperson of the Immigration Review Tribunal. She held that position for quite a number of years and no-one, in the period during which she has held it, has been able to level criticism at her. She is a very highly professional person who has conducted her affairs and the affairs of the tribunal in a very competent way. The fact that at some particular time she may have been a member of a political party is of no concern. It has not affected her in any way. It has not affected the way she has conducted this particular function.
—Her appointment was supported by the CLP government of the Northern Territory.
—As Senator Collins said, not only is she a person who has earned the respect of this tribunal, but she is a person who had support when she—

—I rise on a point of order. The minister is still failing to appreciate the question which was: how can he claim that a committee of three, including a member of his staff, was politically independent?
—Senator Bolkus, I again draw your attention to the question.

—What we are talking about here is another slur on another person who is doing a good job for the Commonwealth. These appointments, by their very nature, involve the discretion of the minister. I have a responsibility—

—I rise on a point of order. This is deliberate defiance of your ruling, Mr Deputy President. The question is a very simple one. Was it a stacked court? Was it a stacked panel? Were two out of the three of them Labor Party people? Why will the minister not answer that question? It has nothing to do with slurs.
—Senator Bolkus, it would be helpful if you would be more precise in responding to the question.
—On the point of order: I have been asked to answer some questions by Senator Short. Every 30 seconds—
—You have not started yet.
—You have had five weeks to think of one. Every 30 seconds I get interrupted. I cannot develop my response. As you can see by the clock, Mr Deputy President, my time is up. I ask you—
—Answer the question.
—I make the point that I am answering the question. If I were given a chance to do so, I would answer it more comprehensively.
—Senator Bolkus, you have 57 seconds left.
—Thank you very much.
—Just so we are clear: Senator Bolkus was responding on the point of order; he was not concluding his answer. If he has concluded his answer we will go to the next question.
—I was responding to the point of order. I presume I still have those 57 seconds?
—Yes.

—I presume I will get two points of order during it. The point I am making is this: it is within the province of government to make appointments. We have appointed very highly professional people. Those opposite come in here and criticise Pam O'Neil because of some past allegiance. They may do so, but those opposite will be judged outside this place. Let me say one thing to Senator Short: it has taken him five weeks to wake up to this.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. It is not for Senator Bolkus to be lecturing Senator Short. Senator Bolkus was asked how can he claim that a committee of three, including a member of his own staff, was a politically independent committee. He was also asked, which he seems to have avoided answering altogether, conveniently no doubt, to advise which appointments were made either against or without the recommendation of the advisory panel and which panel recommendations for appointment or reappointment did he reject. The minister should have a go at answering the questions.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Hill should not be giving advice like that. Mr Deputy President, you can if you wish to rule on the point of order; but the very end of Senator Hill's comment has absolutely—
—Why can't he be ordered to answer?
—Senator Hill is not entitled to give advice across the table and be an acting chairman.
—Order! On Senator Hill's point of order, it could be vaguely argued that Senator Bolkus—

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you are not helping me a bit. In respect of the point of order, it could be vaguely claimed that Senator Bolkus was, in a nebulous way, answering a small part of the first part of the question. Senator Bolkus, I think it is fair to say that you are not directing yourself to the question, and I ask you to do so.

—Mr Deputy President, in respect of that part of the question, I can say that all the new appointments in Victoria, for instance, were assessed—and I have positive assessments in respect of them. As to all the others, I will take them on notice and come back to Senator Short.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I look forward to getting the detailed response to the questions that Senator Bolkus has taken on notice. In that context, I note his answer to me yesterday that:

QUESTION.PARA: The jobs were advertised, a list of people was assessed by a panel, that panel made recommendations to me and, in many of those instances, I accepted their recommendations.

He also claimed that he had gone out of his way `to ensure that the people appointed are independent of any influence from me and from the department'. In the light of that, I ask: could the minister either confirm or deny—just a simple yes or no—whether his recent new appointee as a full-time member of the IRT in his own state of South Australia has no legal or immigration experience, was a member of his wedding party at the minister's recent wedding and was appointed without even being interviewed? I further ask whether this appointment was recommended by the advisory panel and, if so, whether it was a unanimous recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, he was not a member of the wedding party. Secondly, as to the recommendation—
—He was or was not?
—He was not. This is another slur that Senator Short is involved in; another slur he has got wrong. He may have been a guest, but he was not a member—

—The other things I will say about him are that, firstly, he has had extensive experience in South Australia's Greek community; and, secondly, not only has he been a teacher at the school to which Alexander Downer's children have gone, but also his wife and Mrs Downer are good friends. So what!
—Mr Deputy President—
—Order! Senator Burns, resume your seat for a moment. Order on my left. I can barely hear the answers or the questions. I would be grateful if those on my left would make less noise.

—Thank you for your help, Mr Deputy President. My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In September, the Prime Minister committed the government to dollar for dollar matching of donations to the farmhand appeal. Would the minister advise the Senate of how much the government has committed to date to this worthy cause?

—In his statement of 21 September, the Prime Minister reaffirmed his earlier commitment to dollar for dollar matching of donations for the farmhand appeal at an estimated cost of $10 million. I am pleased to advise the Senate that yesterday a cheque for $5.4 million was presented to the farmhand coordinator, Mr Doug Miell, as the first instalment in the government's contribution. As of this morning, I am advised that in excess of $9 million of support from farmhand has been allocated to 3,857 households, predominantly in Queensland and New South Wales, with some support distributed in Western Australia and South Australia.

PARA.TAB: In Queensland this support has assisted 6,008 adults, 3,492 children and 321 other dependants. In the light of the government's substantial drought relief package, much of the pressure has now been taken off farmhand resources in Queensland and the worst affected areas of New South Wales. Both farmhand and the drought relief payment have exactly the same objective of helping farmers meet day-to-day living expenses. It is important that we avoid duplication and target our support where it is needed. I spoke with Mr Miell yesterday morning and he agreed that farmhand should now concentrate its efforts outside of those areas that qualify for the drought relief payment. Mr Miell agreed that this was the best use of both government and farmhand resources.

The drought package, including additional resources for the rural financial counselling program run by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, was included in this package. These counsellors will be a useful source of information for Farmhand in targeting the support. Mr Miell is working closely with my office and my department to ensure that farmhand does not duplicate the government's efforts and to assist in the identification of regions of particular need outside of these areas that now qualify for the drought relief payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to various press reports today about the approval of a licence for the export of a further 500,000 tonnes of woodchips from New South Wales forests. Has the minister seen the decision from resources minister Beddall to Sawmillers Export Pty Ltd on its export woodchips licence renewal application? Did Minister Beddall's decision follow the advice to him from the minister when setting the conditions? Were any conditions placed on the licence? Does the minister think that Mr Beddall would actually know what an old growth forest looks like?

—I have seen a copy of the decision of the Minister for Resources on the Sawmillers Exporters Pty Ltd export woodchip licence. As Senator Kernot knows, it is my responsibility to provide Mr Beddall with advice prior to the renewal of export woodchip licences. In the case of SEPL, I provided detailed and extensive advice to Mr Beddall, including stringent conditions to protect the environment.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say from my preliminary examination that the intent of many of my recommendations has been incorporated into the new export licence. Mr Beddall has imposed a number of extra environmental conditions on SEPL's export licence. For example, the licence requires that better information on environmental matters be provided by SEPL in applications to obtain pulpwood from private forests; the licence requires SEPL to provide the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with reports on the volume of export woodchips from each licence source; and there are also requirements to avoid areas on the register of the National Estate and any action which might threaten endangered species.

It is also true that some of my recommendations in relation to this application have not been fully accepted. For example, although the licence contains a new condition requiring the company to report annually on its operations, the reports are not to be made public. I intend to take up Mr Beddall's offer of consultation on this and other outstanding matters as soon as possible.

I am pleased that the Minister for Resources has undertaken to advise the company of any implications arising from the study that my department is carrying out to identify areas of old growth forest that are likely to have high conservation values. The purpose of this exercise is to rigorously assess all available information about the conservation values of old growth forests and wilderness areas. Those which are identified as having high conservation values will warrant interim protection under the national forest policy statement.

I have asked my portfolio agencies to assemble and assess the available data and I have invited my state counterparts, industry and unions to participate in this process. I have also authorised my department to seek substantiated advice from voluntary conservation organisations on those areas they consider to be of high conservation value, and it is my intention that this advice be rigorously assessed in advance of the next round of woodchip export licence renewals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Faulkner is saying that the minister half listened to him. This is really about process, is it not? It is about treating resources and environment separately. Does the minister's proposed review of EPIP offer any hope for resolution of this continuing process failure?

—I certainly have indicated that I will release a discussion paper which details a number of reform options in the area of environment protection impact assessment. That discussion paper is currently being developed by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency in my portfolio. It has been developed following extensive consultation with stakeholders, and I think it reflects the outcomes of ESD working groups and also the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. This paper will propose some changes to the legislation, which will allow the environment minister to determine when impact assessment is required and also enable him to place environmental conditions upon project approvals. Obviously that is going to be the subject of intense discussion within government, both state and federal, and I look forward to progressing that discussion paper after it has been released.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister would be aware of the launch by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training last week of the report entitled Green Jobs in Industry. Can the minister advise of the report's findings in relation to the potential for growth in ecologically sustainable jobs and what measures the government can implement to capture environmental export opportunities for Australian industry?

—The Green Jobs in Industry report was partly funded by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and was produced by the Green Jobs Unit—a joint initiative of the ACTU and the ACF. The report shows that new jobs and economic growth are just two of the benefits Australia can realise by focusing on preserving its environment in industries such as waste management, recycling, energy efficiency and ecotourism. Between 1988 and 1993, growth in environmental jobs was 38 per cent. The report estimates that the industry currently employs up to 400,000 Australians and by the year 2000 we can expect as many as 700,000 people in Australia to be employed in these industries. Of course, this will make a significant impact on unemployment while preserving our environment and generating economic growth.

PARA.TAB: The report was launched in Melbourne at Encore Rubber Technologies, part of the Pacific Dunlop rubber group, which is an outstanding example of the potential for green jobs. Encore Rubber Technologies recycles tyres to produce products which can be used for applications such as road construction, watering systems and pavers. To date, more than 50 new jobs have been created because of this venture.

Another example is Memtec, an Australian based multinational company in the water and waste industry, which has taken its revolutionary self-cleaning, continuous microfiltration system out to the world, created new markets and jobs employing more than 1,000 people. We have also had examples of the MFP in Adelaide developing new technologies in environmental remediation that are already attracting overseas interest.

Mr Deputy President, one very significant opportunity for growth in green jobs is the continuing development of exports of Australian environmental management expertise. Already the environmental management industry is valued at $200 billion worldwide, while the global market for environmental management is predicted to reach some $600 billion by the year 2000. To meet this challenge the government will provide $4 1/2 million through the industry portfolio to develop a coordinated environmental management industry strategy. This will include the establishment of the project development and technology diffusion network to harness Australia's environmental research capability, to overcome problems of scale and to promote exports.

This government is committed to supporting the development of this industry. We win in two ways. We win in creating economic wealth and jobs and we win in preserving a sustainable economy with a sustainable environment in Australia. It is an initiative that this government will pursue with vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the different recollections of the deployment of Australian military aircraft and warships during the gulf conflict coming from Mr Keating and Mr Hawke. I ask, in the interests of making sure neither of them is rewriting history: was advice sought from the ADF? When was it sought? What was the advice placed before the government? Were the minister's defence advisers present at the government discussions? Did the advice include the proposal to deploy FA18s?

—First of all, I welcome Senator Newman back to the front bench. I had a look at my CV this morning. It did not indicate that I was an adjudicator between past and current Prime Ministers, and I do not intend to be.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I hope that at the end of this question time I will not get complaints from opposition members that they did not get their questions in.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister at least provide us with the facts which I asked for?
—Mr Deputy President, I refer to my previous answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I ask: one, is the minister aware that logging is about to commence in the Kerr block near Balingup in the south-west of Western Australia? Two, is the minister also aware that the rare chuditch was caught during identification trapping carried out by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management between December 1992 and as recently as February this year? Three, is the minister aware that CALM anticipates that the logging of this area will yield over 4,000 tonnes of woodchips for export? Four, what amount of money is the Commonwealth spending on implementing the recovery plan for the chuditch? Five, does the Commonwealth intend to stop logging in this area to ensure that it does not further endanger or threaten the recovery of the chuditch and thus breach the Commonwealth Endangered Species Act 1992? Six, if not, why not?

—I am not aware of the details of the surveys conducted by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management in the Kerr block, but I am seeking advice on that issue. This particular forest block is outside the region covered by the joint Australian Heritage Commission and CALM regional assessment of national estate values in the southern forest region. The Kerr forest block is not within any area listed in the register of the national estate.

PARA.TAB: The chuditch recovery plan incorporates research and management actions in forest areas to ensure the continued survival of the chuditch. The recovery plan provides that `under current silviculture guidelines, habitat trees and suitable logs and stumps are retained during timber harvesting operations to provide refuge for hole-nesting fauna, including chuditch'. Research into the effectiveness of silviculture guidelines for chuditch conservation was recently commenced at Kingston and Warwick forest blocks near Manjimup, and this study includes pre-harvesting surveys on chuditch and monitoring for three years after harvesting.

From 1991-92 to 1993-94 the Commonwealth provided $250,100 to the chuditch recovery plan through its endangered species program. Commitment for 1994-95 is $85,400 and for 1995-96 is $75,000. Research indicates that the major threat to the chuditch may be predation by foxes, as increases in chuditch numbers have been recorded where fox baiting is carried out, including within forest blocks where timber harvesting occurs.

All woodchip licences include a condition obliging the exporter not to threaten with extinction or significantly impede the recovery of species listed under the Endangered Species Protection Act. I have recently initiated a program that aims to identify areas of forest containing high conservation values, including for endangered species, which may warrant interim protection under the national forest policy statement.

Should this process provide information relevant to the Kerr block, I will be providing that advice to the Minister for Resources for his consideration in the context of the 1995 woodchip export licences. In addition, I have asked the Australian Nature Conservation Agency to identify areas of forest in Western Australia that are critical for the protection of the chuditch. I will also take this information into account in preparing my advice for Mr Beddall on the next woodchip licence renewal round.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Anybody listening to the minister's answer to Senator Hill would be as stunned as we are on this side that he can say that the view of the then Acting Prime Minister as to whether to send Australian troops into a war zone was a mere detail on which memories could now be blurred.
—What do you mean the then Acting Prime Minister? Get your question right. Why don't you sit down until you get your question sorted out?

—All right—the view of the now Prime Minister as to whether we should send Australian troops into a war zone was a mere detail on which memories could now be blurred. Will the minister undertake to check whatever records are available, whether of the note taker, his own notes or any other records? It is very important that Australians know whether between 1983 and 1990 Labor members and ministers were working for and supporting a liar or whether they are now doing so. Who is the liar? Is it Hawke, is it Keating, or is it in fact both?

—There is no doubt about the decision that was made in November about sending Australian personnel and ships to support the action that was then proposed to be taken against Saddam Hussein. There is no doubt whatsoever about the unanimity with which that decision was embraced and espoused by all members of the government. There is no doubt about Mr Keating's commitment from the outset back in August to the need to respond in some appropriate way to the challenge to international order that was posed by Saddam Hussein.

PARA.TAB: Beyond that, I have nothing further to add. My own recollection of the particular exchanges that are alleged to have occurred does not extend to the particular views that were attributed to Mr Keating or the particular language that was attributed to him. There is no official record of that meeting because it was not an official meeting. Beyond that, I do not propose to pursue the issue any further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Evans says there is no doubt as to who said what, but clearly there is a doubt as to who said what. His Prime Minister is calling his former Prime Minister a liar. What we want to know is: is he telling the truth when he says that Hawke is a liar or is he not telling the truth? Senator Evans cleverly says that there are no official records. I was not asking what his damn memory of it was; I want to know whether he will go and check the records. If there are no official records, will he at least come back and say what records there are? Will he say whether he has got records and will he check them? At least let us ascertain that. Did Senator Evans have this meeting, and are there no records of a meeting, where people were deciding whether to send Australian troops into a war zone? Is he saying that there are no records, or is it that he just cannot damn well be bothered checking them?

—Apart from having a vulgar turn of phrase, Senator Vanstone also has a cloth ear. She was not listening to what I was saying. I did not say there was no doubt about who said what. I said there was no doubt about the decision that was made; there was no doubt about the unanimity of the commitment that was made and sustained to that decision; there was no doubt about Mr Keating's belief, throughout the whole course of this saga, that some appropriate action needed to be taken. Of course recollections differ about what might have been said and when. That is the matter in issue. My recollection does not extend to that particular exchange. I am not aware of any record or note that I may have kept of that meeting. I do not recall taking any note. If I have, it has been well and truly lost in the mists of time. I repeat: there is nothing to be gained by any further pursuit of this particular issue.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Immigration: Temporary Entry of Business People and Highly Skilled Specialists

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In August this year the minister announced that in light of the rapid growth of international economic activity and the increased globalisation of business, he would establish a committee of prominent business people, together with a representative of the ACTU, to review the temporary entry into Australia of business people and highly skilled specialists. I ask him now whether he would inform the Senate of the membership of the committee, whether it has been announced, and what its terms of reference are.

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. He is right—I did announce a few weeks ago that I would be setting up a committee to look at this area of policy, and this question gives me an opportunity to give the Senate an update of that process. I mentioned then, and I re-emphasise now, that over the past decade there has been an irreversible trend in world affairs—and that, of course, is the increasing globalisation of business. This is going ahead in leaps and bounds. With internationalisation and globalisation, ideas, skills and technology are moving around the world more quickly than ever before.

PARA.TAB: This, of course, has had an impact on the temporary flow of migrants into and out of Australia. This has also been increasingly reflected in our temporary entry figures. In the last financial year, for instance, some 13,030 temporary resident visas were granted to highly skilled specialists and business people. Most of these people, some 55 per cent, wanted to stay in Australia for less than 12 months. Only 0.3 per cent intended to stay in Australia for more than four years.

The policy objective for this government is to place Australia, through our rules and regulations in this temporary migration area, in a position to benefit both now and into the future. If we are going to benefit fully by this exchange, it is crucial that we ensure the smooth movement of key personnel into and out of this country. Policies such as those covering temporary migration need to be reviewed to ensure that they not only reflect the current demands but meet the emerging needs of the next five to 10 years. I say in this context that it is a two-way flow we are talking about here. An increasing number of Australians are living and working overseas for short periods. I think the trade potential that is available to Australia through those contacts—the cultural expertise and awareness of other countries—is going to be extremely important as we expand our export and trade base.

I am pleased to be able to announce to the Senate that a number of very highly qualified and experienced people have accepted my invitation to form the committee inquiring into the temporary entry into Australia of business people and highly skilled specialists. The managing director of Fujitsu Australia, Mr Neville Roach, has agreed to be the chair. I am very pleased that someone with his qualities, experience and eminence has agreed to chair this committee.

Other members of the committee are Mr Ross Baldwin, who is the Director, Asia Division, of the John Holland Group; Mr John Hall, Executive Director, International Banks and Securities Association; Mr Alan Matheson, International Officer, ACTU; and Ms Pauline Mathewson, Partner of Coopers and Lybrand. Clearly this is a committee with a wealth of practical experience of international business. It will be invaluable in assessing how our immigration procedures and policies can best respond to those imperatives I mentioned earlier.

The committee has called for submissions. The first advertisements were placed in the national media on the weekend. The committee hopes to be able to produce a discussion paper for public comment by the end of the year. The committee's terms of reference essentially are to assess how our policies and procedures are working; to look at our existing criteria; to look at labour market testing procedures, including labour market agreements; to look at our obligations under the general agreement on trades and services; and to look at our policy of achieving closer ties with the APEC region.

I am sure members will understand that this committee's work is also underpinned by the overriding need to ensure that employment rights of Australian citizens and permanent residents are paramount. I look forward to this committee producing a report later in the year. I hope that it will be the basis of further policy developments as we further address our regulations and laws in this critical area, an area which has the potential of ensuring that Australia does benefit to the maximum from the increasing globalisation of resources and skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and concerns the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, which is presently renegotiating a range of protocols for the export of meat products to the European Union. I ask the minister to guarantee that AQIS has not embarked on a campaign of having export and inspection protocols rewritten for the EU or for any other export markets, to include mandatory inspection by AQIS to protect the AQIS monopoly position as the supplier of export inspection services. Has this policy been locked in, in advance of the agreed Senate inquiry into AQIS which may recommend that many of AQIS's functions, including inspection, be privatised?

—The question is a nonsense. AQIS has not embarked on any action which, by implication from Senator Tambling's question, is political in respect of its own position with regard to inspection services. AQIS is continuing to deliver the same professional service that it always delivers on these issues. Decisions that AQIS takes are based absolutely on the sanitary and phytosanitary measures involved and have nothing to do with any extraneous issue.
