—Mr Acting President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister did not address the issue of the protocols that are currently under renegotiation with the EU and with other export areas. I ask him to address this question about the protocols that AQIS is currently rewriting; or is AQIS, once again, just conning the minister and embarking on another camouflage of in-house protectionism?

—This question is so garbled, even for Senator Tambling, that it is difficult to provide any kind of answer. The fact is that AQIS is constantly reviewing protocols. That is its job. As well as the protocols mentioned by Senator Tambling, it is currently flat out engaged in developing a whole range of vitally important protocols to do with the importation of feed grain into Australia. That is its job. I did answer the question, as I just said.
—Are they giving themselves exclusive rights?
—AQIS does this, as I have just said, in the totally professional manner it always does it. It is based on the technical sanitary and phytosanitary measures involved and on no other extraneous issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I note that, first, correspondence from CSL shows that at least until May 1986 it was mixing blood plasma from Australia with that from New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and various Pacific and South-East Asian countries. Secondly, an interview with a senior officer from CSL reveals that it knew that the incidence of hepatitis C in Hong Kong was very high and that Hong Kong was not testing for hepatitis C. Thirdly, a rare independent inspection of CSL's sterilisation of blood products showed that its technique was wanting. When CSL was sold, was an indemnity in relation to possible later legal action over hepatitis C infection—and I stress the next part—derived from plasma from countries other than Australia and New Zealand, offered or granted; or were the above facts made known to prospective buyers in the prospectus? If not, why not?

—With regard to the second part of Senator Coulter's question in particular, the public float of the Commonwealth's 100 per cent shareholding in CSL Ltd was conducted in line with standard commercial practice. The Commonwealth was not bound by the corporations law in undertaking the sale of CSL but at all times acted as if it were so bound. It conducted a detailed due diligence investigation over a period of some 16 months and registered a comprehensive prospectus with the Australian Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: This prospectus was prepared under the guidance of a due diligence committee comprised of representatives from CSL, the task force on assets sales and the Australian Government Solicitor, as well as prominent commercial experts—Arthur Robinson of Hedderwicks, the legal adviser to the CSL board; Potter Warburg and Price Waterhouse, business advisers to the Commonwealth; and Arthur Andersen as the investigating accountant.

Judgments regarding what was material as well as decisions on the level of disclosure in the prospectus were made by this committee, and all members subsequently signed off to the Commonwealth and the company that there were no material statements in the prospectus that were false or misleading and that there were no material omissions from the prospectus. That, comprehensively I think, covers the second point.

I make the further point that it is important to note that since the float of CSL in late May 1994 at a price of $2.30 the stock has traded on the Australian Stock Exchange at a premium and last night it closed at $2.52. I do not have anything with specific reference to the issue of indemnity that Senator Coulter raised. I think that deals with the second point, but if I can find some additional information relating to the indemnity I will get it from the Minister for Finance and provide it to Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. I take up his reply to Senator Brownhill on Monday in relation to the six New South Wales drought areas initially understood to be included in `exceptional circumstances'. Would the minister confirm that in the Department of Social Security television hook-up explaining the government's drought initiatives these six areas were included in the list shown on television? Has the minister therefore been less than frank with the Senate about how this information became public knowledge as his department was involved in the hook-up and he therefore must take some of the blame for the false hopes raised? Will the minister look again at exceptional circumstances as they apply to severe drought areas in eastern Australia?

—The answer to that question, of course, is no. In fact, in the House of Representatives yesterday—and indeed I will be canvassing the issue at greater length than question time gives me when the bills are brought in here for debate, hopefully on Thursday morning—the chair of the caucus committee, Harry Woods, made it absolutely clear what the basis of that social security exercise was. At this point I must say that I commend all the members of the committee, including its chairman, for the extremely positive role it played in this exercise. I stress that it was a Department of Social Security exercise—and quite properly. It was principally an in-house exercise for the purpose of alerting the department's own social security officers, and in an extremely short space of time, I might say. Those officers have performed minor miracles in getting this money on the ground as quickly as they are.

PARA.TAB: I indicated to the Senate today in question time how effectively the department's officers have handled this exercise in a very short space of time. It was an in-house exercise for the Department of Social Security to actually alert its officers, and that was the principal focus of these messages being beamed in on the ambit of the exercise required.

I have to say that clearly those efforts by the Minister for Social Security and his department were successful. The Department of Social Security is handling very effectively a brand new form of payment it has never had to make before and it is doing so in a matter of weeks. Something in excess of 3,000 applications, on my latest advice, have been processed just in the last 48 hours. That was the purpose of that exercise.

The New South Wales government was well aware that the list being discussed was a draft list. In fact just this morning I have seen some extraordinary statements that the New South Wales minister for agriculture made in the New South Wales Parliament which indeed must be the brassiest piece of misstatement I have seen in 16 years in this business. On the one hand Mr Causley—and he cannot have it both ways, although he is trying to—is criticising the federal government for the decision that it took on the 24 months out of 36 months criterion which, I inform the Senate, I took deliberately to advantage New South Wales.

As I explained before, if our existing criteria that were already in place for Queensland which stipulated two years of continuous drought had been applied, which is what the opposition's shadow minister was advocating should be done, one pastoral area of New South Wales would have received assistance. The second option the opposition's shadow minister put up was to give assistance to those suffering three years of drought out of five. I looked seriously at both of those proposals, and if either of them had made sense I would have adopted them.

I do not have a mandate on good ideas. In fact, I asked my staff to work out and tell me what the result would be if Mr Anderson's suggestions were adopted. His first suggestion would have resulted in one rural district in New South Wales receiving this assistance. His second suggestion would have resulted in six districts receiving it. I said, `That's clearly not good enough. Let's make this 24 months out of 36 to pick up the farmers who were droughted in 1991-92, had good crops last year and are currently droughted.' As a result of that decision, 15 districts in New South Wales have been assisted, instead of the one or six that the shadow minister would have had. Instead of complaining about it, those opposite should be applauding it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand that the minister's personal appearance before the Department of Social Security explanatory hook-up had been advertised. Where was the minister when such an important drought issue was being explained? Are we to understand that organising the Hobart uranium faction brawl was more important than the drought?

—I am delighted to have an opportunity to answer this question. It was a Social Security exercise. As far as I was concerned, it was for its purposes. That is the advice that I received, and it was correct. That exercise was for the officers of the Department of Social Security. There was no need for me to appear in it. I was approached and asked whether I would. My answer was that I would have done it on Monday, if it had been appropriate then, after I had seen a complete script for the teleconference. That was my response.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sandy Macdonald is just chasing hares on this. I stress again that the important thing that has happened—Senator Macdonald has not mentioned a word of this—is that yesterday this government paid over $5.4 million to the farmhand appeal. It will now be able to direct those resources away from the areas we are helping into the very areas he is talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Yesterday Senator Harradine asked me a question about Mr Bilney's comments after the ICPD conference in Cairo. I have a full answer to that question, and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

(1) Minister Bilney's remarks have been quoted out of context on more than one occasion. His statement after the Cairo Conference was that a strong case could be made for stabilising population in all nations, including Australia, but that in Australia, from the point of view of simple numbers, there was no urgency. In simple terms, this is an acceptance that population growth is seen as a global concern, a principle embedded in the Program of Action agreed at Cairo.

Australia supports the efforts being made by countries where population growth rates are outstripping growth in economic and social development and threatening natural resources, to stabilise population and to achieve that stabilisation through policies which integrate the wider provision of basic health and family planning services with programs to address gender inequality and social and economic disadvantage. As a developed country which has completed its demographic transition to slower rates of population growth, Australia's requirements are clearly quite different in nature and are currently addressed through a range of policies, including those on migration, environment, and family planning. I expect to be making a statement to Parliament on these matters shortly.

On the second statement attributed by the Honourable Senator to Minister Bilney, the Minister himself has said that if, as a result of the Government's trebling of aid for maternal health and family planning activities, he is misrepresented in words similar to those quoted by Senator Harradine, `then so be it'. Such a misrepresentation has occurred in this instance, particularly since this remark of Minister Bilney's was made some time before the Cairo Conference, and has been taken out of context.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—A resolution of the Senate on 22 September called on me to release the report from Mr Peter Valentine commissioned by my department into world heritage values and the deed of agreement between the developer, the Cardwell shire and the Queensland government after consultation with the Queensland government.

PARA.TAB: Last week I publicly released the full Valentine report which followed the release on 1 October of the executive summary of the Valentine report. I also released recent correspondence I have had on this subject with the Queensland environment minister.

In regard to the deed of agreement, I have spoken to the Queensland environment minister, who has advised that the Queensland government will consider the request. I am still awaiting a response on this matter. I table the material that I have released publicly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge receipt of those documents and thank Senator Faulkner for providing them, even though he was forced to do so by the chamber. I ask him to explain whether or not the Commonwealth has jurisdiction in that area in light of the letter which I referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer your questions at question time, if there are any. You can go and jump in the lake.

—I acknowledge what Senator Faulkner said so that it can appear in Hansard. There is an opinion from the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department indicating that Senator Faulkner and the Commonwealth government have no jurisdiction in this area. I have raised this with the minister in question time before and he has not yet come back to me with any sort of indication on whether he accepts that legal opinion, whether it is right, wrong or indifferent. If it is right, why is he still trying to overturn the Queensland government's jurisdiction in that area? It is obvious, according to legal advice given by the Commonwealth legal officer, that Senator Faulkner and his department have no jurisdiction in the area. If that is the case, why is he spending this sort of money? Why is he holding up this matter?

PARA.TAB: The Queensland government, apparently, according to Commonwealth advice, has jurisdiction. It has investigated the matter. It has gone through the environmental issues very carefully and has approved the project subject to environmental conditions and standards—conditions and standards which I think should be rigorously enforced. Having done that, it is a matter for the Queensland government. If Senator Faulkner does not agree with that, I would appreciate it if, as well as tabling the documents that he has tabled, he could give an explanation and an answer to that. He has obviously avoided it this time but I raise it again and hope that Senator Faulkner may have some interest in keeping the Senate informed about what is happening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the Gulf War and statements by the current and previous Prime Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is demeaning for the individuals concerned, Labor's two contemporary heroes, Mr Paul Keating and Mr Bob Hawke, to be publicly calling each other liars. Is it not degrading for the office of Prime Minister to be dealt with in this way? Is it not embarrassing for the ALP? We have the public spectacle of these two men, so arrogant, so proud, calling each other liars over a matter that was of vital concern to the security of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful and embarrassing. It is embarrassing not only to them but to the nation as a whole. It is important, therefore, to put on the record exactly what they have been saying about each other.

PARA.TAB: It all started a few days ago when the current Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in a typical way, claimed that the prosecution of the Gulf War had not been done competently. Basically, what he said, with all the benefits of hindsight, was that it should have been prosecuted to an end to Saddam Hussein himself. That is interesting in itself, but then we learn that it is to the background that Mr Keating did not even believe that Australia should be involved in the Gulf War. We learned that from his predecessor, the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. Mr Hawke, of course, in the book that was to make him a lot of money, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Paul Keating was opposed on the grounds that we did not owe the US such support.

He, in turn, quotes Keating as saying, `What has the US done for us?' So there we have Mr Keating going public, lecturing the world on how it should have prosecuted the Gulf War, when it seems that in his view we should not even have been involved because he did not believe we owed the US a favour. No understanding of the international dimensions of the conflict; no understanding of the UN role in it and the Security Council resolutions. He had a personal view; he said that we should not be involved, and so Hawke has recorded it.

PARA.TAB: What happened then was that Mr Hawke sought to put the record straight; to remind the Australian public of what he had said in his book. What was Keating's response on the record last night? He was reminded of what Bob Hawke had said, and he was asked the question, `Did you support involvement in the Gulf War or not?' The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said, `I did. That is just a straight lie.' In other words, he said his predecessor was publicly lying to gain himself the sale of some of his books.

What happened today? Mr Hawke decided that he would get back into the debate. What did he say about his successor, Mr Keating, the current Prime Minister of this country? Mr Hawke was asked, `What's your reaction? Are you a liar?' His answer was:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course I'm not and fortunately the record makes it absolutely clear and shows who was the liar in this matter. The record of that meeting of the 29th of November is as follows. Keating started arguing that we should not do anything: `What has the US ever done for us?'
As I said in question time, Mr Hawke went on to say:

Paul stop trying to rewrite history . . . Now stop it Paul, don't tell lies, the record shows that you're lying, get on with running the country, that's what your job is, not trying to rewrite history.
A little later in the interview Mr Hawke is speaking of the current Prime Minister, his successor, Labor's leader, in these terms:
He—
Mr Keating—
is incapable of telling the truth on the substantive issues.

How embarrassing! How degrading to see this spectacle continuing. But there is an important issue beyond that, and that is: who is telling the truth? We are entitled to know whether Mr Keating did believe that Australia should be a party to that international effort to stop Saddam Hussein in his invasion of Kuwait. So we asked the foreign minister, Senator Gareth Evans, who, we understand, was present at the meeting of the 29th: `Who was telling the truth?' Senator Evans said, `My memory is blurred.' This is the person who keeps detailed records of all these things. He knows what the truth is. The truth is that he is not prepared to get up here today and acknowledge that in fact Mr Keating's view was that we were not prepared to be part of the conflict.

PARA.TAB: If ever that was to be demonstrated, it was in the answer by Senator Robert Ray to Senator Newman's question today when she asked, `Who was telling the truth about the FA18s?' Mr Keating says he argued against them being committed. Mr Hawke says there was never any suggestion of them being committed. Senator Newman puts the question to Senator Ray, and what does he say? He says, `I am not going to answer the question.' He is not going to stand behind his leader. He is not prepared to stand behind Mr Keating. The whole thing is just an embarrassment to the nation as well as to themselves, and they ought to be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has just referred to the fact that in response to the question I asked Senator Robert Ray he had nothing to say whatsoever and totally refused to answer the question. I point out to you, Mr Deputy President, that he not only refused to answer it once; he refused to answer it twice. He reminds me of somebody whom we all know quite well: except St Peter denied his leader three times. I guess that, if I had had a chance to ask another supplementary question, Senator Ray would have denied his leader three times and would also have gone down in history as a welsher.

PARA.TAB: He is a welsher, but I recognise that he was in a very difficult position. He certainly was astride the proverbial barbed wire fence. Whatever he said was going to end up with egg on the face of the Labor Party; one of his leaders would have been going down the mine. His answer once and for all could have determined who was the liar or whether we have two liars. Unfortunately, though, for Australia, it is more important than that—serious though it is as to who is the liar who has been leading this country.

The Senate is entitled to the answers to the questions that I asked. Senator Ray, as the Minister for Defence, has the responsibility to account to this parliament for the deployment of Australia's forces. We need to know what the decision making process is in sending our forces to war. It is very blurred now after the different descriptions that we have had. From what we can glean from the newspapers reporting the battles of Hawke and Keating, it seems to have been a fairly ad hoc effort; and that was behind my question to Senator Ray.
Mr Keating has been acknowledging that he had no expertise but at the same time boasting that he led the discussion.

Where was the Minister for Defence in all this? Where was all the wisdom and the knowledge of the Department of Defence? Did Senator Ray prepare the proposals considered by the government? There is silence on that too. Did his military advisers provide advice and the options on that proposal? Did they sit in on the discussions? Were they called on for an explanation of any of the advice, if the ADF did give advice to the government?

No more significant or serious decision could be made by a nation than that which commits it to war. Unless the minister has something to hide, he cannot ignore the question I asked. He should be pilloried for refusing—not once, but twice—to tell the Senate what happened. The nation deserves to know that when it goes to war, the decision is based on a properly considered and rational basis. The minister's silence reflects the embarrassment of the government. His repeated silence, when he was given a second opportunity to answer, demonstrates that he is not prepared to support the Prime Minister's lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a situation where we have the former Prime Minister calling the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) a liar, and the present Prime Minister calling the former Prime Minister a liar, the Australian people have a simple choice. They have to decide whether they have been led by a liar as Prime Minister for nine years or whether they have been led by a liar as Prime Minister for two years. The balance of probability is that both were lying and that we have been led by a liar for 11 years, which may explain why the economy has been in such terrible shape.

PARA.TAB: We certainly know the extraordinary statements the present Prime Minister made while Treasurer—that there would not be a recession, that there would not be 10 per cent unemployment and that all the problems were just the bubbles dripping over the side of the glass of champagne. We know that was not the truth. So there is already some evidence clearly suggesting that at least one of those two men was not telling the truth during some of their periods in high office. We also know of the extent to which their words were their bond when they came to a secret deal about who would be Prime Minister when they were trading the prime ministership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did that happen?

—At Kirribilli House, as I understand it. The fact is that Australia deserves to have as Prime Minister someone whose word can be believed. It is a position of trust. We certainly have had problems believing both Prime Ministers over time; although no Prime Minister in my knowledge has ever handled the truth so carelessly as the present Prime Minister did in the run-up to the last election in that scare campaign which was mischievous, devious and disgraceful.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that we have evidence here from the people who know each other best—Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. They know more about each other's political activities than anyone else. The evidence they have supplied to the Australian people is that the other is lying. We do not need a great deal of evidence about this, but it is worth pointing out—and I think it was in Mr Hawke's book—that there was some suggestion that there may have been the need to have F111s in the gulf. I think that suggestion was made quite early on. Maybe Mr Keating is just being incompetent and does not know the difference between an F111 and an FA18. There are many instances where one could say that Mr Keating was not really—in Mr Hawke's terms—lying; he just did not know. He was too incompetent to understand, and this may be the problem here.

As Senator Evans said, when one has questions of recollection, it is very difficult to work out who is right and who is wrong. I must say that Senator Evans's enthusiastic determination not in fact to participate in history in any way, other than to squib it, is second only to Senator Robert Ray's exquisite withdrawal just in time to avoid creating an interesting offspring.

Senator Robert Ray said that his CV does not include resolving disputes between Prime Ministers and former Prime Ministers. Had he chosen to say what really happened, which would, of course, have involved backing one or the other, he may well have needed a CV, because I presume he would have been out of a job. It is a terrible thing that there is an inhibition on senators in this place to tell the truth because of the fear of retaliation from a Prime Minister whose history in politics has been one of standover tactics, political thuggery and get squares.

It is a shame that a man of such an honourable nature as Robert Ray should have been terrorised on an occasion from telling the truth to this parliament. He did not say he did not remember. He did not take that squibby approach taken by Senator Evans—he just said he did not want to intervene in this sort of dispute. That, I believe, is a disgrace. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow on from the remarks of my colleague Senator Michael Baume in relation to what Senator Robert Ray did in this matter. Basically, what Senator Ray has done is to say that it is better to say nothing than to lie. Basically, that is the approach he has taken in this matter. This, of course, is clearly understandable, given the difficulty in which he finds himself and the Labor Party, and his expectation of possibly becoming leader in this place after the current leader moves on to the other house. So, undoubtedly, Robert Ray is preserving his position.

PARA.TAB: But the simple fact is that the people of Australia will not be impressed by that sort of performance from somebody who aspires to be the leader of the government in this place. Clearly, he must have been involved in the discussions, as indeed was the current leader, Senator Gareth Evans. The question remains: is Bob Hawke telling the truth or is Paul Keating telling the truth? The people of Australia clearly understand that they cannot have it both ways—it is not a situation where both could be telling the truth. Clearly, there is a divergence in their stories.

Interestingly, despite Paul Keating's protestations about how gung-ho he was and what a big man he was in wanting to finish off Saddam Hussein, it now becomes clear that he did not want to get involved at all. It is really a little Jack Falstaff episode, of somebody trying to stab a dead body and saying, `Look what I've done. Aren't I great?' The simple fact is that the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was too wimpish in relation to this matter. When it all blew over and was a success, he wanted to be part of the success. The simple fact is that he is like a little bantam rooster who is too scared to have a fight but struts around the yard all puffed up, saying that he was the one who would have done the job properly.

Of course, he has been absolutely exposed by the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, who has shown, quoting from documents, that Keating has misrepresented the situation and only came into this after he made his gratuitous comments that Bob Hawke was lying. So Bob Hawke came back with proof to indicate that in fact it is the current Prime Minister who is misrepresenting the truth in this matter.

It is interesting that our current Prime Minister should be exposed in such a way in this debate because this really does raise the questions that my colleague Senator Michael Baume has been asking for so long in this chamber. Senator Baume has been seeking straight answers to questions such as: how did the Prime Minister afford to get into his failed piggery venture? How is the Prime Minister able to afford, after 25 years as a parliamentarian, to buy a $2.2 million house?

There is a whole host of questions that directly reflect on the integrity of this Prime Minister; questions that he fails to answer. I have a funny feeling that the reason he continually fails to answer those questions is that he would have a lot to hide and he is not in a position to be able to rewrite history, as he sought to get away with on this occasion.

Undoubtedly, the people of Australia are very concerned that somebody like Bob Hawke should come out of retirement and wave the documents around to expose the current Prime Minister for what he is—that is, a fraud and a person who is not able to tell the truth. I will quote from an interview in which Bob Hawke addresses Paul Keating, `The record shows that you are lying. Get on with running the country. That is what your job is—not trying to rewrite history.' What else has the Prime Minister been doing, other than running the country, if he can afford to buy a $2.2 million house?

The simple fact is that the Prime Minister has once again been exposed as engaging in shonky behaviour but, on this occasion, it is the former Prime Minister who has exposed him. It is to the shame of the Australian Labor Party that it has allowed itself to be led by these two individuals for in excess of 11 years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Finance (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to blood supply products distributed by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

SPEECH.PARA: Following yesterday's question without notice and the taking note of the answer, I was involved in an interview on ABC regional radio, which also involved Mr Jack Wood from CSL and a spokesperson from the Haemophilia Foundation of Australia. Interestingly, the Haemophilia Foundation of Australia said that it had repeatedly asked CSL whether it had mixed plasma from other countries with Australian plasma. It was always told that plasma from Australia and New Zealand only had been mixed; no plasma from other countries had been mixed. The foundation was surprised at the information I produced which showed that CSL clearly was mixing plasma from Papua New Guinea, the Pacific islands and South-East Asia with plasma from Australia and New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: In the same interview, Mr Jack Wood maintained that the practice had stopped in mid-1980, yet there is evidence, on CSL's own letterhead, which shows that it continued until at least May 1986. The practice was vigorously defended then as being absolutely necessary. At this time, the Red Cross Blood Transfusion Service wrote to CSL and said that, on the basis of CSL's refusal to change this practice and legal advice it received with regard to the liability which the Red Cross would have to bear, it was no longer prepared to use CSL blood products.

There is evidence to show that this practice did not cease in 1986 but continued. In 1984, an independent review by a senior officer of the national biological standards laboratory revealed that the sterilisation of CSL's blood products was inadequate. Despite the fact that this officer made proposals for improvement, it seems very likely that there was no change in these practices until at least December 1992.

The question is: when CSL was sold, was there an indemnity to cover the new owners so that they would not be liable in the event of a claim relating to blood plasma which came from mixed plasma—that is, containing plasma other than from New Zealand and Australia? If that indemnity was not there, were the prospective new owners, who would have bought shares in response to the prospectus, informed?

The fact of the matter is that the prospectus associated with the sale of CSL did not mention this practice. Indeed, the indemnities given at the time were very carefully crafted to provide an indemnity with respect to products made from Australian and New Zealand plasma but not plasma coming from other countries. Yet we know from quite a lot of other evidence that these sources were being used. Clearly, there is now a possibility of charges.

The minister dealt extensively with the processes by which the inquiry was conducted leading up to that sale but did not deal at all with either the indemnities or the prospectus. He concluded his remarks by talking about the share prices of CSL. We can only speculate about what the share price of CSL will be when the claims for contaminated products start flowing in.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, simply cannot take a trick on some of the key issues relating to his portfolio. Yesterday, in answering a question from Senator Short regarding concerns about certain appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal, the minister was at great pains to establish that appointments were made on the recommendations of an independent panel. I will quote part of Senator Bolkus's answer from yesterday's Hansard. He said:
The jobs were advertised, a list of people was assessed by a panel, that panel made recommendations to me and, in many of those instances, I accepted their recommendations.
Further on, he said:
. . . I have gone out of my way to ensure that the people appointed are independent of any influence from me and from the department.
And still later, he said:
I want to see people in these positions who are not beholden either to me or to the immigration department . . .
But today, in answer to another question from Senator Short, he let the cat out of the bag and, in the process, demonstrated his complete inconsistency.

PARA.TAB: Today, Senator Bolkus acknowledged that the three-person assessment panel recommending the appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal included, one, the former deputy leader of the Labor opposition in the Northern Territory and, two, a member of his own staff. That hardly constitutes a majority on the panel who could claim to be politically independent. Then, in a complete turnaround from his attempt yesterday to create this myth of independence, he cited the conclusions of the committee headed by Ian Macphee—that it was up to the government to make its own appointments in this area. The minister simply cannot have it both ways. It is clear that today, under questioning from Senator Short, he has been found out.

Senator Short showed that the minister's claim to independent advice is false. The minister now claims the right to make appointments as he pleases. Had the minister not been found out, he undoubtedly would have sought to perpetuate this myth of independence. As we have seen today, that is all it is—nothing more than a myth.

This is no better exemplified than with the appointment in South Australia of Mr Harry Alvizos as a full-time member of the Immigration Review Tribunal. There is no doubt that this is a mates-rates appointment if ever there was one. It mirrors what has been going on with other statutory bodies under this government's administration—the board of the ABC, to mention just one.

In this case, we have seen a job given to a person who was present at the minister's recent wedding—obviously, a personal friend of the minister—and who has no legal or immigration experience. According to the minister today, his claim to the job is based on the fact that he once taught Alexander Downer's children—no doubt a very important vocation but hardly a qualification for a full-time member of the Immigration Review Tribunal—and has some links with the Greek community. No doubt that is also commendable but it is not really the sort of experience of immigration issues and immigration law that would give him the expertise for this very important full-time appointment.

There was no evidence presented by the minister today that this appointment was recommended by the advisory panel or, indeed, that this particular appointee was even interviewed to determine his suitability for the appointment. So it is no wonder that in question time today the minister dissembled to the Senate in answering the question that Senator Short put to him on this particular appointment and the general procedures relating to appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal. He has certainly been caught out and severely embarrassed over the way he is administering his department—administering it, no doubt, as his own personal fiefdom rather than with the independence and responsibility that ought to apply to appointments of this nature.

As I said at the outset, the minister has completely changed his position in the space of 24 hours. Yesterday he was at pains to establish the independence of the advice he was receiving and, therefore, the fact that these appointments were beyond political interference. Today he has done a 180-degree turn and not only acknowledged that he has made these appointments himself but also claimed the right to do so. As I said, it was a complete turnaround and a complete inconsistency on the part of the minister. This is an utter demonstration that he is running this department as his own personal fiefdom, probably to the detriment of sound immigration administration in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
