The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—The Deputy President has received a letter from Senator Parer proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

The government's negligent administration of air safety regulation, particularly as it relates to the commuter and general aviation sections and its continued refusal to deal with surveillance and regulatory problems within the CAA as a matter of urgency.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Parer speaks, I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is vital to the future of Australia and to the future of the Australian aviation industry, which is one of our great industries and has been historically of incredible importance to a country the size of Australia. If ever there was an example of an incompetent and irresponsible government and an incompetent and irresponsible minister, it is seen in the mismanagement of the Civil Aviation Authority, culminating in the recent Seaview disaster.

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Authority has been a disaster waiting to happen, not because of individuals within the authority but because of flawed government policy and the inaction and ineptitude of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). In his reply to this debate, Senator Collins should address the following questions. Following one of the worst disasters in recent years when nine people tragically lost their lives, why was the minister swanning around the fields of Perisher with his best mate, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? He was not heard: he was up in Perisher skiing with the Prime Minister.

I understand today that Seaview has been grounded. What has happened is that the chief pilot's licence has been withdrawn which, in effect, grounds the airline. The question the minister should respond to is: why, if there are good reasons for the grounding of Seaview, has it taken 10 days to ground this airline? No-one has attempted to give the answer to that question.

The aviation industry is in chaos and in crisis because the mess that the government has created has resulted in a genuine and understandable fear of flying in the hearts and the minds of the general public of Australia. The minister could be excused if he did not know that anything was wrong, but he did know. My colleague John Sharp, the shadow minister for transport, told him over and over again in the House of Representatives. Not only that, the Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association met the minister on 24 March this year, and because there was no response of any sort and nothing had changed, they wrote to him again on 4 August 1994. The Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association pointed out in that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Since our meeting with you on 24 March 1994 we have watched with interest and concern the daily unfolding of . . . events concerning the Civil Aviation Authority.
The letter goes on to say:
At that meeting we expressed reservations about the ability of the . . .
Civil Aviation Authority—
to adequately monitor air safety standards.

The letter goes on. What happened? What did the minister do? John Sharp raised the matter over and over again. We had the licensed engineers, the LAMEs, as they are known, drawing his attention to their concerns, and they are the people who know what goes on within the Civil Aviation Authority and within the aircraft industry. What did the minister do? He did nothing. He did absolutely nothing.

PARA.TAB: As the minister has a shameful habit of finding a scapegoat he may well, with some justification, turn his attention to his equally accident-prone colleague Senator Collins, who presided over the structural changes of the Civil Aviation Authority from 1990. In fact, it has been said to me over and over again that the minister may well be reaping the whirlwind of what Senator Collins did. After all, what did Minister Brereton do with ANL? He fired the board when the heat was turned on him. In regard to aviation safety, he fired George Macionis, who was implementing government policy. That is what George Macionis was doing. So the minister seeks out a scapegoat.

Singling out an executive of the Civil Aviation Authority to take the heat off is no different from blaming the employees of Quintex for the activities of Christopher Skase. The ritual sacking of an individual is the typical coward's way out of attempting to shift the blame and has only served to highlight the minister's own irresponsibility. It was an ad hoc, knee-jerk reaction and no way to run an organisation as important as the Civil Aviation Authority. What is fundamentally wrong is the structure of the Civil Aviation Authority itself whereby the commercial operations of the authority are hopelessly mixed up with its regulatory and surveillance roles.

The opposition for some time has been calling for the regulatory arm of the CAA to be structured as a separate body directly responsible to the minister. This must be done as a matter of urgency. Properly managed regulation and surveillance are paramount to restoring confidence to both the industry and the flying public. Australia, until recently, has had an enviable reputation around the world as one of the safest places in which to fly.

This government and this minister have put that reputation at risk. It is a very serious matter. What it means in practical terms is that the general aviation industry will suffer a further major setback, having barely survived the recession we had to have. This is a minister who was a failure as a state minister in New South Wales. He switched to federal politics and, because he was a mate of the Prime Minister and, more recently—as I mentioned earlier—is now a skiing mate, he was given a senior portfolio. This was obviously not based on merit, but on mates' affirmative action. Maybe the 35 per cent rule applies to the mates of the Prime Minister.

So far, the minister has destroyed the credibility and potential viability of the Australian National Line. Now he has done untold damage to Australia's great aviation industry. He has lost the confidence of the industry and the flying public. For the good of the industry—and it is about time this government started to think about the good of the industry—and for the good of Australia, this minister should resign. If he does not resign, the Prime Minister should take decisive action—he prides himself on this, so I read in the papers in recent days—and fire the minister before he does any more damage to this industry. Finally, if this chamber were of a mind that this matter was as serious as I have portrayed, we would support a censure of this minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance canvasses basically the history of safety regulation during the course of this government. That is what I will address my remarks to in terms of the Civil Aviation Authority. I make the obvious point that any air disaster is a major human tragedy which all of us regret. We must constantly work, in conjunction with all the people involved in the aviation industry—and there are a great many entities in this business other than the regulator, the Civil Aviation Authority—to ensure that, so far as possible, these accidents do not occur.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that in terms of commercial aviation—that is, regular passenger transport operators—Australia has a safety record which is the envy of the world. There is no question at all that the Civil Aviation Authority has to take a significant amount of the credit for that, as a regulator, along with all the other components of that safety system, including very importantly the pilots, the air traffic controllers and so on. Indeed, I noted the appearance in Aviation Report of an address by Senator Parer. In that publication on 26 September this year—only a very short time ago—Senator Parer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The continued strength of our safety regulation system owes less to the government's policies than to the commitment and professionalism of not only the Civil Aviation Authority's staff but also of the people in the industry itself.

I am pleased that Senator Parer agrees with me—he led this debate—that it is a professional staff at the CAA. He acknowledged that less than a month ago to an aviation group. Knowing that Senator Parer is an honest man, I do not suppose he would attempt to have it both ways. That was what he told an aviation group less than a month ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said it a few moments ago, too.

—I am pleased to hear it. I have just confirmed what Senator Parer has said—namely, that the regulator, as part of that aviation safety system that we have in Australia, has to take a great deal of the credit for that enviable record. But that is in RPT operation. It is a fact that in light aircraft operation, charter and general aviation, our record in Australia is no better—and, I stress, no worse—than that in comparable countries. As I have said in this parliament on many occasions, that is not something anybody is satisfied with—and we all should constantly strive to make it better.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the impeccable record of major airline safety that we have in this country, which I hope to God we will continue to have, the statistical information that is available indicates comprehensively and very clearly that the rate of fatal accidents, whether we use the benchmarks of fatal accidents or accidents per hours flown, has remained relatively stable over the past 10 years. The opposition attempts to draw a constant line about the restructuring of the Civil Aviation Authority, which I might add was demanded from one end of the aviation industry to the other, including, as I said before, quite senior members of the coalition—and I refer to Senator MacGibbon in this respect; I regard him as a senior member of the coalition and, as I have acknowledged before, his expertise is noted. That restructuring was called for by everyone; there was no doubt it had to occur.

The remarkable thing is, and it is a great credit to the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority, that the record over that decade has remained constant. I have said publicly, as indeed have ministers before me, that we do not find it satisfactory that the situation with general aviation and charter has remained static. We want to see those figures come down, as I know do the United States and other countries such as Canada which operate comparable systems to Australia. We must strive to do that.

But, of course, one of the natures of the beast is that—and I am sure Senator Mac Gibbon would concede this in respect of light aircraft operation and these bald statistics that do not ever tell the whole story—when one is talking about private pilots and small aircraft, and particularly single engine aircraft, in respect of which decisions are taken to fly in conditions that should not be flow in, it is very difficult for any regulator to even attempt to bring down that sort of statistic. I can concede immediately that a far heavier responsibility—and I am sure that Senator MacGibbon agrees with this—rests with the regulator in respect of aircraft and companies that are operating RPT services. There is no question about that. The regulation should be as rigorous as possible in that regard and, if it is not, immediate action has to be taken to correct that.

There was a major restructure undertaken of the Civil Aviation Authority. It was long overdue. Throughout the period of that restructure, it was not the case that the government and civil aviation restructured in splendid isolation from the industry; in fact, the contrary was absolutely the case. It was done in the closest possible consultation every step of the way with the companies involved, with the staff of those companies and certainly with the unions. I can attest to that in terms of the number of meetings that I know of between the Civil Aviation Authority and me.

It is worth while to have a brief look at some of the history after the restructuring took place and the establishment of the CAA by the then minister for transport, Senator Evans. The CAA was subsequently under other ministers, including me. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation was created at the same time to provide the investigatory arm. A non-stop period of examination and review then took place in respect of aviation safety. It has not stopped since, and neither should it.

When I was minister I deliberately appointed one of Australia's most respected pilots, Captain Alan Terrell, to the board of the Civil Aviation Authority so that he could chair a safety subcommittee of the board. As all honourable senators know, that resulted in a report, a complete review, by Captain Terrell of the operations across Australia. The regard in which Captain Terrell is held by the aviation industry generally is beyond dispute; in fact, it never was disputed. That report became known as the Terrell report. The report contained a great many recommendations to the Civil Aviation Authority that had to be implemented in order to improve Australia's safety record, particularly in regard to general aviation and light aircraft operation, which we concede without question are the areas that need the closest attention.

I want to raise one important issue which is very relevant to the points that the opposition is making today in urging the government to make changes presumably in basic policy and direction. It has been correctly identified by a number of writers—Tom Burton among them; and I acknowledge this—that one of the central policy issues involved is the question of cost recovery. This is something, of course, which need not be and should not be, depending on the kind of cost recovery, contradictory to air safety because that should always remain the major focus of the regulator. The question of cost recovery is important in regard to safety regulation.

I have mentioned the Terrell report. I should also mention the safety regulation forum which I established in August 1992. The forum was held in Parliament House. It was set up to give everyone an opportunity to get into a room together—the LAMEs, who were just mentioned by Senator Parer, the light aircraft operators, the charter operators and the major airline companies—to examine the report to the Civil Aviation Authority. It was set up so that everyone could have an opportunity, fully and freely, to put on the table any concerns they had about the changes and the CAA's response to the Terrell recommendations and their implementation.

As I subsequently reported to this parliament, there were none. Everyone expressed satisfaction at that time with the rate of implementation of those recommendations that the Civil Aviation Authority was adopting. I again mention that to stress that there has been constant review and many changes made in this area. I have no doubt that there will need to be more changes in order to bring down the level of accidents that are continuing to occur—accidents not entirely confined to but particularly involving the general aviation and light aircraft area.

I raised the subject of cost recovery because it is a central policy issue that concerns the government. I noted an article today by Tom Burton, which I must say was reasonably balanced and accurate. There was one error in the article which I do not blame Mr Burton for as it was not an unreasonable assumption to draw when one works on the basis that all cabinet ministers are automatically happy at all times with all government decisions. I do not think that is a sensible assumption to draw. I refer to the central question of cost recovery which, of course, Minister Brereton himself raised in the House of Representatives yesterday.

From recollection, a paragraph in Mr Burton's otherwise fairly balanced article makes the point that when the government took a decision some years ago to fully cost recover for safety regulation, Mr Beazley and I were `happy with the decision'. I am not telling any state secrets—in fact, we issued a number of press releases during the course of the discussions that ensued; this is already a matter of public record—when I say that the facts are of course that that was not the case. The government did take a decision some years ago when all this was being put together to fully cost recover the cost of safety regulation. And I agree with Tom Burton: it is an important central issue in this debate. That was shortly after I became minister. The original cabinet decision, I might add, also included the decision to fully cost recover for search and rescue as well as for safety regulation.

The facts are, however, that Mr Beazley and I were not happy about that decision. Almost immediately, cabinet reversed its decision on search and rescue and that was put back where it should be—that is, on the public purse. A decision was then taken by cabinet to defer the implementation of the cost recovery decision by a full 12 months. Subsequently, when it went back to cabinet for what was a very robust debate, cabinet changed its original decision and implemented a 50 per cent regime for cost recovery. I might add that this is all a matter of public record and, indeed, statements were issued at the time by the government explaining it. But it is an important issue.

The simple reason I raise this issue is to indicate that it is an important issue and that the opposition, regrettably, has no clothes whatsoever to wear. I assume that Senator Parer was part of the discussions that formulated the policy of aviation which the coalition took to the last election. In relation to this issue, this was the only thing the coalition raised in its policy document. It had to do with cost recovery. Not only did the coalition advocate an aggressive stance on full cost recovery in its policy document it took to the last election; the coalition abandoned the transitional arrangements the government had made for the benefit of the light aircraft and general aviation area. The transition periods that we provided for that full cost recovery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Senator Parer is a little sensitive about this, is he?

—What we are debating today is a matter of public importance which refers to the government's neglect of administration of air safety regulations and its effect on the general aviation industry. What Senator Collins is saying has no relevance whatsoever to the matter of public importance.

—On the point of order: it is an absurd point of order to take. What I am discussing is an extremely important central issue about cost recovery—which no doubt the opposition must have some interest in—that impacts on, in my view, aviation safety, and I am comparing the opposition's stance on this, which obviously Senator Parer would like to hide, with what is in fact happening.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do not uphold the point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to correct the record: there is a problem, and I have identified it on at least five occasions in the last 15 minutes, that has to continue to be worked on; that is, the unsatisfactory safety record of light aircraft and general aviation. The coalition went to the last election—this was the only mention of aviation in its whole policy—with not only an aggressive stance on full cost recovery but the abandonment of the transitional arrangements we put into place. Those opposite boasted about the fact that, by pulling out 100 per cent of cost recovery in the aviation industry instantly they got into government, they would save the budget $20 million.

PARA.TAB: To the best of my knowledge, and this is the reason I raise this, those opposite have not changed that policy. I look forward—I say this in a constructive way because I agree with Tom Burton that this is a central issue—to hearing other speakers, perhaps Senator MacGibbon, because to the best of my knowledge the opposition has not changed or abandoned the policy it took to the last election of 100 per cent cost recovery for safety regulation from the Australian aviation industry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the general tenor of the matter of public importance debate this afternoon. I point out to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) that one does not prove safety by pointing to the number of inquiries which are being carried out or the efforts which are being made to improve safety. They are not in themselves objective measures of safety at all. Indeed, one could argue quite the contrary: the more inquiries one has into safety might be proof that the system is not working safely. If it were working safely, we would not need so many inquiries. I do not know that some of the arguments used by the minister hold water.
—It has to be constantly kept under review.

—Even if we look at the statistics, we may find that it may well be that one can hold for a time a level of safety free from accidents involving death or injury by good luck rather than by good management. Again, these statistics by themselves, when there is evidence of inadequate practice, are not in themselves a proof of safety.

PARA.TAB: When I look at some of the issues that were raised in the House of Representatives by Mr Sharp back in May 1994, I find that the response of Mr Brereton—I saw it on A Current Affair just before I came in here this afternoon—was that, if Mr Sharp had put these matters before him in some other way, they would have been investigated. When I read Mr Sharp's accusations, which are clearly set out in the House of Representatives Hansard, I find that there is plenty of information there for investigation. If Mr Brereton has not taken that on board and investigated it on the basis of those allegations, I think he is derelict in his duty.

I also find it rather strange that the head of the CAA has been sacked at a time when these sorts of accusations are being made in relation to a particular airline and, as I understand it, there is the lack of a definitive conclusion as to what caused the recent crash. One must ask the question: has Mr Macionis simply been used as a scapegoat so the minister can appease those who want some action taken in relation to the CAA?

The evidence was before the minister in the House of Representatives Hansard. The minister evidently did not take action. Mr Macionis has now been sacked in the absence of evidence as to precisely, as I understand it, what caused the Seaview aircraft to crash. The minister said he had lost confidence in Mr Macionis. But the question is: does his removal solve the problems arising from a whole range of serious allegations made about CAA? And many of those allegations are in the Hansard record.

Surely the removal of one person has little effect on what happens at regional airports around the country, such as at Wagga, where Western Airlines operates, and which has been criticised for its safety standards, or in New South Wales where Monarch Airlines and Seaview Lord Howe Island Pty Ltd are operating. All these airlines have been the subject of serious complaints about safety and operations, involving air inspectors, allegations of corruption, poor safety standards and breaches of licences and general airworthiness. These complaints have evidently not been investigated.

It appears that Australia's so-called good air transport safety record has been more by good luck than by good management, with the frequency of air incidents rising steadily in recent years. Records show that violations of controlled airspace have soared in recent years, more than doubling from 1987 to 1992 from under 300 to more than 700. From late 1991 to mid-1993 there were at least 27 incidents involving pilot misuse of radios. The Bureau of Air Safety raised serious questions about the CAA following the tragic Monarch crash in New South Wales in June 1993. The concerns about the CAA extend right across the board, with complaints from its own inspectors, commercial pilots, operators and aviation unions.

As late as April this year, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation was complaining again about the poor management and operation of the CAA in relation to violations of controlled airspace. The bureau's safety analysis manager, Paul Mayes, said the bureau had heard nothing from the CAA for three months following the publication of a report showing a dramatic rise in airspace violations. There are allegations of CAA inspectors receiving free flying hours with commercial operators in return for `fixing' problems airlines may have in meeting their safety and licensing obligations. There were also serious allegations of a CAA inspector attempting to intervene in a case involving the DPP and a particular airline and have charges against the airline dropped.

All in all, it seems as though the record of the CAA in relation to its internal operations is questionable and merits closer examination, as does the role of the minister and the way he has dealt with the CAA. Immediately after this MPI has concluded, I intend to seek leave to move a censure motion, to be put immediately, against Mr Brereton. I understand from what Senator Parer has said that the opposition will support that. I hope that we can deal with that matter quite expeditiously once this debate is over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is facing a crisis of enormous magnitude in the regulation of aviation in this country. For quite a while the Civil Aviation Authority has not enjoyed either the confidence or the respect of the aviation industry. Now the Australian public has no confidence in or respect for the authority. The people to blame for this are members of the government. They created the Civil Aviation Authority, they have directed it and they have managed it. The duplicity of the government in this regard ought to be exposed.

PARA.TAB: Over the years I have asked many questions in this parliament about the operations of the Civil Aviation Authority. I have always been told, especially by the minister at the table, Senator Collins, that it is an arms-length operation. It has the mystique of a government business operation. He has said, `We do not interfere with it in any way at all. We have nothing to do with it.' It is hands off the Civil Aviation Authority.

But what happens? We have a disaster like the Seaview incident, and the minister slips in and fires the person who he thinks is responsible—the head of the Safety Regulatory Group, Mr Macionis. The minister does not fire the chairman. He does not fire the board in the way he fired the ANL board a few weeks earlier. He does not fire the chief executive officer. He goes way down the ladder and fires a person who is responsible to many superiors in the chain of command.

The minister cannot have it both ways. He cannot say that it is an arm's length operation and then go right into the structure of it and exert control. The problem is that the government does not know where it wants to go. All it wants to do is to make money out of aviation so that the money it would normally put into aviation, in seeing that people travel safely, can be spent in other directions, by buying votes. The government has a duty to see that passengers who pay for a flight, who learn to fly or who have any aviation service at all, have that service provided to them safely, as it was for so many years in Australia. In short, anybody or any company who flies for hire or reward must meet minimum standards with respect to safety.

Aviation is not part of general transport activities. It is a special world all of its own. It is a three-dimensional activity, as I have told the Senate many times. It requires certain attitudes and certain approaches. There are more things to think about in aviation than making money. If there is a mechanical problem in flight, the pilot cannot get out and fix it, as is the case with a ship or a truck. I am not saying that the CAA must be run in a wasteful or inefficient way and cost the taxpayers millions. Of course, it has got to be run efficiently, but that is not happening.

The Labor Party has been blinded by the economic rationalist argument and the user pays doctrine. I have got an impeccable history of opposing the user pays concept in aviation from the time that the Labor Party introduced it. Senator Collins will affirm that on many occasions he has recognised that I am a maverick in this regard. But I do not walk away from my argument that there is a public interest in aviation and that should be funded from the public purse.

Members of the public are entitled to know when they board a 737, for example, to fly between Brisbane and Sydney, that they are going to get there safely and that the aeroplane is not going to fly through a school and kill hundreds of school kids. What I am saying is that the public interest is a broad interest; it does not relate only to the passenger who sits in the aircraft.

Since the formation of the CAA and the FAC we have seen nothing but turmoil because the CAA is directionless. The board must be blamed for this. The board sets the policy, not the detail. It is not able to do so because it does not have either the knowledge or the expertise in aviation. Members of the board are all very nice people and I think they have all got excellent life histories. They are estimable citizens but they do not know what goes on in the aviation world. What is needed on the board of CAA is people who have a deep knowledge of aviation and an operational involvement in contemporary aviation so that they know what is happening, or they need to have successful commercial experience. We have a board composed of people who have neither. Because the board does not have this, it cannot set priorities.

If anything goes wrong, the CAA has a standard response: scream for more people, scream for more money and scream for more draconian legislation. None of those responses is correct. They do not need any more people; they do not need more money; they need correct priorities to get to the task at hand. But they lack the professional knowledge to know what the priorities are. The senior management of the CAA does not have that professional knowledge, either, because its members are professional managers imbued with the belief that if you understand management, you can manage anything.

Let us look at the safety regulatory group. Overall, it has a confrontationist approach to the industry. Instead of consulting and advising the industry, it wants to slap heavy fines on it. It is obsessed with money. It costs about $2 an hour if you ring up a person in the group—about $160 an hour for advice. It picks on the wrong targets. It picks on the small fish rather than going after the people who really matter.

Senator Collins talked about the private pilots. I deplore stupidity and poor airmanship in any branch of aviation because it reflects on me as an old airman and on my friends who fly carefully and well. But as a legislator I really cannot legislate to prevent acts of stupidity. If someone wants to go and do something stupid and if I can counsel him against doing it, well and good, but I cannot really prevent him. But as a legislator, I can ensure that there are minimum standards so that the paying public can fly safely. That is not being done because the priorities of the Civil Aviation Authority are not directed in that way. It is too busy pursuing the rabbits. I have gone through that many times in this chamber.

The most difficult area in Australian aviation is undoubtedly the charter operators—the third level operators. That is the hardest area in which to make money. It is now loaded up with excessive Civil Aviation Authority charges. It is very difficult for these people to stay in business. But there are some characteristics that we know happen in this level of operations. The three common faults in this cash strapped area of aircraft operations are: overloading of aircraft, which is very common; an extension of duty times for aircrew way beyond the statutory level; and inadequate maintenance. The CAA ought to be putting its surveillance activities into that area in order to protect the travelling public.

Most of the aircraft that the charter operators are using now are very old. They go back to the 1970s or early 1980s—the piston driven twins. We have never operated aircraft as old as that for public hire in Australia's aviation history. It is only the turbo prop and the turbine aircraft that are reasonably new. We have got all sorts of evasions going on in the industry. There are pilots coming out of flying schools who want to get into the airlines. The requirement to get into the airlines is to do a certain number of hours with the charter operators. There are charter operators saying to these young pilots, `Pay us $10,000. We will give you an endorsement in a sophisticated aircraft and 30 hours or 40 hours, whatever you need,' and it is all under the lap.

With regard to the maintenance side, apart from the mandatory 100 hourly checks—and probably those are done, on average, at about 150 or 200 hours, way beyond the statutory limits—no records are kept. Aircraft are being flown with unserviceabilities which are blatantly against the law. Pilots flying for these companies are under pressure not to protest. They are forbidden to enter in the maintenance release the mechanical defects of the aircraft. When they have a problem in flight, they call up the company on radio and, in code or doubletalk, they say, `We've got a vibration problem, it's come back,' or something like that so that the company knows that the unserviceability has come back. But when it lands, there is no entry in the logbooks.

In my home field of Archerfield a couple of years ago, a twin flew into a hangar, quite tragically. Upon inspection, two logbooks were found in the aircraft. There was a logbook for the pilot which recorded accurately his flying hours so that he could be paid, and there was a maintenance logbook which grossly understated the hours flown. The case for intense surveillance in this area of the industry is overwhelming. With the limited resources that the CAA must have, that is where its priorities should be but that is not where they are going. They are not going there because the CAA does not know the realities of life in aviation in Australia today.

There was the terrible example of the Monarch crash where the field inspection officer, the surveyor on the ground, said, `This company should not operate; it's not good enough.' Through cowardice or incompetence, his professional advice was not accepted. He was overridden further up the chain and nine people died. Goodness knows what went on in the Seaview case. I will not comment about that. Again, there are grounds to believe that the person on the ground who made the judgment was overruled by a higher authority and that company got an RPT licence.

What we need in the Civil Aviation Authority is professional skill and professional judgment. We have not got that. We are not getting it from the government. Tragically, we are going to see a run-down in standards, with the paying public being put at risk while the present system continues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather sad that, as a result of deaths in aircraft, we are discussing this matter today. It is rather disappointing that people make political points, although I do not deny them the right to do so and I believe they should speak out if they have a concern and if they have some views about how these things can be corrected.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the election of the Labor government, of course, we had the Department of Civil Aviation, which was then changed so that we had the Federal Airports Corporation and the CAA. One looks mostly at commercial areas and the other looks at aircraft safety and the safety of associated services and facilities. It is quite interesting to read what the CAA said during an investigation conducted by a standing committee in 1989. I believe Senator Parer was a member of that committee. The CAA said, very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the prerogative of the Government and Parliament, within their respective areas of power and responsibility, to set the financial basis and framework within which the CAA is to operate. The Authority's responsibility is to conduct its affairs as efficiently and economically as possible within the framework set for it by the Government and Parliament.

That is a very clear statement with which I agree. The government cannot be on every aeroplane and in every airport facility. The government cannot be everywhere. It has to rely on experts who are employed by the CAA to see that systems are in place which guarantee to the greatest extent the safety of the people who fly in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting to hear Senator Parer make a comment today on the question of dividing up certain responsibilities within CAA. In the 1989 report there was a dissenting report by Senator MacGibbon, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: I record my dissent from the view of my colleagues that there should be no amalgamation of the FAC and CAA.
The proposition was that there could be an amalgamation. Further on he says:
Secondly, the users must have the inalienable right to say what they want to buy.

I do not want to be unfair to Senator MacGibbon, but that appears to me to mean that if there were certain requirements to guarantee safety or standards in the operation of aircraft, those airlines should be able to make their own decisions about certain things. If they require CAA to carry out surveillance they would pay CAA to do that.

PARA.TAB: One of the matters raised is the question of cost recovery. It is very clear that prior to the establishment of the CAA—when the DCA was in operation—there were methods of taxation and charges, even though there may be some alteration to the way in which they now operate.

The minister has responded fairly quickly. He has made a submission to the government in relation to the funding of public benefit. When one talks about public benefit and trying to conduct aircraft movements in safety, one has only to look at the attitudes of companies or organisations that fly aeroplanes or run airlines small and large. For instance, the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia told the committee on that occasion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is the continuing saga of the Rescue and Firefighting Services at general aviation airports—a service which is unnecessary, unwanted and long recognised as a clear case of over provision of service.
As far as that organisation is concerned there should not be firefighting equipment there at all.

PARA.TAB: Here we have criticism because safety is not being guaranteed. On the other hand, we have people suggesting that we are conducting ourselves in a way that creates more requirements for safety than are necessary. In 1989 the Bankstown Airport Chamber of Commerce said:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1979 the Unites States and Australia entered into a bi-lateral airworthiness agreement essentially to avoid duplication of design standards, to stop the duplication of tests and quality control. Unfortunately the essence of the agreement has been and is being totally ignored by the civil aviation authorities.

These aircraft were given a certificate of airworthiness in America, but when they came out here they were being subjected to tests that required an audit by the Civil Aviation Authority to see whether they were fit to fly. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance proposed by the shadow minister for aviation, Senator Parer: namely, the government's negligent administration of air safety regulations. It is a matter that needs some airing because the coalition warned the government months ago about the tragic events of the past two weeks.

PARA.TAB: Our general criticism of the government's inept handling of the whole of the aviation portfolio goes back to even before the pilots dispute and the Labor government's bungling of that particular issue. The question of air safety in Australia is something that the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, ought to have been across before he read last weekend's newspapers. He is quoted in Hansard as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . operational deficiencies are evident in the records of the Civil Aviation Authority—records that I have had the opportunity of studying in part over the course of the past 48 hours, but not before that time.

That means that this Minister for Transport, in response to an aircraft disappearing with nine people aboard seven days before—and in spite of criticism and questions about whether the aircraft was safe, and whether it had been or had not been checked by the CAA—took seven days to bother to pick up the newspapers. How times have changed. Clearly the minister is tiring of the portfolio or is incapable of handling the pace. It was only in May, in response to a number of questions raised by Mr Sharp in the other place, that Mr Brereton made this touching comment:

I have had this job as Minister for Transport now for four months and I will tell honourable members this: no one will put more energy into guaranteeing the high standards of aviation safety in this country than I.
He has failed. He has failed dismally. He should resign or he should be sacked.

PARA.TAB: Yet the minister admits now, five months later, that it took him seven days to bother to read CAA documents relating to the matter. The issue of air safety has been one of continuing questioning by the coalition. Over recent years we have highlighted the debacle concerning radar contracts. Hundreds of thousands of dollars were wasted by the CAA because it had to go back and redo the whole radar contract system.

There is still a dispute over the new provisions for air space management around Australia. We have a current dispute between the CAA and the Bureau of Air Safety over the number of violations of controlled airspace. BASI expressed concern about dangers that were starting to exist in air space management; yet the CAA said, `She'll be right'. The Minister for Transport is responsible for this area.

The shadow minister for transport has been asking Mr Brereton for some time about shonky airlines. The honourable member raised the specific issues of Seaview Airlines in parliament in May. Mr Sharp said:

SPEECH.PARA: A pilot flying for an operator, Seaview Aviation, which flies from the north of New South Wales to Lord Howe Island, claimed that he was sacked on the spot for refusing to fly a plane in which the auto pilot was out,
the same problem in the incident with the Monarch plane.

About an hour ago—14 days too late—the minister revoked Seaview's licence. I would have thought that if he were a minister who was on the ball he would have been a bit quicker in moving on something like that. In May the shadow minister said the following very prophetic words:

the Monarch air crash is simply the visible tip of a very large and potentially very destructive iceberg. The CAA has obviously fallen down on its prime responsibility to conduct safety regulation of civil air operations in Australia. It has no excuse. The CAA has been given the teeth. The problem is that it is not using them.
Might I add again that Minister Brereton is in charge of the CAA.

PARA.TAB: In the light of this most recent plane tragedy the coalition has continued to ask questions, but again the answers have not been forthcoming from the minister. The Minister for Transport has said that, living under the flight path of Kingsford Smith airport, he has a particular relationship with airports. Those of us who use Kingsford Smith airport on a regular basis know only too well the trouble and the safety risks that Mr Brereton has exposed us to and the unnecessary cost that he has subjected the commuter airlines to in respect of that airport.

His opposition to the development of the third runway is well known. He lobbied hard to stop its construction. With others from the Right wing of the Labor Party he forced expensive consultation processes. Now that the third runway is finished and ready to be used Mr Brereton is refusing to have it opened. We have to wait until there is a vacancy in the schedules of Mr Brereton or Mr Keating to fit in with the opening of the airport to have the ceremony that they obviously want.

In the meantime, delays at Sydney airport of 40 minutes or more are common. Sometimes we have delays of an hour, sometimes two hours. One commuter airline advised me that these delays are costing airlines something like $1,000 an hour for one Saab aircraft on a holding pattern. Another airline operator advised me that it cost him an additional 7.5 per cent in operating costs to fly to Sydney—an additional $375,000 a year. No small business can operate with those burdens; burdens that have been put on those commuter airlines by Mr Brereton in not getting on and opening the third runway.

Air traffic controllers have sought to have the third runway opened because it would ease their job and make landings and take offs at Sydney safer. Here again we have another safety issue. Aircraft go round and round in circles at Sydney airport for hours. This leads to more problems and more danger of having a crash

Given that government contribution to air safety has been reduced from $80 million to about $58 million, and given that the industry has to foot the difference, it is in the government's best interests to ensure that those in the industry are allowed to operate in the most cost-effective way possible. Minister Brereton is not allowing even that to happen. He definitely stands condemned. Keeping planes in the air in holding patterns is no way of ensuring a viable or safe industry.

There is no point in having reviews of air safety if the recommendations of those review panels are not enacted. Tom Burton's article has already been referred to by Minister Collins today. We should look at Mr Burton's article, which talks about the CAA and the problems there. The government has been on full notice of the problems that have happened during the minister's time and at other times. This government has been negligent and this minister should resign. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is agreement on two things here today—that the crash of the Seaview Aero Commander was a tragedy and that the deaths of nine people was a tragedy. There is also agreement that the Civil Aviation Authority's operation and safety surveillance needs to be improved. Where there is divergence, where there is disagreement, is on the claim that the government has refused to deal with these problems. The actions of the government and the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) clearly refute this claim.

PARA.TAB: Before I outline what the government has done, I hasten to point out that the Australian air safety record is the best in the world. This view was shared by Senator Parer when he referred to it in an address to aircraft engineers just 19 days ago. It is further worth noting that the Australian air crash rate has remained largely unchanged over the past 10 years. For instance, contrary to statements made earlier this afternoon, over the past five years the number of air accidents in all flights, except sports flights, has been as follows: 250 in 1989; 278 in 1990; 264 in 1991; 237 in 1992; and 261 in 1993. There have been only three fatal crashes by commercial aircraft in the 1990s.

The CAA was set up by the government in 1987 to carry out several roles. These included the responsibility for setting air safety standards, day-to-day regulation of the aviation industry and operational control of air traffic services. Over the comparatively short life of the CAA, it has become clear that there are flaws in its operations. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report on the Monarch accident, which report was produced after the tragic crash in June 1993, made a number of criticisms of the CAA and recommended improvements to the operation and administration of the organisation.

The Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, acted immediately to deal with these criticisms. He announced a major safety strategy review aimed at re-examining the entire field of Australian air safety. He oversaw the implementation of the national aviation safety surveillance program. It provides an ongoing assessment of the safety level of our aviation industry. Most importantly, the minister announced a package of eight safety regulation measures to ensure that the risk of future air safety problems was reduced. The details of these measures would be well known to senators. They were raised in question time yesterday and Senator Collins has also referred to them today, so I will not go over them again.

I would like to make two points. The first is that the government has clearly recognised the operational flaws of the CAA and has put in place a strategy to deal with them. An important part of this strategy has been the setting up of a parliamentary inquiry into the commuter and general aviation sectors of the Australian aviation industry. Honourable senators would note the similarity in the terms of that inquiry and the wording of this MPI.

A parliamentary inquiry is not nothing; it is not a small thing. I fail to see how the moves by the government to thoroughly investigate the issue of air safety through this inquiry can be said to show negligent administration or a continuing refusal to deal with the problems. There is no doubt that the government has moved decisively to meet the problems and to maintain Australia's good air safety record. The government has shown a willingness to adapt to the changes in the aviation industry with deregulation, at least on a financial level, as well as a commitment to increase the effectiveness and efficiency of Australia's air safety regulations.

Since the measures were announced, there has been another crash. The Seaview Aero Commander crashed a week ago last Sunday. Like all accidents, this accident will be investigated independently by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and a report will be made available to the public. All honourable senators would agree that this is a tragedy, and this has been expressed in this MPI before the Senate today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time available to me this afternoon I would like to raise two issues in the context of air safety. The first issue concerns the impact of deregulation and privatisation on air safety, and the second and related issue concerns the elimination of air traffic control from 80 per cent of this country. The continuing push by this government for deregulation and privatisation in the aviation industry and elsewhere has pushed the safety thresholds to their absolute limits.

PARA.TAB: While the government has, in part, acknowledged the need for action in this area by establishing an inquiry into the adequacy of air safety standards, it is interesting to note that Dick Smith, the former chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, has recently raised serious concerns about an inherent conflict between the various responsibilities of the CAA. On the AM program on ABC radio on 21 July 1994, Mr Smith stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with the CAA is that its main direction is to put primacy to safety but at the same time the airways side must make a profit as a government business enterprise. The reason they conflict is not so much the profit, it is that they're two totally different things. Running an air traffic control system and making a profit for the government is one thing; regulating aviation safety and airworthiness and pilot standards is totally different. It's a totally different situation. You have a board there which is competent at running a business but does not have the experience to be responsible for the safety of aviation in this country.

This is indicative of problems in many other sectors of the economy where the push for commercialisation and the imposition of cost recovery are eroding service standards in favour of economic efficiency.

PARA.TAB: The second problem, which is related to the first, is the elimination of local air traffic control from large sections of the Australian continent. In my state of Western Australia, it is best evidenced at Karratha airport, which has very substantial air traffic due to the many resource projects in the region and the decision by many of the companies working in the region to use fly-in and fly-out staff who rotate on a weekly basis. In addition, there are many small and large helicopters that operate from Karratha airport to service the offshore oil industry.

This problem was pre-empted late in 1990 when the elimination of air traffic control was first mooted. The issue was discussed on A Current Affair on 27 November 1990. Mr Neil Mitchell, a flight service officer, when asked how Australia's safety record compares with that of the rest of the world, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, Australia has a very high safety standard, but safety comes at a cost and, unfortunately, this is becoming the equation nowadays.
Peter Wilkinson in summary then stated:

If the Civil Aviation Authority's plan is accepted, pilots in G-air space will only have warning of other aircraft in the area, if the two pilots are able to talk to each other directly by radio. The trouble is, when you're talking on the radio yourself, you miss other reports and messages, that's if they've been given in the first place.
This is certainly a matter of public importance and I am pleased that Senator Parer has provided me with the opportunity to raise some concerns on this issue. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Coulter)—by leave—put:
That the Senate censures the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, for his negligent administration of air safety.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTORAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Schacht, on behalf of Senator Faulkner) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to repeal the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, to amend the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is to amend and repeal those parts of the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory self-government legislation which are no longer appropriate now that the A.C.T. Legislative Assembly has enacted its own electoral legislation. The bill provides for transitional arrangements for dealing with disputed qualifications of members of the Assembly and casual vacancies in the period up to the next Assembly election on 18 February 1995.

These provisions arise from a review of the A.C.T. electoral legislation, which was conducted by the A.C.T. Administration and my Department after self-government was granted in 1989. That legislation, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, applied the modified Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to the Territory and provided for the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct Legislative Assembly elections.

The A.C.T. Legislative Assembly has now passed its own comprehensive electoral legislation, some of which came into effect on 25 August 1994. The A.C.T. Electoral Commission has been established, its functions and powers determined and the procedures for Legislative Assembly elections laid down in the Australian Capital Territory's Electoral Act 1992 as amended in 1994.

The effect of this is to provide parallel mechanisms for running A.C.T. elections—the Commonwealth legislation and the A.C.T.'s local legislation. The Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 still serves as a `constitution' for the Territory. Some of its provisions need amendment to permit the transition from the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 to the Electoral Act 1992 of the Australian Capital Territory.

The Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 on the other hand needs to be repealed to make way for the A.C.T. legislation, with the exception of Section 16, saving that provision which allows Division 2 of Part XXII of the modified Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to apply. This enables the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory to continue to determine issues of disputed qualifications and casual vacancies in the period until 18 February 1995, after which the A.C.T.'s local electoral laws will commence to apply.

Item 1 of the Schedule to the bill deals with subsection 48(1) of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988. That subsection currently refers to subsection 10(7) of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, which is repealed by the bill. Item 1 brings the Commonwealth's self-government legislation into line with the Electoral Act 1992 of the Australian Capital Territory in respect of the circumstances following the calling of an extraordinary general election by providing that an ordinary general election shall not be held within 6 months of such an extraordinary general election.

Items 2 and 3 of the Schedule amend the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 by omitting subsection 67A(2) and subsection 67C(2) and substituting a new subsection 67C(2) to reflect the fact that the Australian Capital Territory now has its own `electoral enactment', the Electoral Act 1992.

Items 4 and 5 provide for the definition of `registered party' found in the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 and in the Electoral Act 1992 of the Australian Capital Territory, to apply respectively before, and on or after 25 August 1995.
The bill also omits redundant provisions in the Commonwealth's self-government legislation.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE NEW SOUTH WALES POLICE SERVICE (ACCESS TO INFORMATION) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
Motion (by Senator Schacht, on behalf of Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: In June this year the Premier of New South Wales requested the assistance of the Commonwealth Government for the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service. This Government considers that it would be proper for the Commonwealth to provide such assistance as it can in the fight against police corruption.

Allegations of corruption within an Australian police service constitute a serious threat to the integrity of the criminal justice system and the safety of the community, not just in the particular jurisdiction, but nationally. All jurisdictions have increased their cooperation in national law enforcement initiatives in response to the national and international threat of organised crime. The corruption of one police agency therefore has the potential to compromise the national law enforcement effort and to jeopardise international law enforcement cooperation.
Such assistance as can be provided without the need for amendment of legislation is, of course, already being provided.

Part of such assistance should be the provision of any evidence the Commonwealth might have of or in relation to such corruption. In some cases, the Commonwealth can provide relevant information without legislative change being necessary. There are, however, two important instances where specific legislative authority is necessary before information can be communicated to the Royal Commission.

These are in relation to information obtained under the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. In relation to the latter, in some circumstances it may prevent New South Wales law enforcement agencies, as well as the Commonwealth, from providing relevant information to the Royal Commission.

The matters being inquired into by the Royal Commission include allegations of corrupt activity by police. By their very nature, such allegations of corrupt activity may include secret transactions involving cash payments or other financial benefits.

The amendments to the Financial Transaction Reports Act allow the Royal Commission into the Police Service of NSW to be treated as a law enforcement agency under the Act. This will allow the Director of AUSTRAC (the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre) to pass financial transaction reports information to the Royal Commission.

The same conditions of access to Financial Transaction Reports information and use of such information will apply to the Royal Commission as currently apply to the Australian Tax Office and to the various law enforcement agencies which currently have access to AUSTRAC's data.

Despite knowledge in the community that law enforcement agencies use telephone interception as an investigative tool, the telephone is still a major means of communication between criminals. Information relevant to matters other than those the specific subject of a warrant under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is often obtained by law enforcement agencies. That Act has strict rules about to whom such information may be communicated. As the Act presently stands, no intercepting agency (including such New South Wales agencies as the Crime Commission and the Independent Commission Against Corruption) could pass relevant information to the Royal Commission.

The proposed amendments provide for relevant lawfully obtained information to be communicated to the Royal Commission. The Royal Commission will then be able to use that information only for a purpose permitted by the Act. This will include purposes connected with an investigation by the Royal Commission under its terms of reference or a prosecution which has arisen out of an investigation by the Royal Commission.
The Royal Commission will not be able to apply for warrants authorising interceptions under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act or itself conduct telephone interceptions.
The amendments will have no significant financial impact.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The references to provision numbers in the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) in this speech are, unless otherwise indicated, references to provision numbers as they were before the renumbering of the Migration Act 1958 on 1 September 1994.

This bill, through its proposed changes to section 35 and 36 of the Act (which were renumbered in December 1989 to become sections 87 and 88 respectively) seeks to restore to those sections the effect they were thought to possess prior to the decision of the High Court in Chu Kheng Lim v Minister for Immigration Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in December 1992.

It was this decision which gave rise to the commencement of claims against the Commonwealth for compensation for wrongful imprisonment of a number of unauthorised boat arrivals who are usually referred to as boat people. Prior to this decision no one had questioned the use of section 36 of the Act (from December 1989 to September 1994 numbered as section 88) to detain the unauthorised arrivals in question. Indeed, those sections were not challenged in the Lim proceedings.

Section 36 of the Act deals with people who come to Australia by boat without prior authorisation and who may be kept in custody until the departure of the vessel from its last port of call in Australia. Up until May 1991, unauthorised boat arrivals of this kind were detained in custody under this section while their claims to remain in Australia were assessed.

In the Lim case other aspects of migration legislation involving boat people were challenged and doubt was subsequently cast upon the lawfulness of detention for a number of boat people under section 88 once it became apparent that the boats on which they had arrived would never depart Australia. This doubt turns not on the central issue of unauthorised arrival, but on the understanding that the vessel be expected to leave Australia on a further, outward and ongoing voyage.

In this instance, the Commonwealth acted on a mistaken view of what the law was, believing—like all other concerned parties—that its detention of boat people was lawful. It is significant that no-one, apparently including the boat people themselves—and their legal representatives—saw any reason to question the lawfulness of detention on the basis none of the vessels on which they had arrived had ever left Australia. Should that custody prove to have been unlawful, it is as a result of an innocent and technical breach, and no more.

This has created an artificial situation when the fact of the matter is that the boat people did arrive in Australia unlawfully, and their detention was based on the understanding of the provisions of section 36 (section 88) by the Government and the Department at that time. Nevertheless, actions for damages have been lodged by some 88 of the boat people who now maintain that their detention under section 36 (section 88) was unlawful.

New provisions to detain unauthorised boat arrivals came into effect in May 1992 with the commencement of Division 4B of the Act. These provisions, under which the boat people have been detained since May 1992, were found by the High Court in the Lim case to be constitutionally valid. However, at that time the High Court cast doubt upon the use of section 88 to detain boat people. As a consequence, section 54RA was enacted in late December 1992 with the support of the Opposition. This section extinguished the right of action for damages for false imprisonment for persons found to have been unlawfully detained under section 88 prior to their transfer to custody under Division 4B of the Act, replacing it with a statutory right of action limiting to one dollar per day the damages payable.

As the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Honourable Gerry Hand, declared to parliament, ". . . It is essential to counter the possibility of significant damages claims. It would be absurd for the Australian taxpayer to be expected to underwrite compensation payments to people who arrived here without authority and who have been detained on reasonable grounds while their claims to remain were exhaustively examined".

A case challenging the constitutional validity of the compensation scheme established in section 54RA—and I would repeat that the compensation scheme in section 54RA was regarded as constitutionally valid when it was established—is yet to be heard by the High Court. The main ground for challenge is likely to be that section 54RA breaches section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution, in that it involves an acquisition of property by the Commonwealth otherwise than on just terms. A number of High Court decisions since section 54RA was enacted on the ambit of the "just terms" requirement in the Constitution have raised doubts whether the limit on damages to one dollar per day is constitutional.

As I earlier remarked, the amendments proposed seek to reflect the Commonwealth's previous understanding of sections 35 (section 87) and 36 (section 88), and their operation. Legislative amendments of this kind can be classed as "curative", which retrospectively correct defects discovered in the law or its administration, and restores what was previously thought by all parties to be the status quo.

Recent High Court judgements involving the "just terms" requirement of our Constitution have suggested that this approach of "curative" legislation is an avenue available to the Commonwealth. Indeed the courts, including the present Chief Justice of the High Court, have emphasised that it is always open for parliament to correct developments in the law, other than in constitutional matters, where those developments do not accord with parliament's intention.

The rationale for curative legislation is the strong public interest in the proper functioning of government. Occasional defects in administration or statutory drafting are inevitable, and it may be fairly argued that a law which seeks retrospectively to cure innocent defects does not take away rights, but merely gives effect to administrative action already taken. Action, it should be noted, which was previously assumed by all relevant parties to be valid.

This bill—the No. 3 bill—is substantially identical to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 introduced to the Senate on 8 June 1994. The Government has introduced this bill with the intention of placing the Commonwealth in the strongest possible position to defend the claims for compensation. The bill seeks only to achieve the same effect as what was intended by the enactment of section 54RA—to prevent a possible windfall of a substantial award of damages to persons who arrived in Australia without lawful authority and were held in detention for the legitimate reason of assessing their claims to stay in this country as refugees. In this way, the Government seeks to ensure that section 88 has, and always had, the effect and operation that parliament intended.

The Opposition parties were swayed in their decision to oppose the curative measures in this bill when it was introduced to the other place by the dissenting report of their members of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in it's consideration of the No. 2 bill. That report attempts to distinguish the proposed curative steps in the No. 3 bill from the dollar a day provision on the ground of retrospectivity. This is pure sophistry.

Section 54RA limits any compensation payable to one dollar per day after the cause of action concerned has already arisen. Thus the parliament has already applied retrospective measures to substantially limit the claims of the boat people for compensation. Sufficient doubt has now been placed upon the measures taken to date, for the Government to accept the necessity of pursuing further retrospective measures of a curative nature to ensure that the Commonwealth is in the strongest possible position to defend these claims.

The dissenting report also adopted the line pursued in the submission of the Law Council of Australia before the Committee that the curative measures would distort the relationship between the legislative and judicial arms of government. This submission ignores the well established prerogative of the parliament to legislate so as to affect and alter existing rights at issue in pending litigation without interfering with the exercise of judicial power in a way that is inconsistent with the Constitution. Until the High Court decides otherwise, curative legislation of this nature remains a valid course open to the parliament.
I turn now to the curative provisions of the bill.

The amendments to sections 35 and 36 (sections 87 and 88) do not seek to change the operation of those sections, but insert new provisions intended instead to reflect the Commonwealth's understanding of sections 35 (section 87) and 36 (section 88) and the manner in which they were actually administered in practice prior to the commencement of Division 4B. The Attorney-General's Department has been consulted at every stage of the drafting process. It is the view of that Department that the amendments are not inconsistent with Australia's obligations under international law.

The proposed subsection 36(1AA) (subsection 88(1A)) seeks to put beyond doubt that section 36 (section 88) authorises the custody, for a finite period, of persons who arrive without lawful authority on board a vessel that subsequently is unable to depart Australia because it has been destroyed, or for example is not seaworthy, has been impounded or forfeited, has sunk, or is otherwise unable to depart.

This amendment also permits the taking and keeping of persons in custody, notwithstanding that the vessel on which those persons departed for Australia might not necessarily be the same vessel on which those persons arrive. It is restricted to persons who arrive on vessels that have left an Australian port and returned to an Australian port without having entered any other country. This covers situations where a person arrives at a port in Australia on an Australian based vessel to which the person was transferred from the vessel on which that person left another country, for instance to a rescue vessel when the original vessel is about to sink.

In the circumstances envisaged by new subsection 36(1AA) (subsection 88(1A)) it is not appropriate that the period for which a person may be detained should be determined by reference to the departure of a vessel from a port. The proposed amendments will, therefore, provide that custody is to be authorised until the person is granted an entry permit; or for such period as is necessary to allow for the person's removal from Australia, following a request in writing from the person to be removed, or after all applications to remain (for example, entry permit applications and applications for refugee status) and associated appeals or reviews have been finalised, or once all consideration of whether the person will be permitted to remain in Australia has been otherwise concluded; or until such earlier time as an authorised officer directs.

Under the Act, a person is considered to have entered Australia once they disembark in Australia. Proposed subsection 36(1AB) (subsection 88(1B)) makes it clear that a person is taken not to have entered Australia as a result of temporarily, haphazardly disembarking—for instance, on an island off the Australian mainland, briefly and without the knowledge of the Australian authorities—after which the persons then reboard their vessel.

The proposed amendment to section 35 (section 87) similarly does not seek to alter its existing operation but instead inserts specific provisions, to avoid any doubts, as to the extent of the power under this section. Under it an officer may, to prevent a person from entering Australia unlawfully, require a vessel to enter a port and require unauthorised persons to remain on that vessel until it arrives at the port.

I repeat that these simple, common-sense amendments, curative in nature, seek no more than to ensure that sections 35 (section 87) and 36 (section 88) of the Act have and have had the operation and effect that parliament intends them to have, which is the operation and effect which the Department and Ministers previously understood those provisions to have had.

The bill also inserts a constitutional validity or "reading down" provision. This will provide, unless a contrary intention can be clearly discerned, that where a provision of the Act could have both valid and invalid applications, the provision is not to have the invalid application but is to have every valid application. The provision is similar to and consistent with "reading down" provisions in certain other Commonwealth legislation.

Given the doubt over the validity of section 54RA the Government proposes only one change from the No. 2 bill which the Opposition parties have indicated they will not support. The current bill—the No. 3 bill—provides for the repeal of section 54RA.

By supporting the curative steps proposed by this bill the parliament can provide the Commonwealth with the strongest possible position for the defence of the boat peoples' claims. In doing so the parliament will not as I have outlined above be embracing retrospectivity for the first time.

parliament has already demonstrated its will to protect the Commonwealth, and the taxpayer, from the potential burden of compensation payments to those unauthorised boat arrivals who were detained under section 88 while their claims to remain in Australia were exhaustively assessed. The Government's commitment to this position is demonstrated by the introduction of the curative measures in this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this bill provides for immediate financial assistance to farmers experiencing exceptional circumstances due to drought. It is part of a comprehensive package of drought assistance announced by the Prime Minister on 21 September 1994.

I need hardly remind honourable members of the crippling effect which the current drought is having on significant parts of the rural community. In many areas, the drought is the worst on record and the Bureau of Meteorology does not expect a break before Autumn 1995. Many farmers and their families and the rural communities in which they live are suffering extreme hardship. Indeed the situation is critical in the worst affected parts of Queensland and NSW. Without immediate assistance, the hard work and personal investment of thousands of Australians might well be wasted.
