The package of measures announced by the government is designed to assist farm businesses which could not have anticipated the severity of this drought and ensure basic requirements of farm families are met. In the Prime Minister's words, the package will ensure that we do not leave these people behind. It creates a safety net to provide for the immediate cash flow needs of the worst affected farm families during and after this exceptional drought.
The main elements of the package are:
a drought relief payment for those experiencing exceptional circumstances due to drought—the subject of this bill;
further measures under the rural adjustment scheme to assist farm businesses; and
further resources for financial and social counselling.

The package provides for a systematic approach to drought relief based on the principles of the national drought policy. This policy, agreed by all governments in 1992, recognises that drought is a recurring feature of rural Australia which needs to be factored into normal farm management, but acknowledges that government assistance may be required in exceptional circumstances.

In total, the package is estimated to cost approximately $164 million over two years. This includes the commitment to match donations to the "farmhand" appeal. This appeal has already raised over $5 million from private contributions. This means that, when combined with the government's matching contribution, more than $10 million in additional emergency relief is being provided to the farming community in drought affected areas.
The government's response is substantial by any measure and has been applauded by the farm sector and wider community.

The government has also indicated that additional measures will be considered to ameliorate the effects of the current drought and to help our farming community to better prepare for future droughts. These may include further initiatives in the areas of taxation, income equalisation deposits, landcare and climate research.

Mr President, the government has been providing substantial assistance for drought since 1992 through the rural adjustment scheme, rural counselling and landcare. However, further measures have become necessary as the human and social consequences of the drought continue to escalate. In particular, it has become apparent that farm welfare needs are not being adequately addressed by existing government programs.

The drought relief payment provided for in this bill is designed to meet this need. It will provide eligible farm families in drought exceptional circumstances areas with cash for basic necessities and services. Payment will be at the level of Job Search Allowance (JSA), including partner allowance and family payments where applicable. Farmers in receipt of a drought relief payment will also receive a health care card.

The drought relief payment will be subject to both income and off-farm assets tests. Importantly, farm assets will not be included in the assets test and no work activity test will apply in recognition of the special circumstances applying to farmers during exceptional drought.

Students from farm families eligible for drought relief payment will also qualify for Austudy assistance. For farm families in exceptional drought circumstances who do not wish to apply for the drought relief payment but wish to access Austudy, provision has been made to waive the Austudy farm assets test.
Drought relief payments respond to the needs of those farmers most affected by drought exceptional circumstances. It complements the well targeted social security system.

Drought relief payments will be administered by the department of social security on behalf of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Under the scheme, farmers will first need to obtain a certificate from a state rural adjustment scheme authority confirming that they are experiencing exceptional circumstances due to drought. They will then make application for assistance through one of the regional offices of the Department of Social Security. The quickest way for farmers to have claims assessed will be to ring the drought contact officer at the nearest social security regional office and make an appointment. Where it is difficult for farmers to get to these offices, they should ring their nearest drought contact officer for advice.
Arrangements have already been made for payments to begin this week, backdated to 1 October. Payments will continue for a period of up to six months after the drought has broken, in
recognition that the productivity of farms and farm incomes will not recover as soon as it rains.

This bill provides for the introduction of the drought relief payment through amendments to the Farm Household Support Act 1992. It includes minor amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973, Social Security Act 1991 and Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to give effect to benefits associated with the drought relief payment and to make necessary consequential changes.

This bill also establishes a standing appropriation for drought relief payments to ensure that funds are available to fully meet the claims of all eligible applicants. Interim payments are being made from the advance to the Minister for Finance.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994, which has been a long time coming to the chamber. This is an omnibus bill which seeks to amend the taxation legislation. I will limit my comments to the social security payments and the dependent spouse rebate, which will be removed to make way for the social security payments for home child-care allowance. First, I will address the dependent spouse rebate that should have been eliminated before now.

PARA.TAB: This amendment is the result of probably the biggest three-card trick we have ever had during an election campaign. The Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, told us—with a big fanfare—that the carers who stayed at home to mind the children would get $30 a week. She did not tell the electors of Australia—nor did anyone else—where that money was coming from.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax revenue, actually.
—If Senator Schacht had followed the debate, he would know that it was not tax revenue.
—It was not monopoly money.

—It came from tax revenue originally; Senator Schacht is right. But that was the three-card trick. Senator Crowley did not tell anyone that the dependent spouse rebate was going to be eliminated and that was where this money was coming from. That is why Senator Schacht is able to sit there and say it is coming from—
—That was announced, if you read the statement carefully.

—It was announced, says Senator Schacht. I could read to Senator Schacht what Senator Crowley said in answer to a question of mine in the Senate, but I do not want to bore him. In summary, she denied that there was anything like that going on. The upshot was that the dependent spouse rebate of $27.50 was removed and the government, through social security, was to pay out $30 per week or $60 per fortnight. Of course, this was part of the lie campaign that was carried on during the last election. That was not an extra $30; in fact, the additional payment was only $2.60, which is the price of a hamburger.

PARA.TAB: I predicted that employees would be disgruntled when they found out about this situation. In fact, a Comcar driver in Perth told me last week that he and his wife had made a conscious decision for her to stay at home and not take a job because of this $30 a week from the government. But all of a sudden he found out that his take-home pay was going to be cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the spouse got the money.
—The spouse got the money. It was simply transferring money from—
—Do you oppose that?
—No, I am not opposing that.
—What are you complaining about?

—Why did the government not come out and say, `We are transferring money from the earner to the spouse to stay in the home.' That is fair enough. I am not arguing with that at all. But the government should have come out and said it so that people knew where they stood. The government should have told the people the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. One of the Comcar drivers did not know last week that that was the situation. People are starting to find out. I predicted that there would be disgruntled employees. I employ some people and I was dreading the day that this was introduced because I knew that they would be looking for more money.
—Being generous, I hope you gave it to them.

—Of course I did not give it to them. The first pay day after 1 October is not here yet and I have not been home to do that. Perhaps I will do it when I get there. The government is simply changing the recipient from the earner to the carer, and I have no problems with that. But the government should have told everyone about it.
—We did.

—Well, the government did not make a very good job of it because there are still people who do not know. A lot of people found out when they looked in their tax pack because the application form was in there. Employees will accuse employers of cutting their wages and then the employers will have to explain that they are really not being cut.

PARA.TAB: I asked Senator Crowley for a choice so that those who wished to stay on the same basis could do so, rather than change over to the new system. I asked her the question on 28 February 1994 and she simply said that she could not believe any woman carer would agree to let the earner—her husband—keep the allowance and there would be no need for a choice. She wanted two simple systems: the first where the carer got the allowance from social security and the second where the spouse without children rebate would remain the same.

She did not want to give a choice. In that matter it had to remain as she thought fit. Whoever introduced this system decided that it would simply be a vote catcher. But it did not really put much more into people's pockets—only $2.60. Then lo and behold, after Senator Crowley would not even think of allowing a choice, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) on 25 August made an announcement that there would be a choice. He said that the ones who wanted to remain in the old system would be able to do so.

I have found the article. It is in the Canberra Times of 25 August and is headed, `Caring allowance provisions altered'. After Senator Crowley denied that there should be any choice, the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, said that there would be a choice—although it meant that people would lose out on about $4 a week by remaining on the spouse without children rebate instead of lining up at Social Security and making application for the $30. For Senator Schacht's benefit, I will read part of this article. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition sought unsuccessfully to introduce similar changes to the legislation which abolishes the dependent spouse with children tax rebate that the new allowance replaces.
The Government did not accept the amendments, but Mr Gear said amendment would be introduced in the Senate to reflect the changes once the detail had been worked out.

In other words, the government came up with this big idea, forgot to do its homework and forgot to advise people. The trouble came and Mr Gear decided that, in the final analysis, he had to do something about it.

PARA.TAB: Having been given a choice, people had to pay $200 a year for it—and a lot of people will remember that. I remind the Senate that there is only $2.60 difference between the systems. As I have already said a couple of times, providing a choice gives a cost benefit to families of only $4, but I suppose we can thank the Lord for small mercies in this case.

All this has caused a great deal of confusion for employers. Originally, under the legislation the start-up date for the home child-care allowance was to be 1 October. But because this government cannot manage its programs, 1 October came and went without the legislation going through. Nevertheless, there were strict instructions in the PAYE tax book for the 29 September pay date—the last pay date on which the spouse with children rebate was to be deducted from wages. Employers had to omit that and pay the rest in wages. But that did not allow for the tardiness of the government. Anyone who looks at a PAYE tax book will see it there in black and white—actually, it is in blue and white because that is the colour in which it appears this year.

What did the government do when the legislation did not go through? It put the onus back on the employers. I have here a copy of a notice that the Australian Taxation Office published. It is headed `Notice to employers, home child care allowance—tax instalment deductions'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments to the taxation legislation to abolish the dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children are currently before the Parliament. These amendments are complementary to the new social security payment, the Home Child Care Allowance, which commenced on 29 September 1994.
Social Security had already started paying that $30 a week to those who had applied. It goes on:

Employers have no legal authority to alter their employee's tax instalment deductions or to cease rebate claims on behalf of employees without a new employment declaration or written notice from the employee. It is the employee's responsibility to alter their tax instalment deductions by furnishing a new employment declaration to the employer.

Employees who have not provided a new employment declaration but who have had their tax instalment deductions automatically adjusted by their employer are entitled to have their rebate entitlements restored. As the legislation before the Parliament is not yet law—
well, we know that—
there is no requirement under current law for the taxpayer to lodge a new employment declaration.
Further confusion! It continues:
However, employees may choose—
the word `choose' is in italics—
to lodge a new employment declaration to adjust their tax instalment deductions to safeguard against under-paying tax in anticipation of the amendments becoming law.

Only after the Parliament passes the legislation will employees, whose rebate entitlement changes because of the amendments, be required to lodge a new employment declaration so that their tax instalments reflect their new rebate entitlement. This is the employee's responsibility. Employers should not adjust an employee's tax instalment deductions without a new employment declaration from the employee.
And there was so much confusion that the tax office supplied a 1 800 telephone number.

PARA.TAB: The PAYE book told everyone what they had to do. The tax pack—which came out in June some time—contained an application form. Then there was all this confusion and the government tried to throw the onus back on the employer, as it usually does. That is the history of this bungle.

I would now like to address the provisional tax uplift factor. I have said time and again in this place that the provisional tax uplift factor should reflect Australia's economy, our inflation rate and those allied things that affect the sort of profit businesses will make. Interestingly, the Australian Democrats have an amendment on this. For the past few weeks they have been running a big line on the uplift factor—and I thank my colleague Senator O'Chee for his media release about where the blame for this lies.

There have been various uplift factors over the last few years—at one stage it was up as high as 12 and 14 per cent. I ask honourable senators not to hold me to the figure of 14 per cent but it has been at least as high as 12 per cent. In the past, it was set year by year but, with the help of the Democrats, it was locked in at 10 per cent for ever and a day unless there was special legislation. Yet the Democrats, including Senator Kernot today, have stood up in this place berating us for not supporting her amendment that would bring it down to five or six per cent. I can tell Senator Kernot that one of the reasons I will not support the amendment to bring it down to whatever percentage suits her is that the government will not accept it in the House of Representatives. We could then finish up with a factor of 10 per cent. If Senator Kernot cannot see that she is more stupid than I thought she was.

In the short time I have left, I would like to address the Royal Flying Doctor Service, RFDS, sales tax amendment, which attempts to bring an exemption back into line with its original purpose—the removal of sales tax from wireless transceivers which are used mainly to make contact with radio services operated by the RFDS and similar bodies. The exemption was primarily obtained by farmers in the outback but, as an unintended consequence of some past sales tax exemption reclassification act—I think it was in 1992—mobile transmitters were removed. That was brought to the attention of the government and the basis for this amendment is to bring them back in.

I would question the way that the government has gone about this amendment. If I am reading it correctly, another amendment might be just around the corner. I will read what I believe to be the relevant passage from the background to the legislation. Paragraph 20.6 of the explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment, which was made to the definition of `authorised person' . . . basically removed the exemption for people who are authorised to use wireless transceivers—
I do not know, incidentally, why they are not called radio transceivers; I think the term `wireless' is a bit outdated—

as they do not conduct the service under the Radcom Act. The amended legislation in effect provided exemption to the Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia and similar bodies which are already exempted from sales tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —There's nothing wrong with `wireless'.

—There is nothing wrong with it, but it seems a bit dated. I know we still have the Wireless Institute of Australia, but I spoke at a public seminar where a professor of education from Adelaide picked me up and told me I was out of date using the word `wireless', which is why I mentioned it. The point is the bill amends the definition of `authorised persons'. Senator Sherry might be interested to know that section 20.8 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The current definition of `authorised person' is amended to allow exemption to a person who is authorised to `operate the wireless transceiver'.
It says that the term `wireless transceiver' is not defined, but we obviously know that it is an apparatus that is capable of transmitting and receiving radio waves. It continues:
The authorisation to use the wireless transceiver in the specified circumstances is currently by being licensed as an "outpost station" . . .

That is my point—it states `licensed as an outpost station', and an outpost station is not a transceiver or radio base. By this definition and this amendment, the government is going to disallow the exemption of the sales tax on the transceiver base. I would certainly like Senator Sherry to tell me in the committee stage whether I am right or wrong.

PARA.TAB: I support all the amendments that my colleagues will be moving later on in the committee stage. I condemn the government for the unnecessary confusion it caused amongst employees, carers of children and employers, as I think I have said, and for lying to the electorate during the election because, after all, it was only $2.60 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't do that; you were caught out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I cannot resist continuing the comment that my colleague Senator Panizza made so well at the conclusion of his speech that the government has broken some promises, at which point the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Resources (Senator Sherry) interjected that we were caught out.

PARA.TAB: I have said this before, and I will say it again: if Senator Sherry and Senator Forshaw can show me where in the election material that they put out they told the electorate that they were going to massively raise taxes after the election rather than the contrary, which I can point out to them, where they said they would not raise taxes, I will be the first to come into this chamber and apologise. It is a fair offer, but of course they cannot do that because Senator Sherry, Senator Forshaw and Senator Burns follow Mr Keating, who, it has to be said, was caught out lying again today. Mr Hawke, the former Prime Minister, today referred to Mr Keating as a liar. So if a Labor member called Mr Keating a liar today, I do not have to join the chorus, because he has been caught out yet again. Senator Sherry looks embarrassed, and fair enough, so he should.

I support the comments of my colleagues and their contributions to this debate, and I do not plan to traverse the ground that they have so well covered. Instead, I wish to make just a couple of points in this debate which I think are important. The first point relates to the hearing that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration had into this bill on Monday, 19 September. I think we were all surprised to hear the evidence that the Treasury brought forward in relation to the calculation of the uplift factor. It was not Dr Ken Henry's finest hour in giving his evidence to that committee, because when we sought advice on just how the government computed the uplift factor Dr Henry said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have a model which throws out at the end of it some magical figure for the provisional tax uplift factor.

Honourable senators may remember that Treasury had a magnificent model for Fightback. It spent three-quarters of a million dollars working out how to model Fightback, and threw out tonnes of figures which were carefully tuned and finessed, with peculiar assumptions built in. At the end of the day, the Treasury model spewed out all these figures—no worries about that—but the Treasury did not have a model on which to compute its own policies. It came as a bit of a shock to us to find Dr Henry, the great modeller in the Treasury, who was able to spend days, hours—indeed, months—modelling the policies of the coalition, did not have the information to model his own policies, the policies of his own government. I think the evidence he gave was very revealing. As I said, it was not Dr Ken Henry's finest hour before any Senate committee, and that has to be conceded.

PARA.TAB: There is, of course, as we are aware, great concern in small business about the uplift factor, and rightly so. Dr Henry gave us quite a fascinating figure, I thought. He said, `If the uplift factor were cut back from eight to four per cent, the cost to this year's revenue would be in the order of $320 million.'

Having first discovered that this figure was not computed but was plucked out of the air by the Treasury, my colleague Senator O'Chee did a bit of research on this matter and asked, `How did all this come about?' Senator O'Chee revealed, I thought rather powerfully, that the uplift factor and the current arrangements were brought about because in 1990 the Democrats persuaded the government to accept their amendment because they considered it wastes the chamber's time to approve the provisional tax level each year. So Senator Spindler felt that was the case. Of course, if that had been included in the budget, there may have been some useful, productive debate on that issue and we may have been able to put some pressure on caucus, as has happened previously.

I point out to honourable senators that Senator Kernot was part of the budget negotiations. The Democrats are part of the budget process. I think all of us are concerned about issues relating to the uplift factor, but it is interesting that Senator Kernot was there when this budget was being framed. If Senator Spindler had been more cautious in moving his amendments back in 1990 about tax uplift factors, and if this chamber had had to approve those uplift factors, maybe it would have come to Senator Kernot's attention early in the piece. That may well have meant that this issue could have been dealt with more sensibly at an earlier and more practical time.

I for one welcome the interest that the Australian Democrats are at last showing in small business. But they have a long way to go because it is the Australian Democrats in this chamber who have constantly called for higher taxes. Their tax policies—I have made this point before; it is not news—are an invitation to the government to bring in more taxes.

The wash-through effects of these tax increases from the broken promise budget of the 1993 election are still having an impact on small business. There was no complaint from the Democrats about the broken promises of the government, nor was there any complaint, by and large, about the massive tax increases which were imposed in that budget and which are having an impact on small business today.

Senator Kernot has referred the issue of provisional tax uplift and a number of other features to the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee. I think in such an inquiry we need to look at the overall burden of taxes on small business and the impact of the tax increases which have been imposed by this government since it came into office on the cash flows of small business. When we reflect that 60 per cent of the price of fuel represents government taxes and charges, we can see that we are dealing with a massive tax impost.

I am delighted with anyone who worries about the tax burden on small business. It is a fundamental issue and should be addressed, but we want to make sure that we address the full range of tax issues which relate to small business. In that notorious broken promise budget, we had not only fuel excise increases, which impact on small business, but also wholesale sales tax increases, wine tax increases—a range of these tax increases. We waited in vain for Senator Kernot and Senator Spindler to join with us to try to prevent these imposts, which have a particularly savage effect on small business.

When we ally the willingness of the Australian Democrats to concede tax rises to the government, which they have done with their pro-big-union policies—it was the Australian Democrats which enabled the ACTU to win an historic victory by removing 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act—we must wonder when we will get the next major strike. Having removed what was a very effective weapon to protect small business from the capricious use of union power—

TALK.START.PARA: —Strikes are down. The long-term trend for strikes is down.
—Strikes go up and strikes go down. I remember—was it one week ago or two weeks ago?—that the wharves of this nation—
—That's right; the number of strikes is down.

—I take Senator Sherry's point. We are suddenly reminded of perhaps the most serious port strike which we have had for a long time and which, of course, cost business, big and small, millions of dollars. That is what that strike did. What was it all over, Senator Sherry? Some grubby deal by Senator Sherry and his factional mates over whether the ANL should be privatised or should not be privatised or how he could protect the interests of his union mates and union contributors. It had nothing to do with the national interest—but it was, as usual, small business and big business alike that paid.

PARA.TAB: We are going to have more of these strikes. When you feed the tiger, it continues to be hungry—and the ACTU and the union funders will be back for more big bites from you guys. You have given them everything and it is still not sufficient, and the demands will continue to mount.

We had the Democrats supporting the removal of 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act and giving an historic victory to the ACTU. When the next major strike occurs, when this weapon is no longer easily available to small business, I, for one, will be standing up in this chamber and drawing to the attention of Senator Kernot once again the devastating consequences of the anti-small business policies of the Australian Democrats.

There was another issue that came up. One of the issues affecting small business is the new Industrial Relations Act brought in by Laurie Brereton. Senator Forshaw smiles. We think Laurie is a joke; Senator Forshaw thinks he is a joke. Have we ever had a bigger duffer in charge of a major portfolio than Laurie Brereton? Everything he touches turns sour.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's a mate.
—He is a mate. He is a mate of Paul's, but I think there are probably some tensions there when he sees a minister performing so badly and so frequently.
—What about Darling Harbour—a great job.
—Senator Burns thinks he is doing a great job but the reality is—
—What about Darling Harbour?

—Senator Burns says that he is doing a great job. He has mucked up the privatisation of the airports, he has mucked up the privatisation of ANL, and he has mucked up the Industrial Relations Reform Act. Is there anything that this guy has not done? Senator Burns's standards are particularly low, so he still thinks he has done a good job. It would be Senator Burns and Mrs Brereton alone who would be thinking that Laurie is doing a good job, because nobody else in this country does.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, you will remember that one of the issues in the last Industrial Relations Reform Act was the ILO convention on the termination of employment which was signed, in secret, hours before the election was called. No-one was told about that one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The election we won.

—The election was won because those opposite did not reveal their policies. They brought in the Industrial Relations Reform Act, and got it wrong the first time round—and so we had an amendment brought in. The termination of employment provisions are too onerous and are causing serious concern to small business. Again, those opposite got it through the Senate, I concede. They signed it in secret; they won the election. And who helped them get it through? The anti-small business people, the coalition that are anti-small business—Senator Kernot, Senator Spindler and Senator Bell and the mates—got this act through which is affecting small business.
—And the Greens.

—I do not know. The Greens presumably gave them some help, too. We can criticise the Greens—although this is not the occasion to do it—but Senator Margetts has never held herself out as a friend of small business.
—She has.

—That will be another debate. I do not think that anyone believes that Senator Margetts is a friend of small business. I do not believe it; no-one over there believes it. But Senator Kernot is now deciding to attempt to hold herself out as a friend of small business. Therefore, I point out to her that, if she is going to be a friend of small business, she should look at the taxes, the burden of taxes, and not keep on agreeing to more and more tax rises for small business. She should not keep on adopting pro-big-union ACTU policies if she is worried about small business.
—And look at the people who buy your goods—the workers of Australia.
—I am sure that has some relevance to this debate, although I am not too sure what it is. In the spirit in which, I am sure, she made those comments, I will not be responding in detail.

PARA.TAB: To conclude my remarks, I point out that the impact of this government's policies on small business is a major political issue and will continue on to the next election. I call on the Democrats and the Greens—if Senator Margetts wants to join the pro-small business coalition, she should sign up and she may even be able to retain that tiny vote that she gets in Western Australia—not to adopt policies which increase taxes on small business and not to adopt pro-big-union policies. Then, and only then, can they really come out and portray themselves as friends of small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) is another 90-page tome by the government to try to fix up its tax system. One of the most contentious issues in this bill is the move to eliminate the dependent spouse rebate where the home child care allowance applies. This is the taxation change in relation to setting up the home child care allowance. The government maintains that most of the issues have already been resolved, and that this is only tidying up. The proposal for a compromise approach which allows those eligible for home child care allowance to opt to get the lesser dependent spouse without children rebate seems to conflict with this.

PARA.TAB: The problem with the home child care allowance is that the shift from the tax office assessment of income to the DSS assessment will in many cases increase the figure used as income and change other treatment. The consequence will be that many people effectively will have the amount of money reduced. A few people, where one member of the couple works but does not make enough money to pay tax and the other does not work or does minimum paid work, may be currently eligible for home child care allowance where they get no benefit, or partial benefit now, from a tax rebate.

Home child care allowance is also slightly higher than the dependent spouse with children rebate—which I shall refer to as the DSR. All except the advantage of the total of home child care allowance over the total of the dependent spouse with children rebate, effectively about $3 per week, may disappear when the parenting allowance is introduced. The allowance will be available to low income earners and includes home child care allowance. The government has agreed to compromise by allowing those eligible for home child care allowance to opt for the dependent spouse without children rebate. Both the coalition and the Australian Democrats are putting up amendments that they hope will ensure that no-one is worse off. We will support amendments that will make it work better.

The best option to my mind would be a simple option for people to apply either for home child care allowance or for the dependent spouse with children rebate. It would be easier to keep the current system intact than to modify it or try to construct a hybrid system, since PAYE taxpayers have the dependent spouse rebate calculated into their contributions.

It would be simpler because all the mechanisms are already in place at the tax office for both the rebate and the variation in tax deductions under PAYE. Everyone knows how it works. It would avoid any complicated refiguring of rebates in relation to home child care allowance received, and would be received in the pay cheque in reduced tax payments rather than as a refund at the end of the year. It would also allow those who work intermittently to avoid the problem of continually reporting to DSS on changing circumstance. This would have been our option, but there is little point in putting up yet another amendment.

I see other problems in regard to a shift in home child care allowance, but feel that most of these have been stated in the debate that brought the program into being. In general, our position is that home child care allowance basically takes more people from an independent system, where deductions are claimed by right, to a system where they are allowed to apply for a benefit and then become clients, to use the current jargon, of Social Security. Senator Chamarette may make some comments about the use of tax file numbers under this program, further extending the linkage between departmental databases and moving towards the tax file number as a universal identifier, without which a person has very little access to things.

Another issue in this bill is in its provision to allow a sales tax credit in respect of sales tax paid in relation to the alteration of goods for export. This exempts from sales tax those components going into exports, which do not include sales tax. Sales tax is applied only to goods sold in domestic markets. Exports are taxed under the domestic sales tax legislation of the country in which sale occurs. Imports are taxed under our sales tax legislation. This change means that we are not exporting goods on which tax has been paid. The opposition wishes to extend this to goods produced for sale to exempt institutions, and we support this move.

Under previous legislation parts and components going into goods sold to tax-exempt institutions were tax free. Under new legislation they are taxed. This puts the domestic equipment repair and recycling—or remachining—industry at a disadvantage relative to imported equipment when selling to tax-free institutions—and this is one-third of their market.

The legislation will make components for export tax free. The industry argues that the disincentives for domestic production could and should be fixed now also. The opposition is putting up amendments to do so, which the government says will not work—for unspecified reasons. The government argues that this is small potatoes and is not worth the trouble. We will support the opposition amendments and, if they do not work, hopefully we will force the government to fix them while complying with the intent. We will support any government bill that more effectively exempts such goods and replaces the opposition amendments.

The so-called remachining industry is labour intensive and waste reducing. It uses and teaches skills that are basically higher level trade skills such as metalwork, machining and electronics, the kind of work that it would be good to see more of in Australia. The issue is that the disincentive is negative for those domestic machining industries, most of which are small or medium-sized enterprises, and it is a disincentive to recycling. This disincentive was Just introduced in tax changes just last year. If it is too insignificant for government to correct, it can be changed without worry about loss of revenue.

There is also the future technology issue, with Europe especially requiring designs which facilitate such repair and recycling, and also the upgradability of new product. It is therefore an area where activity is expected to increase. One problem we have is that government is happy to make small changes to level any economic field where recycling has an advantage—for example, with paper products—but is content to allow the field to slope when it allows a disincentive to recycling. Why is this?

The government now claims that this change will not result in tax exempt institutions buying more equipment, that buying policies—mainly government buying policies—are to blame. We know and accept this. It is not about increasing the total market, but about changing the skew towards imports and away from domestic products within the existing market, a skew which was recently created and which should not exist.

Government also states that although this skew exists in relation to sales tax exempt institutions, there is a skew in the system favouring domestic producers selling to non-exempt buyers. All I can say is that this does not excuse a skew which affects a market where tax exempt buyers are currently one-third of all buyers. We do not like the threat that if government is forced to correct this negative bias affecting one-third of sales, it will punish the industry by eliminating the positive bias.

The Greens do not favour the famous level playing field. We believe that many community values are not given any value when measures to favour what the community wants are forbidden through regulation forcing free market ideology. We would like to see strong policies which say that things should be recycled and should be made recyclable; and they should be made easily upgradable in order to allow the incorporation of technical improvements without throwing away things we have made. We would like to see buying policies in all public institutions, including government departments, which explicitly state that they should buy recycled goods unless unavailable, and should buy recyclable goods in preference to disposable ones. We believe we should see this happen, but do not expect it with the current government attitude.

What we do hope to see is the sort of economic incentive-disincentive program designed to internalise externalities, to make the market work well. This is a minimum, and we do not see it. These would give some preference to recycled and remachined goods. Instead, we see a government that seems to want to remove any such measure to account for the social and environmental cost of waste. It wants to do this to level the playing field, in spite of the fact that the playing field is already slanted by the absence of inclusion of social and environmental costs.

On the other hand, whenever the playing field is slanted against recycling, against domestic production that would create jobs, the government seems happy to let it lie and to claim that the effect is insignificant. For this reason, even if the opposition amendment is not perfect, we will support it in the hope that it will send the government a strong message that it cannot keep on the way it is going.

This bill will also drop provisional tax increase from 10 per cent to eight per cent. This is a government commitment. The Democrats are proposing to drop it to five per cent, and expect coalition support. We will also support this move. The argument here is whether an uplift of eight per cent is still too high, and it is not clear why the uplift will go back to 10 per cent next year. The Democrats proposal for the uplift factor to go to five per cent on a continual basis is probably okay, but it would be better to have an uplift factor that reflects the economic forecasts, for instance inflation, and some factor determined by level of income from work and level from investment.

Perhaps an amendment here would lead government to think about this. One thing is certain: there is little rationale to consider that people with their own income from self-employment or investment will automatically see their income increase by 10 per cent per annum. Ten per cent growth is, after all, higher than most optimistic estimates for economic growth in Australia.

This bill will also give income and sales tax concessions for regional headquarters of transnational corporations. This is a real little gem. We know that many others in this place support this scheme. The Greens cannot support any scheme that helps in any way the foreign economically powerful, especially through support with Australian taxpayers' money. We are the only people who seem to care about this.

Why should Australian taxpayers pay for this? In spite of arguments that it is a tax concession, we can bet expenses will be involved in promoting this idea overseas and administering it here at home. Why should they get tax breaks? Is it because the government hopes it will create jobs for lawyers, CPAs, cleaners and those in the hospitality industry? Give us a break! The government should give it to Australian small and medium-sized enterprises if it wants to give it to someone and if it wants to create jobs.

There is the reportable payments system as well. This involves measures to increase compliance with tax. We generally support increased compliance, particularly at the top end of taxpayers. But this was initially designed to catch people in the clothing and fishing industries. Those are areas in which frequently little tax is paid on a PAYE basis, employers leaving it to employees to pay their own tax.

In the clothing industry, the workers concerned may be women working on a piecework rather than a shift basis. Often these women are poorly paid, are from ethnic minorities and speak poor English. I would like to see these women in more secure employment. I would like to see them better paid. I would like to see some form of negotiated contract that gives them decent wages and conditions, superannuation and so on. It does not appear that this bill or any other proposed bill will do that. The government does not care about them; it just wants its tax.

In the fishing industry, the conditions are also variable. In some cases workers are paid by the day—in some by the trip. In some cases part of income may be a portion of the catch. Work is also often not steady but is on a `while available' basis—workers can go out with a ship as long as it is out and the fish in season. In such circumstances, figuring out the tax to be paid as an equivalent to PAYE may be fairly difficult and involved for the payer. It is also the case that the income in any week may have little bearing on annual income, so the correct rate of tax is hard to determine. The payer will also not know what other income a worker may have, and certainly seasonal fishing workers are likely to have other income out of season.

Aside from the problems for employers in a more conventional sense, how will this work for the situation in which payers are actually people off the street paying a dressmaker or tailor? Will they be required to withhold tax? How will they process it to pay the Tax Office? Presumably, payees are also small business people who pay company tax or provisional tax, so they will be double taxed.

There are two other issues here. Firstly, the government says this is the first area in this new form of tax and that this is a new form of tax parallel to PAYE and provisional tax. There will be more areas, and this is the thin end of a wedge of indeterminate size. Secondly, the government estimates that, currently, $100 million of tax owed is not being paid by workers in these industries. Is this figure true? What is it based on?

This bill will also deem foreign banks to be separate legal entities, prevent double taxation of foreign sourced income and ensure consistent treatment of some termination payments. None of these issues seem to be problems, but none are overriding reasons to support this bill. There is actually little reason to support this bill as it is presented and some substantive reasons not to. However, given opposition support, the bill will go through. We have, therefore, chosen to support amendments which seek to improve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also address the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Before I do so, I cannot allow Senator Burns's very strong defence of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Laurie Brereton, to go by without challenge and without reminding Senator Burns that, but 30 minutes or so ago, this Senate censured that very minister. The whole Senate just censured that very minister.
—So what?

—I hear Senator Sherry interjecting. His defence of the minister was quite limp, and for obvious reasons: he is seeking that minister's portfolio. Senator Burns put in a very strong defence of Mr Laurie Brereton. The Senate censured that particular minister because of his most dangerous and incompetent administration of the CAA. They are the bare facts. I think the government knows that and is putting up a pretty limp defence for that minister. Even after this minister's dangerous administration of that particular area of his portfolio, even after Mr Sharp, who is in the other house, time and time again warned the minister about air safety problems in this country—
—He didn't provide any evidence.

—The evidence happens to be buried somewhere between here and Lord Howe Island. The minister's record in this particular area of his portfolio does not end there. He has a very poor record in preventing strikes in this country. A coal strike is pending at the moment. It will be the second one we will have had in 12 months because the minister has been unable to negotiate with and settle down the relevant union.

PARA.TAB: We have also had two damaging waterfront strikes in the last 12 months while that minister has overseen this portfolio. The first one cost the country a mere $100 million during a time of current account crisis. The latest one cost the country $50 million. But the minister did step into that particular strike and resolve that most damaging affair by offering to the maritime union the most generous tax concession known in this country: no tax at all. That is how the minister ended that strike. If I were a maritime worker I, too, would have gone back to work if I had been given that particular concession.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not given to the employees; it was given to the employers, you fool.

—Yes, it was; that is correct. But it was an unnecessary and generous concession. At a time when Australian farmers had not even heard an announcement of the government's drought package, the Minister for Industrial Relations resolved that damaging and pathetic strike over the sale of ANL by giving maritime union workers a tax concession unknown in this country, and that is no tax at all.

PARA.TAB: The minister's incompetence goes further than that. In the very core of this minister's portfolio of industrial relations there was some remanence at some time of his wanting to reform industrial relations and put together some reform, particularly in the area of enterprise bargaining. That was until he was met at the congress by the ACTU and the tomato-throwing brigade. Who can forget Laurie Brereton ducking the tomatoes at the ACTU congress? It was not very long before this very weak minister backed right off from any semblance of reform that may have been proposed in the industrial relations area, collapsed and kowtowed to the ACTU.

The so-called Industrial Relations Reform Bill came through the Senate. It proposed to do nothing more than enhance the power of unions, particularly the ACTU. I wonder whether I have left out anything in relation to this particular minister. I have not heard the cries of, `What about Darling Harbour, that is one feather in his cap.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You will credit him with that, will you?

—I will tell Senator Sherry about Darling Harbour. I am skating on thin ice here, so I will be a little careful when it comes to talking about Darling Harbour. Mr Laurie Brereton got out of town before the cries went up `What about Darling Harbour and the tenders?'—and he found his way into the lower house. I have probably left out a lot when it comes to Mr Brereton. I hope that Senator Sherry, a very fine representative in the Senate of the cabinet, is in line for his portfolio.
—You're going to kill me.

—Senator Schacht does it more often than not to Senator Boswell. Before I get onto the substance of the bill, I must remind the Senate of Senator Richardson's farewell speech to this Senate when he damned Mr Laurie Brereton with faint praise by quoting the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as saying that he found Laurie Brereton on a surfboard and he can send him back to being on a surfboard. So we know where Mr Laurie Brereton's loyalties lie. He is beholden to the Prime Minister—a Prime Minister that only today a past Prime Minister basically called a bald-faced liar. So birds of a feather flock together.

PARA.TAB: This most comprehensive taxation bill does cover a wide range of matters in regard to taxation. For a government that desires simplification of tax law—in particular, corporate tax law—this bill is evidence that the left hand of the bureaucracy does not know what the right hand is doing. In the Senate we are constantly facing layer upon layer of tax law amendments in the most contorted and longwinded language. Anyone who picks up this piece of legislation and sees this array of amendments and changes will agree with that.

Every extra dollar taxed on business is a cost and reflects on future investment and employment capabilities. Equally, every extra dollar taxed on households reduces future savings and expenditure. Given that governments are not known for their efficient use of the tax dollar and that it is far more efficient to leave that dollar in the hands of the private sector, the underlying philosophy of tax is the less that government taxes, the greater the efficiency of the economy. Of course, a balance must be drawn, and tax is considered necessary. The problem is the complexity, the interpretation and the calculation of the tax system. It is often regressive in its application.

With regard to the complex and regressive taxation system, this government has truly made it an art form. Recently, a National Bank survey found that the typical medium size business spends more than 62 working days a year filling out an array of different tax forms and pays the equivalent of another 12 working days on professional advice on how to do it. So it is little wonder that the head of that bank, Don Argus, said that it was quite frightening that 500 hours or 62 working days a year are spent filling out tax forms alone.

Further official studies on this issue have found that the burden has been increasing, not decreasing. The array of different tax forms includes income tax returns, sales tax, customs, fringe benefits tax, tax instalment deductions, prescribed payments system, Workcare, payroll tax, the training guarantee levy—although that has now been suspended—and superannuation forms. There is no end to the number of forms which make up that 62 days or 500 hours.

The Attorney-General, Mr Michael Lavarch, has made a good start in simplifying company law. Equally, tax law should be simplified. This is in line with the criteria laid out in the 1985 white paper on the review of the Australian taxation system which indicated that the tenets of a good tax system should be equality, efficiency and simplicity. There has been some advancement on that 1985 statement, but only in the area of tax administration.

In August this year, the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, released a response in which he said that only 28 of the 148 recommendations of the JCPA—the Joint Committee of Public Accounts—on the administration of the Australian taxation system would be rejected. I reiterate that that is only in the area of tax administration. One of the better recommendations of this committee taken up by the government was the establishment of a small tax claims tribunal as part of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Taxpayers with disputes involving less than $5,000 will gain access to that tax claims tribunal; a minor fee of $50 will be required.

The legislation before the Senate does bring relief to small business in another area by reducing the uplift factor from 10 per cent to eight per cent. Senator Kernot, for the Australian Democrats, made quite a good point in relation to the uplift factor; that is, although it is a minor change from 10 per cent to eight per cent—she is calling for a figure of five per cent, I believe—greater emphasis is given in this legislation not to small business, as it should be, but to incentives for regional headquarters. They are getting a greater tax deduction and greater tax incentives than our own small businesses.

The reason that the coalition is not supporting the Democrats' suggestion to reduce the uplift factor to five per cent is simply because, if we do, the legislation will go back to the House of Representatives and the government has told us quite clearly—and as the financial year rolls on, it looks to be so—that it will simply revert the uplift factor to 10 per cent. So we will grab this small mercy while we can but we signal that we will be reviewing the matter year by year. Next year we may not hold the same view. Certainly, the uplift factor should be reviewed in relation to keeping it in line with inflation or the government's growth forecasts. This ad hoc approach of making it up as we go along is clearly unsatisfactory and introduces an element of uncertainty, particularly for small business, at a time of uncertainty.

Small business groups have lambasted the very concept of provisional tax; they say it is inequitable. The Chairman of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, Mr Paul Greenwood, believes that the advance payments of provisional tax are pushing many small businesses to the brink of failure and that there is an absurd situation whereby success hastens bankruptcy because growth requires increases in working capital and early tax payments. It would be known to the government that the concept of provisional tax is not welcomed by small business, and never has been. There has been a long, ongoing battle to get governments to understand the type of burden that provisional tax places on very small businesses in particular in having to find this cash at a time when cash flow is not readily available. So the uplift factor is very important to small business. Governments should not make it up year by year, on an ad hoc basis, but should have some formula that small business can factor in yearly and thus allow for.

Small business also has great complaint about the fringe benefits tax, which would not be news to the government. Again, this has been a longstanding concern for small business—not just the complexity and the administration of the fringe benefits tax, but the level of the fringe benefits tax. It is seen as an attempt by government to milk every last drop from small business. It has gone beyond the tenet of tax being fair and equitable. It is now simply a tax which is a burden and which is squeezing business so hard that it is directly affecting their employment ability—their ability to employ that one extra person.

Business has to meet the administration costs and the complexities of the fringe benefits tax, so will simply not put that extra person on. It is an overhead that is directly affecting the employment factors of small business. This is all because of the broadened definition. In the August 1993 budget the government broadened the definition just to grab the extra dollars. Those extra dollars are very significant because in 1986, when the fringe benefits tax was first introduced, the government received some $585 million. The government has now budgeted in the new financial year for over $3 billion in fringe benefits tax. That is a clear signal that this government is simply using this as a revenue raising tax to the hilt, to squeeze every single ounce out of small business. It has reached the absurd situation where business cannot even have a Christmas party without wondering what part of the Christmas party will be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't have Christmas cards or Christmas carols.

—Senator Boswell is quite right. This government seems to have a thing about Christmas. It is ruining and damning Christmas. Each year the government comes up with a device to ruin Christmas. Last year it was Christmas carols; this year the office party is under threat because even Santa is going to be taxed. Let me give an example of what would be a normal Christmas function for business X.
—They have been holding Christmas parties in May.
—I will read this into Hansard. Let us say that business X holds a Christmas party for staff each year at the employer's premises—nothing unusual in that.
—In May.

—No, we are leading up to Christmas. As part of the festivities, a live band is hired to entertain the staff, as well as a comedian and Santa Claus for the kids. While the food and beverages consumed by the employees will be exempt from fringe benefits tax, the cost of the live band, the comedian and Santa will need to be separately accounted for because the cost of providing non-property entertainment will be subject to FBT. Further, some of business X's major clients are often invited to the Christmas party—there is nothing unusual about that. This creates further complications as the cost of providing the non-property entertainment will need to be further apportioned between employees and non-employees. And so it goes on.

PARA.TAB: That is the sort of advice one has to receive from one's accountant to judge whether to hold a Christmas party or not. That is the absurd complexity that the fringe benefits tax has reached. Thankfully, the government has agreed to review the complexities of the fringe benefits tax. An announcement was to be made in July 1994, but we still await that announcement. I do not know why there has been a hold-up on that review of the fringe benefits tax, but business awaits it with bated breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I only want to speak on one aspect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994, that is, the section dealing with the dependent spouse rebate and changes to the home child-care allowance scheme. This bill allows for payment of the dependent spouse rebate at the lower without-child rate if the taxpayer's spouse is not eligible for the home child-care allowance at all.

PARA.TAB: We now see before us additional government amendments to allow for payment of a partial allowance if partial home child-care allowance was available but that amount was less than the person would have received under the dependent spouse rebate. However, this `top up' rebate will be calculated on the dependent spouse rebate without-child rate, and that is the lower rate. Basically, the home child-care allowance will be paid at the rate of $60 a fortnight, or $1,570 a year, for those who have no other income. The dependent spouse rebate with-child rate for 1994-95 was to have been $1,452 a year, or $55.40 a fortnight. Obviously those families with no other income are certainly benefiting.

The without-child DSR will be $1,211 a year, or $9.20 a fortnight less than the dependent spouse rebate with-child rate. For a wage earner on, say, $20,000 a year, that is $241 a year less than they would have received under the old dependent spouse rebate arrangements with child. That is the equivalent of effectively losing a week's wage in a year.

The eligibility for the dependent spouse rebate—and this is where the problem lies—was based on an income test of the dependent spouse's net income as defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act, whereas HCCA eligibility will be based on the current income test in the Social Security Act. Unfortunately, this income test is far stricter than the income tax separate net income test.

In broad terms, the income tax income test is a net income assessment after work related deductions have been taken off. But the Social Security income test is a gross one with no deductions allowed. I must add here that the Social Security income test also includes unrealised capital gains income on assets.

The result will be that the income of many dependent spouses will be judged to be much higher for the purposes of gaining home child-care allowance than it would have been if that family was applying for the dependent spouse rebate. This will leave many families worse off under the new system. This is despite the assertions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—and I go back to the 1993 election speech—that basically HCCA was simply a replacement, a reorganisation, of the dependent spouse rebate. In the speech Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the Keating Government will increase the dependent spouse rebate and pay it directly to the spouse at home caring for children. The new Home Child Care Allowance will be $30 a week and will provide some source of independent income for women at home caring full time for children.

We obviously have no problems with that, but there was no mention of the fact that many families—our estimates are up to 200,000—will be worse off. There was no adequate explanation of the various processes or the tests that would be applied to the new allowance. Indeed, there was no mention of the fact that the government could seek to claw back the cost of the increase by reducing eligibility for the allowance through that tighter Social Security income test.

PARA.TAB: We have had a very extensive public advertising campaign, costing something like $18 million, to tell families how much better off they are going to be. That campaign has been run through women's magazines. I have one here telling us how basically people will be $60 a fortnight better off. At the beginning it says:

SPEECH.PARA: If you stay at home for your children this simple quiz could get you $60 a fortnight.

I notice the word `could', and that should ring alarm bells for those who are suspicious in the first place. But as one goes through the advertisement, it is not explained that it is in fact a replacement; in other words, while $60 is going into the hands of the spouse who stays at home, the money is no longer able to be claimed through the taxation system by the working spouse. I read very carefully through a number of these advertisements and nowhere does it correctly explain how the system is going to work.

PARA.TAB: Yes, it has a number on the bottom, but those who have been listening to talk-back radio—and I am thinking particularly of my home state—will know that this has created confusion and animosity amongst people who have never had it explained to them. Firstly, they have not been told that it is a replacement; secondly, many people will be worse off, even with the final government amendments that we have before us today. Basically, a family on a low income will be worse off by the equivalent of a week's wage at the end of the year.

Really, the only families that are going to be $60 a fortnight better off are those families who are now so badly off that they pay no tax. In fact, rural families, along with some small business families, are about the only ones whose income has been so low that they did not qualify. Those people could not get the dependent spouse rebate because there was no tax to rebate it off. Therefore, they would be the only people who would get the $60 a fortnight. While this is a good scheme, I would like to have seen advertising that was far more explicit and far more honest.

I issued a press release on this matter last week, which the minister criticised, but I will go through some examples of the matters I raised in it now. I take the example of a spouse who stays at home with the children and takes in washing or looks after someone else's children. That spouse is usually the woman. If, as it says in the advertisement, she earns more than just over $10 a fortnight—which in today's currency means very little but it is an amount that has not changed since the 1970s—that family will start to run into problems because, effectively, home child-care allowance will cut out, as the dependent spouse rebate did. As soon as she earns $4, she loses $1. So she does not have to earn very much to be in that group affected by that new test.

I also take the example of parents who work part time three days a week, live 15 kilometres from work, buy and dry-clean their own uniforms, claim bank and union fees, pay child-care expenses of, say, $45 a week, and earn, say, $120 a week. The separate net income for the dependent spouse rebate would have been assessed at $1,068 a year. Under the dependent spouse rebate scheme, the working partner would have got back $1,256 through the tax system.

However, with the home child-care allowance, the income will be assessed as $6,240 and, until we see these amendments go through, only $80.50 will be received. These are the sorts of problems people encountered once they began to work out what they were going to get under HCCA as against what they used to get under the dependent spouse rebate. So, under the unamended bill, that sort of family would basically get very little. Under the bill before us, the family would get nothing extra until these additional government amendments go through, which will mean that the family will be only—only—$241 a year worse off than before. But then, looking at what the home child-care allowance is adding on, the family would still be worse off by another $4.50 a fortnight.

Mr Baldwin in the other place said that I was wrong for quoting this example because the family would get the child-care cash rebate—which it would—but it would also get that under the dependent spouse rebate. So the disparity between these two examples remains. Thousands of families will be affected. That is not our estimate; it is the estimate of the Australian Taxpayers Association that 200,000 families who currently receive a partial dependent spouse rebate will be worse off even with the government amendments to this bill. If the NRMA float goes ahead in New South Wales, many families in New South Wales who get home child-care allowance will be affected because of the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares.

Another problem is that the dependent spouse rebate is payable at the higher rate for students aged between 18 and 25; home child-care allowance is not. The dependent spouse rebate is payable when a taxpayer is out of the country; HCCA is not. The government has sought to rectify some of these problems, and our amendments and those of the opposition will rectify the rest. Our amendment seeks to ensure that, where a family receives less home child-care allowance in a year than it would have been entitled to under the dependent spouse rebate, it can claim the difference on its tax return at the end of the year. The rebate should be at the higher with child rate and not based, as the government wants it to be, on the lower without child amount.

This amendment would not be necessary if the social security income test was improved. That would have been our preferred position. It is disappointing that we are forced to run this safety net arrangement because of the flaws in the social security income test. The Democrats will be supporting the amendment to be moved by the opposition during the committee stage of this debate, which looks like being tomorrow. We will, however, be seeking to amend the opposition's motion to make it clear that the partial rebate can be claimed only at the end of the financial year. Also, the rebate should not be able to be claimed if the family is eligible for home child-care allowance at the full rate.

Our amendments are to ensure that HCCA becomes the primary means of assessing predominantly single-income families. In our view, the HCCA system of paying the allowance direct to the care provider rather than the spouse is a very welcome change, particularly given statistics showing that up to 15 per cent of husbands provide their dependent spouses with no income whatsoever. What is needed under the home child-care allowance is a safety net to ensure that no family is worse off under the new system and to give some meat to the Prime Minister's promise to this effect. That is what our amendments and the opposition amendments will seek to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which covers a variety of tax changes. There are two changes that I am concerned with and I will direct my contribution to those two amendments. I am very concerned with the harsh approach that the federal government is taking to small business. One of the amendments in this bill today points out the uplift factor that is affecting small business. It goes to prove that, over the years, the Hawke government and now the Keating government have continually been increasing costs at a higher and higher rate on small business and farmers. They have been the real victims of Mr Keating's regime as Treasurer and now as Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: One of the worst areas to affect small business and primary industry is the regime of high interest rates. We have heard a lot of discussion over the past two months about drought. The drought is a very serious problem that has affected farmers all over Australia. But I wonder whether that drought has adversely affected small business and farmers more than the high interest rates which the government used and continued to use and which crippled Australian business for far too long. I have always been intrigued as to how the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could go forward and admit that he has made mistakes, admit that we have the recession we had to have, admit that he has broken the inflation stick and so forth and just go on to another subject and leave small business and farmers to grapple with the consequence of his mistakes.

I now want to address my remarks to the part of the bill which will hit small business in a very hard way—that is, the amendment relating to the provisional tax uplift factor. The rate of the uplift factor is of great importance to provisional taxpayers. It is the amount by which the previous year's income tax is raised for this year's provisional tax assessment. The government has arbitrarily decided that the going rate is eight per cent.

There has been a great deal of representation to the government from the small business sector for the uplift factor to be reduced to a figure that reflects the growth figure, which is around four per cent when we consider inflation and the increased cost of interest rates. The small business sector has been saying that four per cent would be an adequate figure to use to assess its future incomes. However, the government has decided that small business can once again be the sacrificial lamb and the government will use the figure of eight per cent to calculate the 1994-95 provisional tax.

It has been pointed out on many occasions that the uplift factor of eight per cent is four per cent over growth. This will require small business to find an extra $400 million for tax payments next year. That is a very unfair element arising from the high rate of eight per cent which the government has imposed. It simply is not calculated on any justifiable figure. I know that my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Kemp took this matter to a Senate inquiry. They could not get any justifiable reason why eight per cent was the accepted figure.
It represents the bringing forward of $340 million paid for by small business to help the government balance this year's deficit. The explanatory memorandum to the bill says that the:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . uplift factor reflects the effects of inflation and other relevant factors in ascertaining the amount of income subject to provisional tax.

The government is going around beating its chest saying that the inflation rate is down to 1.7 per cent this year, yet it goes out and charges the small business sector eight per cent. Surely there is a great difference between the present inflation rate of 1.7 per cent and the eight per cent on which the government will assess future small business tax. This is a concern because when Treasury officials were questioned at the Senate estimates hearing on how they calculated the uplift factor, they could put forward no relevant factors for the calculation. At the Senate inquiry, Senator Kemp said:
We have learnt from Treasury that this figure of eight per cent is a notional figure, a figure sort of plucked out of the air.
My colleague further noted:

The uplift factor going from four to eight per cent is having a major effect on the cash flow of small business, particularly in the climate where the government is very anxious to create jobs in small business.

Senator Watson is acknowledged by all members of the Senate as one of the experts on taxation matters, and his view is that the uplift factor is too high as evidenced by the number of applications last year to reassess provisional tax. This all costs small business time and money. Many small business operators have to face the fringe benefits tax and the prescribed payments tax. Now they will have to reassess themselves on their provisional tax.

PARA.TAB: To digress for a few minutes, I have been approached by builders in my home state saying that it is taking them two days a month to fill out the prescribed payments forms. These are not big, massive builders, but cottage builders. They are finding it very hard to give time to fill in these prescribed payments forms. Now they will have to reassess their provisional tax.

The uplift factor in provisional tax is an extra federal tax that is unfairly placed on the extra cost of small business. I was in small business for 20-odd years and many small business people tell me, `What happens now is nothing like what happened when you were in small business 12 years ago.' They tell me that they almost need an extra person to keep the books and to do the necessary paperwork in order to provide the government with information so that it can then in turn tax small business.

I want to turn to a point made by the Queensland Retail Traders and Shopkeepers Association. The point the association makes is that by imposing an uplift factor at double the growth factor, the government is severely penalising all those who pay provisional tax. Unlike the PAYE and companies which pay tax on actual income earned less cost, provisional taxpayers are being forced to pay on projected turnover at double the current rate of growth. The government is plainly using small business to fund its irresponsible budget deficit. The entire Australian community is the worse off for the job opportunities that are lost in the small business sector from this extra cost burden.

I want to point out that this becomes particularly serious when viewed from the perspective of small business communities and retailers in rural areas that are affected by the drought. Queensland and New South Wales are suffering the worst drought that has been experienced in a number of years. But the National Party of Australia understands—and obviously the government does not understand—that rural communities stick together in times of adversity. They try to maintain as best they can their own business structures in their own small towns. They try to help one another, back one another up.

The small business community moved in to help the farming community when many of the banks and the lending institutions wrote them off and would not extend any lending, and when the government was insisting that drought was a natural part of life. Small business and the retailing sectors came to the aid of the small business person. Consequently, many rural small businesses have debts on their books, particularly from farmers, of $150,000 to $200,000. I would say that in some cases those figures are fairly modest, but they are figures that I obtained from the Queensland retailers.

Because the drought has lasted longer than anyone anticipated, many of these small businesses have already collapsed and more are in danger of total collapse. Small business has had its cashflow severely restricted, while at the same time small business operators have had to continue to pay their wholesalers on a seven-day account. This problem is magnified when provisional tax has to be paid and when the tax regime incorporates an unrealistically based eight per cent uplift factor on the income increase factor.

For the rural small business person the credit amounts are classed as sales. If one sells a product, it is classed as a sale and as profit, irrespective of the fact that one may not get paid for it for six months. The provisional tax has to be paid on sales, not on actual profit. In normal times the money will come in in 30 days and a sale gets turned into a profit. But as we used to say in small business, a sale is not a sale until one gets paid for it.
