Unfortunately, in these circumstances a sale is deemed to be profit which has to have an uplift factor of eight per cent paid on it before the money comes in, and this is further affecting the small business regime in rural Australia at the moment. In these extreme circumstances the small business community is calling for consideration of its case and for means to be found to address the plight of rural small businesses caught in this horrendous drought.

I would like to instance the small business scheme initiated by the Queensland government, which gives a $5,000 interest subsidy to small businesses caught in exceptional drought circumstances. I think the Queensland government is putting some $5 million into it and it is to be commended for that. I am suggesting to the government—and I hope I can have senator McMullan's attention—that it match dollar for dollar that small business initiative provided by the Queensland government. On many occasions in exceptional circumstances and at other times of need the federal government puts out some forms of money that have to be matched dollar for dollar from the states. It would be a welcome initiative if the federal government were to match the Queensland government subsidies dollar for dollar. I ask the government to consider that suggestion.

The drought, combined with other long-term government policies, has placed a heavy threat on the survival of many rural communities. The figures are there. Last year, the drought caused a $580 million loss in gross value of production in Queensland's rural sector, with a flow-on effect of $1.4 billion. Included in these massive losses are losses burdening rural small business. I will address this matter further in my contribution to the drought debate tomorrow but, while I have Senator McMullan's ear, I would like to make sure that he picks up this matter. I call on him and the government to consider rural small business as an integral part of its response to the drought. I ask the government to match the Queensland government dollar for dollar in its small business drought interest rate subsidy scheme.

The coalition has always believed in assisting small business as part of severe drought measures. To its shame the government, in removing drought from the natural disaster relief arrangements, has neglected to even look at the great chasm that is left for small business in times of severe drought.

The federal government has always called on the states to meet its rural assistance interest subsidy schemes dollar for dollar. The federal government now has the opportunity to show that it can do the same thing when the boot is on the other foot and the initiative for small business interest subsidies comes from the state government.

Small business is often called on to create employment, yet the government insists on creating more and more disincentives. A recent survey showed that a major disincentive for small business to take on more employees was the government's new dismissal provisions in the industrial relations legislation—the reverse onus of proof is now on the employee.

There is one other aspect of the bill that I would like to address—the reportable payments system. At this stage, a reportable payments system is being introduced for certain industries. This is an entirely new tax system which, no doubt, over time will be inflicted on many other industries. Initially, it will apply to the fishing and clothing industries only. The system commences on 1 November this year. According to the government, its purpose is to increase compliance with taxation laws by extending the use of the tax file number scheme. Before a reportable payment is made, the tax file number of the payee must be quoted. If this does not happen, tax is deducted at the 48 per cent rate for payment to the commissioner.

There is a very real concern that this system will be cost-effective for neither the government nor the fishing industry. In fact, there will be increased costs for wholesalers, associated with keeping records and complying with the system. As happens to all price takers in the fishing industry, these costs will be passed on to the producer or the fisherman, who will have to bear the extra cost.

I will use the fishing industry as an example. For several years, the fishing industry has been scrutinised by the tax office, and tax compliance has been found to be good. Now within the industry, under the new reportable payments system, payments will have to be recorded as the product moves through each wholesaler. In reality, this could happen many times for the same fish products. A fish could move from a local wholesaler, to a Sydney wholesaler and on to an Adelaide wholesaler. The same fish may be reported six times to the tax office in Canberra. The real tax avoider in the industry is the amateur fisherman who on-sells to retailers and other outlets. They will not be caught by this new tax system. They will continue to sell their catches for cash through the black market.

The reportable payments system will impose extra costs on buyers, which will be passed on to producers through lower returns, while the black-market seller will continue undetected outside the tax system. These problems are also plainly there in the building industry, where the prescribed payments system is costing builders several days' paperwork a month. I will address these problems in the committee stage of the bill, when I will seek assurances from the minister that the reportable payments scheme will be assessed within a period of time and, if it is shown not to be effective, it will be removed from the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts has provided a Greens (WA) response to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 and stated our position on the amendments. I wish to take the opportunity to place on the public record a serious concern we have regarding the interaction between this bill, the use of tax file numbers and the connection with both the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security. This is referred to in the bill, and I will come back to it in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts mentioned briefly that those who work intermittently experience the problem of continually reporting their changing circumstances to the Department of Social Security. I will speak on the difficulties that impact on social security recipients and the way in which the tax file number has become a de facto Australia Card.

The government seems determined to make a mockery of its initial rhetoric about tax file numbers. When the system was introduced, we were told that no one would be compelled to provide a tax file number; it would be used only to detect tax fraud. Since then, the net has been thrown wider, and the use of tax file numbers is being justified as a means of reducing social security fraud.

The government has now shown that its desire to extend the use of tax file numbers knows no bounds. Since the decision of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court—which all found that Mr John Malloch was not obliged to provide a tax file number under the Social Security Act—that very Social Security Act has been changed. The implications and principles underlying those decisions have been disregarded by the Department of Social Security to such an extent that more than 36,000 people have been denied social security benefits or have had them stopped. It is outrageous that the government still informed people that they were required to provide their tax file numbers even immediately after the decision in the Malloch case. That directly contradicted the Federal Court's decision.

I requested information—as did Senator Woodley and the honourable member for Stirling, Mr Eoin Cameron—regarding the way in which the request for tax file numbers had been used to deny benefits to people. We were astonished to receive a table from the Hon. Janice Crosio, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, which showed that 31,000 people had their payment stopped; 4,000 people had made a voluntary surrender of their tax file number; and 1,142 new claims had been refused. Overall, a total of 36,684 claims were stopped because of a refusal to provide a tax file number. This is a very disturbing trend.

I can understand the government's need to minimise social security fraud, but its measures to achieve this appear to be focused more on withholding benefits than on pursuing fraudulent claims. It is hardly a compelling argument to suggest that, if 36,000 people refuse to give their tax file numbers, it is an admission that the claim for a benefit was fraudulently based. It is a very novel way to approach the criminal code, and I am sure it would not be appreciated within the courts. Yet the government seems to include all such savings in its figures on fraud minimisation—further proof that it considers this is its main measure of assessing fraud. I object to it strongly.

Clause 220AF of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) states that there will be a deduction from reportable payment if a payee's tax file number is not quoted. This bill will supposedly benefit members of the community who are otherwise disadvantaged, but it is yet another subtle way of introducing a penalty if they fail to produce a tax file number.

I must confess that I have not gone through all the intricacies of subdivision C to find the ways in which the tax file number is implicated so that I can provide a detailed critique here and now. I will raise these matters during the committee stage and, no doubt, will be enlightened by the minister.

Finally, I would like to repeat something I said in the debate about the social security act being used to close the loopholes that were justified and supported by Mr Malloch's court action. If the government wants to use the tax file number as a universal identifier, the Australian people should be told about it. I believe that this is a matter of concern and that is my reason for placing it on the public record now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be canvassing a number of matters that have already been canvassed in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994. However, I would like to say that I agree very strongly with the view that has been expressed during this debate that the government's promise prior to the last election of $30 a week for carers of children at home was and is a fraud. There is no other word that can express the widespread deception that was perpetrated on the public of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Many people, particularly women, were saying, `Isn't that good. I will now be truly free to choose to give up my part-time job and care full-time for my children.' There were many who wanted to give away a full-time job, cutting it down to a part-time job and access what they thought was a belated recognition of the work of parents, normally the mothers, in caring for children at home.

They were led to believe this because the child-care cash rebate scheme was also bandied about through the length and breadth of Australia before the same election. Now they realise that all they were getting was $2.60 a week. This bill is designed to knock off $28.40 from the pay packets of the workers of Australia. That is what this bill is all about and, in my view, that is a disgrace. The workers of Australia will soon be well aware of the subterfuge and the fraud perpetrated upon them. They will be well aware of it when, whether they be male or female workers, their pay packets are cut by $28.40 a week.

The suggestion has been made that it was necessary for this to occur so that the carers, normally the mothers, get some of the dependent spouse rebate in their hands. Of course, many mothers are the managers of the home finances and already get the whole pay packet every week. That is generally the case. It was certainly the case in my family—I was going to say `when I was working'—before I came into this place. Has it never occurred to the government that, instead of setting up the enormous bureaucratic bungle that will take place, the simple way to do this is to ensure that when workers make out the form for a dependent spouse rebate they nominate the bank account into which it should be paid on behalf of the carer. That would be the simple thing to do and would achieve the objective.

My worry—I will come back to this later—is that what will happen to this scheme is what has already happened to the family allowance payment, now called family payment. The value of that allowance has decreased substantially over the years and I am concerned that the same will happen here.

But before I continue with that, I would like to refer to something that Senator Boswell mentioned in his contribution to this debate. I agree with what Senator Boswell had to say about the fishing industry: there is a problem with reportable payments. The proposal to force taxpayers to report payments by PAYE tax file number or have 48.4 per cent withheld is a potential massive extension of bureaucracy. The reason for self-assessment was to free tax officials from assessing and allow them to undertake extensive auditing. Why is it necessary to turn taxpayers into enforcement agents? I would like Senator Sherry to take this on notice so that he can answer it tomorrow.

The fact is that thousands of honest people are being forced to become unpaid tax collectors. The fishing industry—an industry of central importance to Tasmania—has been targeted. I do not want to see honest, hard working people sent broke because of a requirement to handle more unpaid paperwork. As Senator Boswell said, one fish might have to be counted several times for the purposes of this particular measure.

If the government wants to introduce this system, it should pay a commission to business people who are being asked to collect its taxes for it. The interesting thing is that these are very practical people. They are doing often very bulky work for the people who benefit from that work—us. We are the ones who benefit from the fishing industry. They have to set aside precious time to do the work of the government and, in my view, that is not appropriate.
I would now like to return to the matter of the child-care rebate. It was bad enough that the government tried to deceive and short change families prior to the last election—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! It being 6.50 p.m., I propose to call on government documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to examine Labor's neglect of Australia's greatest export industry. Tourism is probably the most competitive industry in the world today, and within this industry Australia has a lot of talented players, with dynamic entrepreneurs and unparalleled natural assets. However, it should be kept in perspective. I refer the chamber to the annual report of the Department of Tourism, where it is pointed out that, even though tourism is awfully important to this country, from the point of view of the share of the world tourism market, Australia gets 0.6 per cent of world tourists into Australia. So there is an enormous potential out there to increase that potential, and the result would be a positive effect in regard to our balance of payments and, of course, the unconscionable level of foreign debt that we have in this country.

PARA.TAB: But the Labor government, through its ignorance, has embarked on a campaign, subtle though it is, to actually suck revenue out of the industry and damage its viability in the world markets. If we are to retain even the relatively small percentage we have and increase it, we must be competitive throughout the world. Currently, there is no doubt, this is an attractive country to visit, but the important thing is to keep it that way. I do not care whether we are talking about social, environmental or other matters, but certainly from an economic view it must continue to be attractive.

To start with, the most important impediment to the industry, the one that is the greatest disincentive to the industry, is the Industrial Relations Act. When one talks to potential tourist operators, whether it be on the Gold Coast, Cairns, the northern parts of New South Wales or anywhere in the country, they all indicate that it is a great disincentive to investment—and, of course, without investment we are not going to have the facilities to attract the tourists.

The act was absurdly suggested to be micro-economic reform, whereas, in fact, it made the workplace inflexible and less productive. One of the great disincentives, even though, on the face of it, it appeared to have some merit, is the so-called unfair dismissals provision. It means that potential legal liability for employers is such that they resist the temptation, which they would like to succumb to, to put people on the full-time work force.

Then there is the other monster created by the Labor Party, that is, the quite complex fringe benefits tax and some of the silly things that have come with it. The main purpose for the introduction of the fringe benefits tax—this was the story told by the government at the time—was to get people to cash out the so-called benefits that were being given to people who were abusing the system. It has gone a lot further than that, and in this financial year alone the fringe benefits tax will bring in $3.2 billion.

That in itself is bad enough for all industry, but I think the worst part of it, by a long shot, is the complexity of it and having to account for it. For example, it might sound ludicrous, but it is the case that, if people use their mobile telephones in their office, which they would not do, it is okay; but if they use them outside the office, they have to account for them or pay fringe benefits tax. Anyone in this place with a mobile phone would know that that is one of the most ludicrous things one could possibly imagine. So that has to be addressed.

There is also the idea, which Labor politicians keep putting forward from time to time for an industry that is really growing, that there should be additional taxes. This is a government of high taxes; it is a government that hits industries when they can least afford it. The Labor member for Lilley, Mr Wayne Swan, has been saying that there should be the introduction of a bed tax. I quote him:

SPEECH.PARA: New taxes on hotel rooms and restaurants would be consistent with our philosophy of a progressive approach to taxation.

I think the industry should be put on notice that that is the hidden agenda of the government and that it is only a matter of time before these additional taxes are imposed. In the short time I have left, I would like to commend the head of the department, Ms Williams, in her thrust to appreciate regional development and the Australian Tourist Commission. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few comments on the 1993-94 annual report of the Department of Tourism. In a number of ways this is actually a welcome report. Tourism is one of the few industries where the government is apparently adopting a strategic approach. There is a national tourism strategy in place, and there is targeted government support to achieve the objectives of that program. This is something that the Australian Democrats have been pushing for in terms of targeted strategic sector by sector industry plans, and tourism is one of the areas where the government has adopted, or appears to have adopted, that attitude.

PARA.TAB: There seems to be some recognition that tourism is a major potential employer and that, since market forces are not clearing our dole queues, there is a need for government programs to develop a major new employing industry. There is, of course, some concern that many of the jobs that are created in the tourism industry are jobs which are not well paid and do not have a career structure, but as time goes on, it is to be hoped, we will rectify that. The increased number of programs and the funding for these programs as detailed in the report are certainly welcome, and I hope that the government will maintain its commitment to these programs.

I should say, though, by way of criticism of this report, that much of the material that is offered in the performance overview sections tends to be a discussion of what has been done in a descriptive way without detailing the actual impact of the programs; and that is possibly something that could be addressed in a future report.

My other criticism relates to a comment which is out of step with the government's apparent commitment to the industry. Why did the government discriminate against single-service tourism operators in its May white paper, allowing only 25 per cent of eligible expenditure to be claimed under the export market development grants program as against the 50 per cent which is available to all other industries?

Tourism generates business not only for the firms undertaking the promotion but also for other Australian companies. That would suggest to me that it deserves more, rather than less, support than other industries. I trust that that is a policy of the government that will receive some review and that the inadequate allowance that the government is prepared to make at this stage will be rectified in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to address a couple of comments to the annual report of the Department of Tourism, particularly those parts related to regional development and to development and promotion of tourism in rural and regional Australia. I must say that there is not much this government does that I agree with, but I think that it is heading in the right direction with the program it has on some support and assistance for development and for development strategies for tourism in regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: I notice that Mr Lee in the other place mentioned me and compared me with Mr Ted Lindsay, the honourable member for Herbert, in raising awareness of this, but of course Mr Lindsay is seen as a fairly ineffectual member. It was, I thought, part of my role as the coalition spokesman on regional matters to draw to the attention of regional councils, regional tourist organisations and regional development boards the availability of these government funds. It is not 100 per cent perfect—nothing this government does is—but it is a step in the right direction and whilst the money is available, I am very happy to raise the awareness of the program in regional areas.

This report indicates that there is $23 million available for this program over a four-year period to assist regional areas to develop opportunities that will increase their capacity to draw both domestic and international tourists. Funding is being provided for initiatives that will generate long-term economic employment, provide sustainable tourism growth through responsible planning and management, diversify the tourism product base, raise tourism industry standards and, to a limited extent, provide tourism infrastructure.

This program, whilst heading in the right direction, did have a noticeable flaw, and that is that there was no cooperation, contact or discussion with state governments, some of whom were doing the same sorts of things. It is a pity that the Federal government cannot manage itself properly to coordinate its programs with programs existing in various of the state governments.

The department's reporting in this paper of a $4 million rural tourism program over four years again is a step in the right direction. But it seems that the question must be asked why that amount of money is being made available for rural tourism programs when five million Australians, that is one in three, live in rural and regional areas. It is interesting to note in passing that ATSIC received more than that—that is, $5 million—for the promotion of tourism in Aboriginal and Islander areas.

In the brief time that I have had to look at this report I note that the Cape York Peninsula Development Association was the recipient of $68,000 to develop a plan to ensure tourist access to this wilderness area is economically, environmentally and socially sustainable. That is an area which I think will benefit from some planning. One of the things that is desperately needed there is toilet facilities along the road from Cooktown to the Cape. There are a lot of complaints that there are no facilities available. At many times of the year that trail looks like one long string of toilet paper because there are no facilities available.

Unfortunately, the Cook Shire Council does not have the rate base to make those facilities available. That is something that both the Queensland and the Federal governments have to look at, because that is a significant tourist area in northern, regional Australia and one which does need some assistance and some support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment briefly on this report. In the time that I have had available to look at it, which has not been long, I have been struck by the significant increase in overseas visitor arrivals from just under one million in 1983 when this government took office to three million visitors last year. Senator Ian Macdonald has, a little reluctantly, acknowledged the contribution of this government in the success of these visitor arrivals from overseas. If we look at the comparative export earnings for tourism, vis a vis the other industry sectors in Australia, we see that tourism has gone from a little over $2 1/4 billion to well over $10 billion in 1993-94, in fact surpassing industries such as coal, manufacturers, gold, wool, wheat and transport equipment. It is a sign of the times of the importance of tourism to our economy.

PARA.TAB: The other issue of interest, although I do not think it is detailed here, has been the shift in tourism from the European region to the Asian region, and particularly the make-up of people within the Asian region. The statistics show that whilst the number of visitor intake arrivals in Japan has continued to increase, the intake arrivals in other Asian countries have gone up 36 per cent in one year. That is a staggering increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a ministerial statement, Nick?

—No, it is not a ministerial statement. I am genuinely interested in the issue, and I will be concluding in about a minute. The other area that is important, and which I think is the key to the success of strategies and programs to meet tourism and environment goals, is outlined on page 20. It lists the number of very significant programs that this government has developed. Senator Ian Macdonald quite rightly highlighted the regional tourism development program. That is a program of great significance to my own state of Tasmania where tourism—
—Do you think woodchipping is good for it?

—We will argue about woodchipping another day. Very significant areas of Tasmania are put aside as wilderness areas; in fact, a much greater proportion of Tasmania—I think it is close to 24 per cent. Certainly they are a very significant tourism attraction. Unlike Senator Margetts, I am one who believes that we can have both. We can have appropriately set aside and managed national parks and wilderness areas, we can have a forest industry based on forestry, including woodchipping, and we can have a tourist industry co-existing. Finally, I want to acknowledge the role of the minister, Mr Lee, one of our most impressive ministers who does a fine job in this area. I know that tonight he is putting together—
—He is not part of your faction.

—He is not part of my faction but as that wacky motion that Senator Ian Macdonald tabled the other day and spoke to shows, he just does not understand the culture of the Labor Party. He does not understand our culture.
—You are a bit sensitive about that one, aren't you?

—I am not sensitive. I can have as decent a conversation with Michael Lee as a member of the Right as I can with anyone else in this government, because the way we develop policy and the way we handle our relationships stands in marked contrast to that of those opposite.

PARA.TAB: This is an excellent report and the growth in this industry is particularly impressive. It is obviously not all driven by government—we have to acknowledge the very important and critical role of private entrepreneurs in the industry. But for our return for dollar, bang for buck—the amount of money we contribute and the amount of money we receive back vis a vis employment growth and industry development—it is a very impressive industry and a very impressive report. We all know that the opposition was going to slug the industry with a goods and services tax at the last election that would have knocked it for six. Those opposite cannot criticise our tax proposals in this area; we do not have any, unlike the opposition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority

TALK.START.PARA: —The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority is charged mainly with two tasks. One is that of promoting the restructuring and revitalisation of the TCF industries to improve their efficiency, and the other is in the long term to reduce the dependence of those industries on assistance from the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The TCFDA administers the industry's development strategy, which comprises four programs. The first is incentives for international competitiveness by way of adjustment grants; and $87 million has been committed since 1988-89, according to the report. The program was closed on 4 October 1993 for a very bizarre reason, that `requests for assistance far outweighed the remaining funds'. It seems odd that if we are trying to assist an industry to change—and there is evidence of that with the many applications on the table before government—we throw our towel in and say, `There is just too much to be done. We will not do anything'. I will return to that point a little later. The second is the further wool processing program and $40 million has been committed to that. The third is the infrastructure support program and capitalisation grants program, at a cost of $159 million; and, fourthly, the imports credit scheme, with $212 million in credits over the past three years.

Mostly, this report presents the changes in the TCF industry as a success story, noting recent impressive increases in exports, production and profitability. It is certainly true that the industry has restructured, moving away from high-volume mass production, where it cannot compete with low-wage countries, and moving more into high value-added areas. That is to be commended. However, two points need to be made. The social cost of this transition has been enormous. Despite the improved performance of the industry over the last couple of years, the industry employs some 30,000 fewer people than it did prior to the decision to cut protection. The impact on local communities in places like Ararat where major plants—the lifeblood of the town—have closed down has been disastrous.

The costs in general terms, both the direct social security cost and the social impact, have been horrendous. The change has been and continues to be major. But why the hurry? Why does it have to be done so fast that we cannot keep pace with the social change, the retraining and the development of alternatives that need to happen? Table 2.1 in the report shows the phase-out of bounty arrangements for the TCF industry from rates of 22 per cent to zero in just two years. Changes can certainly be made and industries could be made more efficient, without damage to people's lives, if the government were to take into account a more reasonable time scale and do so gradually.

The haste and pressure that have been exercised on the industry have led to the development of sweatshop industries, backyarders and subcontractors who work for a pittance. I believe that is an extremely unhealthy development. It has been well and truly documented, not least by a series of articles in the Melbourne Age by Mr Heinrich. The point of these arguments is that further transitory finance support from the government must be provided. A pause in the rate of tariff reductions would also be appropriate, as would supplementary funding for the various TCFDA schemes. The adjustment period is certainly not over, and this report tells that story.

The industry's peak body, the TCF council, recently lodged a submission with the future strategies committee. It gives a detailed and well thought out analysis of future directions for the industry. The Australian Democrats support the call in that submission for a further $200 million in funding to be made available over the five years from 1996 to 2000 to assist the industries in continuing to upgrade plant and equipment, to facilitate appropriate skills development, to adopt best practice and workplace reform, and to strengthen supply line relationships and other industrial networks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority was charged with the deregulation and restructuring of the TCF sector. The avowed intention of these measures was to encourage efficiency and competitiveness. We note also that international agreements, including the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have had great impact. At various times the government has said that the tariff reductions are not as a result of the GATT. Of course we all know that is nonsense. That actually went far ahead of what was required under the Uruguay Round of GATT.

PARA.TAB: What happened is that we simply opened our borders to cheap imports. Is this bad? Does it benefit Australians? Does this benefit the developing nations that mostly produce these goods? Clothes are probably cheaper than they would be if they were made here, although evidence in the United States shows that investment in capital intensive technological improvements in productivity can result in a product competitive with clothes made in some of the African states where labour is cheapest. But this is not happening here. Industry in Australia is not interested in technological improvement. Productivity is interpreted as paying less for the same work—paying less per worker.

The argument from government is that we should not be bothering with this kind of job or industry. It talks about clever countries, sunrise industries and the export of things like environmental technology. The government pins a lot of hope on the export of environmental technology. What this means is that in a large area of consumer buying we become dependent on imports. Industries here close down. The balance of payments suffers and jobs are lost. How many people can work in the TCF industry? Realistically, how many people will work in producing environmental technology?

This report seems to say that the authority has somehow managed to improve the industry, with at least some exports going up. But all anyone has to do is to walk into virtually any clothing shop to see the truth. Page 15 of the report shows that exports have increased by about $200 million, but the column above says that imports have increased by $500 million. That is an addition of $300 million to our trade deficit. This is the policy that we are introducing, supposedly to make things better for Australia.

We have virtually ceased producing for our own needs. Investment figures, which are also shown in this document, do not relate to domestic employment, but to exporting jobs in other countries. Virtually all the clothes and cloth is produced overseas, mainly in China. Cloth from China is also priced at a level where it is often cheaper to buy finished clothes than to buy the cloth to make them at home. What is produced here is often made in sweatshops. As Senator Spindler quite rightly said, there are sweatshops in Victoria in 1994.

This brings us to another problem. It is not the final customers who make the market choices; it is the wholesalers and distributors. For them, it makes sense to get track shoes made in Indonesia or wherever, with labour costs of a dollar or two. This is much cheaper than buying them from the United States or in Australia. There is a cost saving, but it does not make sense for them to pass those savings on to customers. The distributors have been making incredible market pushes for Nike, Adidas and other shoes. The distributors and retailers can also control the availability of alternatives—and the perception of the quality of these alternatives. So those same shoes made in Indonesia are sold for $100, $120 or $150. Even if a company can make a product whose final price is competitive with imports, it will not be competitive with the final profit margin made by the manufacturer, distributor or retailer.

It does not help the developing nations. If we look particularly at the TCF industry overseas, we see it as one of the areas where worker conditions are the worst. Frequently, the companies involved in underpaying workers are TCF companies. Underpaying in Indonesia means paying workers less than $1 per day, rather than the minimum wage of $1.80. In Thailand, it means paying two or three dollars, instead of the minimum wage of $5 per day. The average Chinese factory worker gets $39 a month. The disparity between rich and poor in developing countries is huge—and growing. The argument of competitiveness is used in all these countries to keep wages down, when any argument is offered at will.

The Treasurer, Mr Willis, said last week in Madrid at the IMF meeting that no measures should be taken to integrate environmental or labour standards into trade. The managing director of the IMF was even more honest about the economic agenda, saying that the IMF believes any minimum wage levels anywhere, as well as unemployment benefits or any restriction on the ability of companies to sack workers when they wish, is an impediment to global growth.

As a consequence, workers in developing nations will be more and more intensely exploited for the benefit of the rich in their own nations and elsewhere. The result will be a situation where every nation will be under pressure to reduce its own standards and protective measures, or be marginalised economically. It is true that high tariffs cannot work. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about an aircraft accident which occurred at Edinburgh RAAF base in 1990. An air force pilot was killed in this accident when the tail of his Nomad fell off. As a result of that accident, the exchange between ministers as to the reasons for the crash and other matters which I do not wish to go into tonight, the ombudsman was asked to investigate the adequacy of the RAAF response to that loss of a Nomad A18401.

PARA.TAB: The ombudsman has gone through a fairly long process of inquiry and produced a draft report, which was sent out to all parties for comment, as is the requirement under section 15 of the Ombudsman Act 1976. The final report has been completed and is now available. It makes a number of trenchant comments about a number of government instrumentalities. The ombudsman says:

SPEECH.PARA: All submissions received were carefully considered in preparation of the Ombudsman's final report.
The ombudsman continues:

The RAAF's investigation was conducted well and identified many deficiencies. The RAAF found that the tailplane of the aircraft had disintegrated in flight because of existing cracking, which would have been discovered had an acceptance servicing on delivery to ARDU been carried out in August 1989. The cracking would also have been discovered had ARDU carried out an Anti-Deterioration Servicing, due no later than 6 March 1990—
which would have been just before the accident occurred. The ombudsman also said:
. . . the RAAF did not go far enough to attribute individual responsibility for the deficiencies found and gave inadequate consideration to the question of disciplinary action.
I will come back to that later. The ombudsman acknowledged:
The RAAF did not attempt any `cover up' of any issue relating to or flowing from the crash.
In relation to the Government Aircraft Factory, the ombudsman found:

The GAF's design of the tailplane was defective. The tailplane failed to meet Australian Civil Certification standards. The defect was known to GAF as early as 1981-82 . . . GAF failed in its responsibility to adequately advise the RAAF, Defence and the CAA of the extent of the problem and remedial action necessary to bring the aircraft back to certification standard. In fact, the GAF appears to have deliberately withheld information in order to obscure the extent of the problem.
The ombudsman also said:

GAF also failed to substantiate its hypotheses about the causes and growth of cracking or to undertake fatigue analysis of the tailplane . . . GAF continued to advertise the Nomad as having a fatigue life in excess of 30,000 hours—when in fact no fatigue life for the tailplane had been established.
In relation to AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd, the ombudsman found:

ASTA did not maintain Nomad A18-401 in an airworthy state in accordance with the terms of its loan contract with the RAAF . . . ASTA failed to recognise the servicing required at the end of its program of running the aircraft's engines while on the ground . . . ASTA failed to prepare a Condition Acceptance Report at the expiry of the loan . . . ASTA's . . . failure to substantiate its understanding of the causes of the cracking significantly increased the final cost to the Commonwealth for its remedy—now estimated by the Department of Defence to be in excess of $6,000,000 . . . ASTA failed to respond to the airworthiness issues set out in letters from the CAA in June 1989 concerning the origins and nature of the tailplane cracking.

The ombudsman also gives ASTA the credit for pursuing the causes of tailplane cracking since the crash and designing and installing modifications to resolve the problem. The Civil Aviation Authority was the next government instrumentality to come under the microscope. The ombudsman said:

Despite a decade of unsuccessful modifications carried out by the manufacturer (GAF), the CAA failed to obtain from ASTA a full explanation of ASTA's understanding of the causes of cracking . . . The CAA, having received a Major Defect Report on a Nomad aircraft nine months before the crash of A18-401, failed to take proper and responsible action to obtain answers from ASTA. As a result of this failure it was in no position to act to maintain Nomad air safety and in consequence precluded itself from preventing the loss of A18-401 . . . Since the crash, the CAA has actively pursued its responsibilities, to ensure that ASTA understands the problem . . .

I am concerned particularly about the sheeting home of responsibility to individuals. I am also concerned that this report entitled Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman: Investigation into adequacy of RAAF response to loss of Nomad A18-401 has not been tabled. I seek leave to table this report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been drawn to my attention that, because of the long delays since this accident, the family of the deceased pilot is now precluded from having the satisfaction of seeing Defence Force personnel who may well be guilty of negligence and certainly have been severely criticised in the ombudsman's report brought to justice. I am told by the ombudsman that the reason for this is that under the Defence Force Discipline Act there is a statutory bar after three years for disciplinary action. I question whether the common law does not prevail, so that people who may be guilty of manslaughter can still be charged with a serious offence, which appears to be the case here. That is a matter which deserves further investigation. I am not entirely satisfied with the answers given by the RAAF in the ombudsman's draft report, but he has reported them in his final report.

PARA.TAB: I am also concerned that it has taken so long for this report to be tabled. On 27 June this year Mr Bill Taylor, in the other place, made a short speech saying he expected the report to be tabled within a week. Of course, it was not. Mr Peter Reith, the then shadow minister for defence, on 30 August wrote to Minister Ray saying he had received representations from the family of Flight Lieutenant Glenn Donovan seeking to have the report by the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman on this matter tabled in the parliament and that the family believed that this would be appropriate recognition of the significance of the report and its findings.

As the requests seemed reasonable, Mr Reith asked Senator Ray to give favourable consideration to tabling the report. We are now in October and there is still no sign from the government that it is prepared to table this important report. So I have taken the action which I have tonight to make the Senate aware of this damning report of a number of government agencies, of the vulnerability of pilots in Australia who are flying Nomad aircraft and of the failure by the people who are responsible for maintaining Nomad aircraft, particularly air force Nomads, which lead to this loss of life. I understand that some Nomads at the Oakey school of military aviation have just recently been grounded.

This is a serious matter which deserves the attention of the Senate. I hope that we can produce a reference for the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade so that it can take up the findings and recommendations of this report, the reason for the government's failure to table it and also the legal question relating to holding people accountable where they have been negligent in the pursuit of their duties. Action may well be available to be taken against people in ASTA or the CAA.

As shadow minister for defence, I certainly want to see that any airmen in this country, who are already engaged in a dangerous occupation, have in place every safety protection available to them. I do not expect servicemen or civilians servicing aircraft to be negligent in their duties. I am sure that the Senate would agree with me on that. I commend this report to the Senate and ask for the issues I have outlined to be investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to pay tribute to Mr Brian Mulherin, a great Queenslander and Australian, who died suddenly on 29 July 1994. I know the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, would want to be associated with this tribute as well. Brian Mulherin was President of the Brisbane South branch of the Association of Independent Retirees. Indeed, he helped to establish the Brisbane South branch of the association in 1992 and was the founding president of that branch as well as the driving force both of the branch and of the association in Queensland. He was serving as Vice-President of the Queensland division of the Association of Independent Retirees and was about to assume the role of Queensland president at the time of his death.

PARA.TAB: After travelling and working overseas in his younger days, Brian Mulherin spent most of his working life in the oil industry. He started working in the industry in Mackay and worked throughout Queensland and New South Wales. He was a passionate follower of the sport of rugby union and was on the formation committee to establish Ballymore, Brisbane's famous home of rugby union. He also worked in senior roles for many years for the Souths rugby club and would no doubt have been pleased to see the great success which that club has achieved in recent years, especially as the club spent many years as battlers in the Brisbane rugby competition.

From my own experiences with Brian Mulherin, it was always very clear that he had a strong and enthusiastic commitment to the cause of independent retirees and their struggle to prevent being forgotten and overlooked by governments throughout Australia. Indeed, he played a part in making the AIR one of the most effective lobby groups that I have dealt with.

Prior to his death, Brian Mulherin was working on achieving an organisational restructuring of the Association of Independent Retirees to enhance its effectiveness and to strengthen its organisation. I know his contribution has been highly valued by the association. I always found him to be very helpful and open in my dealings with him. I recall a very lively forum which he chaired during the election campaign last year. It was a forum in which Senator Alston, Minister Con Sciacca and I debated a number of issues. It was a pretty lively forum but he was a very able chair. I remember at the end of the forum as he was thanking the three of us for speaking that he predicted that either Senator Alston or Con Sciacca would be a minister and that I would be elected. With a record like that, he might have missed his calling as a political analyst. He was certainly doing better than many of the other analysts. Anyway, that is one memory which I have of his ability.

The enormous amount of voluntary work done by Brian Mulherin in so many aspects of the community is a prime example of the unsung but crucial contribution made by people in a voluntary capacity throughout Australia. It is important that the value of such work is recognised by society, by government and, I trust, by the Senate. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I extend my sympathies to Mr Mulherin's wife and two children.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Building

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to remind the Senate tonight of the magnificent edifice that has been built alongside Parliament House which is affectionately known as Gareth's Gazebo. I had a feeling of `I told you so' this morning when I read in the Australian about this $165 million edifice—this very expensive memorial that is being built to remind us of what a wonderful person our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) is. The joke is, of course, that it is not big enough.
—That is what the paper says.

—That is what the paper says and that is exactly what the Public Works Committee said back in 1992 when the then deputy chair of the committee, Bill Taylor, Bruce Scott and I put in a dissenting report to the committee report that approved the construction of this extravagant building.

PARA.TAB: This government is so inept that it is building this huge edifice at a cost of $165 million. Back then, we made the point that there were cheaper and better options. In fact, in our dissenting report we talked about refurbishing and adding to the existing building. We stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This option would supply an extra 14,000 square metres and an additional 240 car parking spaces. At an estimated cost of only $102m . . .

We are going to end up with a building that has cost $165 million plus a refurbishment of the old DFAT building which will have to be used to take up the slack of this huge government department at a cost of at least another $80 million—all because our foreign minister wants something built in his memory next to Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: At that time, the conscience of the Labor Party, former Senator Peter Walsh, was absolutely adamant that that building should not be proceeded with. He lobbied me; he lobbied the Public Works Committee. A majority of members of the Public Works Committee, including Labor Party members, after they had seen the figures, the proposal and the gross extravagance of this building, were going to vote against it. But at the end of the day, the old Labor Party mates trick worked. They were squeezed, they were pushed, they were shoved. One of the members did not turn up for the vote and the other one reluctantly supported the government, under threat. So this controversial project—

TALK.START.PARA: —What threat?

—Under threat, yes. Senator Sherry might like to talk to Russ Gorman; he will tell him all about it. So this Taj Mahal which is being built for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is going ahead. We see today that they are fighting over who is going to have which desk. We made the point in our dissenting report to the Public Works Committee report that this huge building would provide no extra space than what was already available in the old building. The alternative that we put forward, and which was put forward to the Public Works Committee in 1985 and approved, was overridden by the government, all at the whim of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

PARA.TAB: I make one further comment. I found out today some information about another edifice that has been built in Canberra—the buildings just keep on coming—the Social Security building at Tuggeranong. An amount of $4.5 million is being spent on landscaping. The country is just coming out of recession and $4.5 million is being spent on landscaping. I just cannot believe it. With these extravagances here in Canberra, it is no wonder that people around Australia keep asking questions. The expenditure of $4.5 million on landscaping makes the purchase of a mansion

SPEECH.PARA: in Sydney for $2.2 million pale into insignificance.
